4428101/4378295/4443984.title: Story
4428101/4378295/4443984.text:
When St. Carthage was crossing the Ferry - when entering Lismore first - he met the two daughters of the Chieftain. To one of them he offered an apple for which she reached out her left hand. A second time he offered it and again, she put forward the left hand. She was unable to use her right hand as she and her sister were joined together.The third time he told her to put out the right hand. This she did, proving he at once had worked a miracle. Given bySeán DooleyChristina Brother SchoolsPortlaoighis



Finn Mac Cumhaill and his wife lived at Baile Fhinn.A Scottish giant, hearing of Finn's prowess, came over to have a Comhraic Aonair. Before he reached the house, Finn's wife saw him.
(continues on next page)

4427880/4353938/4444440.title: A Story
4427880/4353938/4444440.text:
(continued from previous page)
Phúca". The man did not mind this because he was drunk. He thought it was his own dog coming to meet him. He was all the time telling him "to lay down" but he wouldn't. The man went to the back of the cart to give the dog a kick. The dogs vanished and he saw them no more.



A Story.There was a man living in Kilmaine and his name was Millar. He was playing dice once in Dublin with a woman that was supposed to be a witch.
(continues on next page)

4428164/4382868/4447844.title: Ballyquin High Stone
4428164/4382868/4447844.text: This stone is situated about 100 yards from Picketts Cross. Tradition says that a tailor living here was ordered by a giant to make a suit of clothes for him in a certain time. When the giant came for the clothes the tailor had not them ready, and the giant was so angry that he threw this stone at the tailor and burned him under it. The marks of the giant's fingers are to be seen on the stone.
4428164/4382868/4447844.school_info: School: Cluain Fhiadh (C.), Carraig na Siúire

4428079/4375986/4450260.title: Story
4428079/4375986/4450260.text:
Once upon a time there was a giant living two miles this side of Belmullet at Glencastle. He was a very strong man. His name was "Conán". The secret of his strength lay in his hair. No one knew the secret but his wife. His wife's name was "Muning".One day a pirate captain came to the shore at Broadhaven bay, and he came to where "Conán" lived. The pirate bribed the giant's wife and at last she told him that the secret of his strength lay in his hair. The pirate told the woman to shave him while he
(continues on next page)

4428153/4382220/4450871.title: Stories about Giants
4428153/4382220/4450871.text:
Long ago giants used throw rocks from one place to the other.  There was a giant in Kilmacomb and another in Ballyscanlon.  They used throw rocks to see who could throw the heaviest rock or who could throw the furthest.  One day as they were throwing the rocks the two rocks hit together up in the sky near Cloughernagh.  The rocks fell down in the strand at Cloughernagh.  The giants finger marks are to be seen on the rocks always.



The Leipricaun is known locally as the lurgadán or sometimes leipricaun.  He is very small only a few inches in height.  I do not know how is he dressed.  He lives under a red dock leaf or some times under a mushroom.  His usual occupation is making shoes
(continues on next page)

4427851/4350633/4451373.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4427851/4350633/4451373.text: Once upon a time there lived a very cruel giant and the people could not get rid of him. He lived to be a very old man doing a lot of harm to the people. But at last he died. When he was buried his people put a bottle of water over his grave and whoever would drink three drops out of this bottle the giant would appear. One day a man came and said he would try it. He took the first drop and when he had the second drop taken the ground began to shake for miles round. The man got afraid and fled from the field.

4427914/4357495/4452195.title: The Giant's Rock
4427914/4357495/4452195.text: There is a huge rock on side of Thiesteen hill about a quarter of a mile from this school and it is called the giant's rock. At this side of the rock there is a big cave and it is said in the district that there was a giant living in this cave long ago. He used to come out at times and plunder the district and then return to his hiding place with his spoils. There were other giants living in the castle at Barnacogue about half a mile away and they had such strong voices that they could be heard a long way off when talking, while it only took one step to do the journey from the castle to the rock. The giant in Thiestun was so strong that he could pull this big rock over his cave and shut himself up when pursued. He was so heavy that one day when he stood on the rock he left the track of his foot on it and this track is to be seen up to the present time. There is also something in the shape of a gun cut in the place of the rock.

4428151/4382116/4452525.title: Games we Play
4428151/4382116/4452525.text:
(continued from previous page)
side pull "Tug of War". The game is replayed over again.



Two Giants lived in this locality hundreds of years ago. Their names were Longa and Cannon. They often indulged in stone-throwing. One day the two giants had a contest. They wished to see who would throw a stone the longest distance. They stood on a hill. One of the stones fell in a field in Drumcannon. The marks of the giants [g] fingers are still to be seen on the stone. Carriglong is named after longa and Drumcannon is named after Cannon. Longa's
(continues on next page)

4428218/4386851/4456567.title: Gleann na Smól or Glenasmole
4428218/4386851/4456567.text: Glen na Smólor Glenasmole.Glen of "the Black Patch"The black patch been (it is said) the black patch mark left on the ground after the old Bruidhean (Bóthar na Bruidhne) had been burned down.At the end of the grounds of Heathfield Lodge (near here) is a huge boulder into which a marble slab was insertedOn the slab was the following inscription.Finmackoon, one of the Irish Giants carried this stone on his shoulders from the opposite mountain on April 1st 1444. He was 9ft 7ins in height and weighed 44 stones

4428088/4377105/4458299.title: Old Ruins
4428088/4377105/4458299.text:
(continued from previous page)
farmers residence, quite close to the ruins of the old castle.



It is told that a giant lived at the Waterfall in the woods near Flower Hill about 2 1/2  miles from Ballyduff, he was called Séan Concubhar.    Over the waterfall there are enormous high rocks rising to about fifty feet high.      At the base of the rock there is a low entrance and a person must creep in by a short passage and inside is a large commode-
(continues on next page)

4428229/4387510/4458604.title: The Danes' Hut
4428229/4387510/4458604.text:
(continued from previous page)
Whitechurch owns it. There is a figure seen every night at about 12 o'clock in the top of this hut. When the figure goes in strange music is heard coming from the inside of it.



Giants and old WarriorsI have found out from some of the people of this district about a giant who lived about two hundred years ago. He lived in the townland of Whitechurch in a castle. He used to raid the people's houses to get food. He was killed by an old warrior with a stone. The stone struck the giant on the side of his head and killed him.



Local MonumentsThere is a monuments in the
(continues on next page)

4428234/4387430/4458953.title: A Boy Hero of the Red Branch
4428234/4387430/4458953.text: One time there was a giant who used to kill people by the means of a candle on top of a rock. If any body looked at the candle they would die the next morning. However a brave company of men heard of the giant. The leader picked out a young boy and told him to knock down the candle, also giving him a magic cap. The boy knocked down the candle and he fled to safety. The giant was killed after, but he did not die it was the boy who killed him. The boy was rewarded with a meadle of bravery for his good and famous deed.

4428276/4390898/4459211.title: Giants
4428276/4390898/4459211.text: long ago, there were people know  as “Giants”. They were very big strong men about seven or eight feet in height. It is about a hundred years since any of these men were in the country but yet, some traces of them remain in the district, such as Giants graves.The people say, that long ago, there lived a giant in a cave on the top of Largan Cairn which is about a hundred yards from my home. Near this cave there is a grave in which this Giant is supposed to be buried and a stone chair was which was supposed to be used by him. Many visitors go to the top of this Cairn in the summer.It is said that this giant threw a stone weighing about twelve hunder weights from the top of the Cairn to the acres in Corker which is about fifteen miles away. These giants used to go out fighting battles and they often fought among themselves.

metadata.Location:: Rossnowlagh Upper or Crockahany, Co. Donegal

4428276/4390949/4459254.title: Giants
4428276/4390949/4459254.text: there were many giants living in this district in olden times but very little is known about the,. Long ago there was a giant living in Ballintra district and everybody he saw he threw stones at them. One day there was a man going along the road and the giant saw him. He at once got a stone and threw it at him but by good luck the man escaped being hit. The stone went about twenty yards over the road and lot in a field which is one side of Ballintra Chapel. The stone is about six feet high and about ten feet long and the shape of the giant’s hand is in it. When the owner of the field saw the large stone he and some other men tried to lift it but they were not able. The stone still remains in the field.

metadata.Location:: Rossnowlagh Upper or Crockahany, Co. Donegal

4428073/4375251/4460883.title: Giants
4428073/4375251/4460883.text:
There was once a giant on Nephin and he was a very strong giant. One day a lot of men went to the top of Nephin and they saw him and he took a big rock up out of the ground and he said to the men "Come for a throw boys". Then he flung the rock and he stuck it in the ground in Anthony Carlons land along the Crossmolina road and it is standing there now. There were two more giants onanother part of Nephin and their name were John Naughton and Thomas Sullivan. One day they were arguing to see which of them was the strongest and one of them lifted a rock and threw it and it fell this side of Killeen. Then the other took another rock bigger than it
(continues on next page)

4460751/4377185/4461589.title: Fairy Forts
4460751/4377185/4461589.text:
(continued from previous page)
Told to me by Mr. P.O'FarrellBallyin, Lismore



Long ago a man visited a witch. There was a giant living with her. The witch gave him three things to do, or he would be killed. Namely, first, to try to beat the witch in a race of two hundred miles, secondly, to eat a big pot of food, thirdly, to drink a tub of water.While he was on the road, he saw a man in a
(continues on next page)

4460751/4377190/4461598.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4460751/4377190/4461598.text:
At one time there lived between Knock Maol Domhnaigh Barracks and Melleray, at the foot of Deirick, a man who was called Tomás Tóibín. He had great strength. He was like a giant. He could poise two half hundred weights in each hand and throw them into the air and catch them in his hands as they were coming down. He played with the weights like this, as if they were toys. At one time he pulled a cow out of a bog hole single handed. Several time she carried a bag of potatoes to market
(continues on next page)

4460751/4377193/4461600.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4460751/4377193/4461600.text:
This story is about Fionn Mac Cool who lived in Ballyin ages ago. One day Fionn's mother was sitting on a rock outside her home when a giant came along. The house that she lived in had a hall door and a back door. Both doors were facing each other.The giant asked her what was the rock she was sitting on. She said "When Fionn, my son, wants to wash himself in the morning, he puts his legs out the back door and his body along the hall and his head out the front door. The rock is in the shape of a basin and he washes himself there".The rock to this day is called Carraig Nighthe.
(continues on next page)

4428237/4387689/4462528.title: Scéal - Oileán na Meadhon agus Loch Neacach
4428237/4387689/4462528.text:
Sgéal - Oileán na Meadhon agus Loch NeacachFadó, fadó, bhí dá fhathach ag troid i nÉirinn. Rith fathach amhain go Sasana agus thóg an fathach eile píosa talamh in a lámh  agus caith sé in a dhiaid é.  An áit in a thóg sé an talamh as tá loch Neacach ann anois.  Thuit an talamh a bhí in a lámh in aice Shasana agus sé sin Oileán na Meadhon anois.



Sgéal - Cill Inghin LéineFadó bhí taoiseach in a comnuidhe cúpla míle ó Dhún laoghaire. Bhí inghean aige dar'b ainm Inghean Laighean. Bhí sí ana cinealta dos na bochtaibh. Do chuir sí teampuil mór ar bun agus tháinig mórán daoine go dtí an teampuil so. Nuair a fuair sí bás bhí gach aoinne ag caoineadh mar geall ar na gníomharthaibh maithe do dhein sí dos na daoine bochta. Ó'n lá san amach tugtar Cill Inghin Léine ar an
(continues on next page)

4428111/4379342/4462599.title: Giants - Béaloideas
4428111/4379342/4462599.text: Long ago there was a cruel giant who lived in a castle. in this castle there was a lot of gold. This giant was very cross. There was a little boy living near the giant and he made up his mind to get all the gold belonging to the giant. One day he came to the giant's castle and knocked there. When the giant heard this he ran to the door to see what was there. When the boy heard him coming to the door he ran behind the hedge of the castle. Outside this castle there was a big hole and when he would step outside the door he would fall into the deep hole. When the giant ran out he stepped into the deep hole and got killed. Then the boy ran in and got all the gold belonging to the giant and was rich for ever.

4428111/4379227/4462634.title: Béaloideas on Witches
4428111/4379227/4462634.text: Once upon a time a man lived out in the mountain. One day he made butter. When he opened the churn to see the butter he had nothing but froth. A woman was called at the first farmer's house. In these days she was called a north-country woman. She told the farmer's wife that her neighbour took the butter. This was done by with-craft. These women were called witches.

4428111/4379249/4462641.title: On Giants
4428111/4379249/4462641.text: There was a giant around here long ago. He lived out in the mountain at Walshe's  Cross. it is said that he fired a big stone from the cross to Mount Melleray. There was another giant up in the North of Ireland who lived on top of a hill. He used to kill all the cattle on the people. One day a small boy went to where he lived. The boy dug a big hole outside the door. Then he struck the door with a pick axe and ran behind. When the giant ran out he fell into the hole and got killed. The boy was called 'Jack the Giant Killer' from that day out.

4428111/4379304/4462665.title: Béaloideas on Giants
4428111/4379304/4462665.text: It is hundreds of years ago since there were giants in Ireland. One lived in Knockanore and another lived in Toor. They made a bet as to which of them would throw the heaviest weight. They threw the largest stone they could find. The Knockanore Giant threw a stone about three ton weight from the top of the Cairn Glas and it landed in Toor and it is to be seen there to this day. The Toor giant had no respect for him. The one he threw was the same weight and size but it went many miles farther as it landed in the Old Parish and is also to be seen to this day and it is called 'Cloc Éagáin'.

4428111/4379310/4462676.title: Béaloideas
4428111/4379310/4462676.text: There is a well in Ballyheena and it is called St. Mochua's Well. People go there on the 10th Februrary and say the round of their beads around the well. St. Mochua is the patron saint of this parish of Clashmore. There is a cement cover over the well to protect it from cattle, and a high wall around it, which was built by the Earl of Huntingdon. People say that this well was on the top of the village one time but it is said that one Sunday evening a woman came out and washed some clothes in it. In the morning when the people came out they found that it was shifted down to Ballyheena.

4428111/4379311/4462678.title: Béaloideas on Wells
4428111/4379311/4462678.text: There is a well in Ballyheeney called St. Mochua's Well. People give a round of their beads there on the 10th February. St. Mochua is the patron saint of Clashmore. Long ago people say that the well was up on top of the village and one evening a woman went out washing clothes in it and next morning it sprang down in Ballyheeney. They do not have any pattern around here now. It is only in Ardmore that they have it in honour of St. Declan because he is the patron St. of Ardmore.Long ago there used to be a pattern held in Piltown on the 24th August and it was held at the Blessed well.

4428111/4379312/4462681.title: Béaloideas on Old Houses
4428111/4379312/4462681.text: The houses that were there long ago were built with mud. They used to have big open fire-places. They used no coal but Bouráns that is dried cow-dung. All the houses had only one room and a kitchen. In the houses where there was a big family, they used to sleep in the kitchen. The used big four-posted bed with hoods. Nearly all the people had a half-door and a threshold underneath it.They cut rushes and plaited them and dipped them in some kind of oil. these were called rush-candles

4428111/4379313/4462684.title: Béaloideas on Landlords
4428111/4379313/4462684.text: The Landlords around here were Mr. Stuart and the Earl of Huntingdon lived in Clashmore. The remains of his mansion are still to seen:People say they were fairly good to their tenants but still they were a few avictions/ Clashmore and its surroundings

4428111/4379314/4462686.title: Béaloideas on St Mochua
4428111/4379314/4462686.text: Saint Mochua is the patron saint of Clashmore. There is a well within five minutes walk of the village called St. Mochua's Well. The pattern day falls on the tenth of February. It is only a few old people who come there now. There is a story told about the well.At one time the well was in the village, and one night a woman washed clothes in it, and to the surprise of many next morning the well was dry and it sprung up where it is now. There was a tree growing over the well and when the well dried up the tree withered away. Boys and girls going to America many years ago from the parish would not go if they had not a little piece of this tree to bring them safe to the end of their voyage.

4428111/4379315/4462689.title: Béaloideas on Witches
4428111/4379315/4462689.text: Witches are people who were supposed to have power from the devil. They practised witch-craft such as taking butter and eggs and potatoes from one another. There was a woman in Tipperary living with her father and mother and husband. Her name was Bridget Cleary. Her people got the idea she was a witch and could do supernatural things so in others to get her information from here they put on an iron gate over a fire and burned her. They were arrested and tried for berating her in this manner and they got 20 years in jail.

4428111/4379316/4462691.title: A Story
4428111/4379316/4462691.text:
Once upon a time I heard a story about a giant . This giant was a very wicked man and he used to kill all the people he would catch. He would take all the cattle and sheep he would see. There was a little boy who lived with his Auntie and Uncle. One day he said he would go and kill the giant, he got up early that morning and got ready to kill the giant.He was thinking for a while how he would kill him. After a while he thought of a plan. He got a spade and he dug a deep hole. He cut some green branches and put them over the hole. He then went to the giants castle door and gave a terrible knock and hearing the loud knock came to the door and said "Who dares to knock so loud at my door" and running out he fell into the hole and with
(continues on next page)

4428111/4379318/4462693.title: Béaloideas on Witchcraft
4428111/4379318/4462693.text: Once upon a time there was a witch living near a farmer's house. One day when they were making the churn they were nearly all the day twisting it and they could not make any butter.They blamed

4428111/4379319/4462697.title: Béaloideas on Shipwrecks
4428111/4379319/4462697.text: Long ago there used to be a ferryboat going across from Youghal to the Ferrypoint. One day the sea was very rough and the boat capsized. Three women lost their lives. Some of them wore cloaks and they spread them on the water and it kept them floating until the life boat came and rescued them. The people were saved. Now it is a motor boat they have and the people say it much safer. Coast Guards are a very brave body of men. They are always there in time of need.

4428111/4379328/4462716.title: On a Giant
4428111/4379328/4462716.text: Long ago there lived in this country a famous giant. He was so famous that he could tear anything to bits. There was also another giant in Scotland. When he heard of the famous giant in Ireland he said that he should go to Ireland to see if he was better then himself. He went across to Ireland and he came to the house where he asked for something to eat. The woman gave him cake and meat. After he had them eaten he asked for the great giant and the woman said that he was not inside. The giant was in a cradle in the middle of the kitchen and the woman said that it was only a baby. The giant of Scotland went over to the cradle and put his finger near the baby's mouth and the baby bit off his thumb. The giant

4462381/4415980/4463412.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4462381/4415980/4463412.text:
148Stories of giants and warriors.Once upon a time there lived a giant in Ireland and there lived a giant in Scotland. This Scotch giant heard that there was a giant in Ireland and he wanted to fight him. He swam over to Ireland and came to the giant's castle and he started to fight with him. When the battle was ended the Irish giant turned on the Scotch giant and ran after him. The Scotch giant jumped into the water and swam away. The Irish giant lifted a mighty handful of soil and threw it after the Scotch giant. It went over the giant's head and landed out in the middle of the sea and
(continues on next page)

4427962/4361253/4465935.title: Cumadóireacht - Ainmneacha Páirce
4427962/4361253/4465935.text:
(continued from previous page)
t- ainm atá air bóithrín cam.



Bhí cailleach amháin in mo cheanncar fadó.  Teach beag do bhí aici.  Níl fios agam ar a h-ainm act bhí Kitty the Hare mar leas airm uirrthi.  Bhí sí in a cómhnaidhe i leacaidhe.  Bhí sean feat darbh ainm Líam Airmeas agus bhí cú aige.  Maidin amháin bhí sé ag fiasach, Chonnaic sé girrfiadh ag tarraingt an bainne óna buaibh.  Do téasbain sé an girrfiadh dón madadh, as go bráth leo beirt, rith an girrfiadh agus léim sé isteach in san b'fhuinneóg a bhí sa tigh act agus é ag sul isteach bhain an cú an rioball de.  Tháine líam suas, do bhris sé an doras isteach agus chonnaic sé Kitty taobh istigh agus í in a suidhe ar phóta.  Nuair éirigh sé bhian pota lán le fuill.  Bhí fios ag liam eeárg a bhí don h'uair Seámus Ó h'Aodha an sgéal seo ó Tomás Mac Mágnuis

4427968/4362448/4466131.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4427968/4362448/4466131.text:
Not far from my home there is a rock which could not be placed there by the power of man.  Long, long ago people said that two giants lived, one on each side of Callow lake.  Those two giants were at war together.  The one on the Cullonaughton side was too strong for the one on the other side.He was so strong that he threw a very big stone after the other giant.  Where the stone fell we now have a rock called Carraig - awal.  On the Mellick side of the river Moy there lived an old hag in a cabin which no one ever visited.  An idea came into her head to build a place which no one could get into.This she meant to complete in one night provided, no one should look at her until it was finished.  The work was started, but
(continues on next page)

4427962/4361297/4466347.title: Fathaigh agus Cailleacha
4427962/4361297/4466347.text:
Bhí cúpla fathach in mo ceanntar uair. Do cómhnuigh fathach i Srón Cam sin Cnoch mór atá i mbaile Ceathramhas Neidin, Cilleasara. Is feídir srón cam a feiceál Ó Seoil Áit Tighe Mhic Aodha. Do bhí troid idir é feín agus fathach eile a bhí in a chómhnaidhe i Neífin. An fathach a bhi3 in a chómhnuidhe an bharr Sróna  Cam. Do chaith sé leach mór go dtí paírc atá in mo bhaile feín Áit-Tighe-Mhic-aodha. Do cheao sé go gcaithfeadh sé é chómh fada le Neífin, act do sgeor an leach as a láimh agus do thuit sé tuairms míle ís Srón Cam. Tá sé fiche míle ó Srón Cam go Neífin. Tá an leach tuairms deichtonna ar meadhchaint do bhí srón cam ar an bhfatach a bhí in a chómhnaidhe san áit sin agus sin é an fáth go bhfuil an t-ainm sin ar an gcnoc ó shoin. Do chuireadh an fathach i gcró na nuan agus tá clocha thart timpeall air agus crann ag fás in a lár.Fadó bhí beirt cailleach in a gcómhnaidhe i mbothán
(continues on next page)

4427969/4362006/4466428.title: An Cailleach Béarach
4427969/4362006/4466428.text:
An Cailleach BéarachAn cailleach béarach according to tradition was supposed to be a witch who is believed to have erected most of the round towers and castles in this country.Tradition tells us that she built each of those buildings with three pocketfulls of stones. As well as being a famous builder, she is believed to have been a great mower. At the time of her death, it is said, she was 121 years and one day.



Cailleach Béarach as a MowerThe Cailleach béarach started one day mowing with a score of men. The men led off & she took up the rear. After an hour's work, she Caught up to the man who was last and mowed off his legs from above the ankles.She Continued the work until she Caught up to the man who was Second last & she cut off his legs also. This procedure Continued until all the men but one had their legs cut off. At this stage, they went to their dinner.
(continues on next page)

4428021/4368761/4474396.title: Giants and Warriors
4428021/4368761/4474396.text:
Long ago there lived a giant in taobh-riabhach under a rock.  He pulled nine men in tug of war and he was only nine years old.  This giants threw a big rock which is still to be seen on the top of this hill.It is said that he is buried in the hill.  The rock is about ten ton in weight.  He used to visit the people around this district and do very hard work for them, but they had to give him something to eat.  One day he invited a man to a feast and he had a cow killed for it.  He said to this man he would kill him if he would not eat half the cow.  The giant went for a can of water for the two of them to drink.  While he was gone for the water the man got a bag in the giants house and tied it around his waste.  The giant ate all his meat and the man was putting his meat into the bag that was around his waste.  When all the meat was gone the man said to the giant. I will cut my belly
(continues on next page)

4428107/4378627/4474633.title: Tallow Co. Waterford
4428107/4378627/4474633.text: Long ago there was a giant who lived in Knockhamuck, Tallow. He was bigger than Cuchulain and he lived very poorly. He worked every day by drawing timber from the wood. He had a horse and he used leave the horse off in the hay meadow every night after work and sometimes when he could not find the horse he used load the car and draw it himself to Lismore. This day he had a friend drawing with him and the second horses leg got broken. The giant loaded the two [?] and tied both of them together. He told the other man to put the horses winkers on himself and to get up in the first car. So he got up to drive. He was pulling this way and that and after three and after three miles the giant was changed into a horse.

4428029/4370055/4474980.title: Éadaí
4428029/4370055/4474980.text:
(continued from previous page)
She joins the thread on to the spindle. Then she winds the wheel round with one hand while she then pulls the wool with the other hand and it then forms thread.

4428033/4370459/4475697.title: Fathaigh - Crooked Legs
4428033/4370459/4475697.text:
There were lots of giants in Ireland long ago. There was one in this district. His name was "Crooked Legs". He got his name from the fact that he had very crooked legs. Once a giant living in Neifin sent a message to "Crooked Legs" and he invited him to come to his castle, so he set off, and although he had very crooked legs, he was a good runner, and he reached Neifin in one day.The giant in Neifin received him kindly, and they spent one day feasting. Then the
(continues on next page)

4428260/4389321/4477483.title: A Giant
4428260/4389321/4477483.text:
There was once a giant who lived some where on the Darty mountains, and it is said that he threw a stone about a few hundred weight from the house of “Cloch Na nUan” into the big meadow near byThis stone is in the big meadow yet and it is calledthe stone of “Cloch Na nUan.” The house which is near to this stone is called “Cloch na nUan” and it got its name from the stone.



One evening a few men named Mc Cafferties were out fishing at Bunansruican and they saw a mermaid. A mermaid with a child appeared to them, and they thought there was going to be a great storm. They brought the boat ashore and they were hardly at the Pier when the sea was over the banks. She did not stay very long only about ten minutes and the child which she had with her was crying. The mermaid had a human body, arms, hands and head and a fishes tail.

4428352/4398402/4486040.title: Fathaigh agus Cailleacha
4428352/4398402/4486040.text:
I bhfad ó shoin bhí clú agus cáil ar ár gceanntar fhéin fá dtaoibh de na fathaigh móra a bhí ann. Bhí fear amháin ann darbh ainm "Leithghin". Duine crodha, cálma a bhí ann. Deirtear gur thóg sé an chloch a b'mhó ar Chnoc Leach-Chonnaill agus gur chaith sé uaidh í anonn gó dtí an taobh eile de uisge an Ghaoith Bhearra agus ó'n lá sin go dtí an lá indiu, beirtear "Cruach Léithghin" ar an chnoc sin.Innistear sgeal deas fa chailleach a bhí ina comhnuidhe san cheanntar seo, tá cúpla céad bliadhain ó shoin. Bhí oiread písreógaí aicí gur tugadh an Chailleach Phísreógach uirthí. Bhí draoidheacht aicí. Seo cuid de na rudaí a bhí sí ábalta a dheanamh. "Ní rabh aicí le déanamh ach feadóg a chur ina béal agus í a shéideadh agus roimh dhá second bhí éanlaith an domhain cruinnighthe aicí, eadar beag, agus mór, óg agus aosta. Ní rabh aicí le déanamh ach slát sailóige a chaitheamh ar an talamh roimpí agus cia bith a léannfadh an t-slat, bheirfeadh sí go geaftaí Aifréann
(continues on next page)

4498840/4385992/4512516.title: Giants
4498840/4385992/4512516.text:
There was a man one time named Jack the Giant Killer. He was sucking his mother for twenty-one years. His legs grew out on the road and stopped the motor cars from going by, and when he stood up he lifted the roof off the house. He had only his mother with him. He said "The first thing he'd do was to repair the house and he went up to and old gentleman named Jeffrey Oatencake for some timber and of course all the neighbours were over-joyed to see Jack out and he gave Jack all the timber he required. When he had the house finished he went to a blacksmith and he made him a steel staff. He put two ton of steel in it so he started off to seek his fortune with his staff and the first place he came to was a wicked giant's place.The giant heard him coming and says he "Fee, Fow, Fom, I smell the blood of an Irishman. I'll have his bones for stepping stones, his guts for garters, and
(continues on next page)

4428403/4404865/4514850.title: Stories of Giants
4428403/4404865/4514850.text: Two huge rocks are situated in Whitehill and Kilmore respectively. They are the subjects of a folklore story. Two giants were engaged in battle with each other. Finally they grew afraid one of the other and fled in opposite directions but each giant turning in his flight cast a stone at the other and the heavy rocks that lie in these places are the stones used in the conflict.A giant called Dorby with his wife Grainne lived long ago in Lossett. Dorby was fighting an enemy giant and got killed in the struggle - the enemy slew the wife of Dorby and buried them both. Two big rocks in Lossett are regarded as the dolmens over the graves of Dorby and Grainne.

4493659/4408829/4519840.title: Stories of Giants
4493659/4408829/4519840.text: There are three stones out in the country and it is said that a Giant threw them from knockabrim

4493679/4410116/4521719.title: Local Giants
4493679/4410116/4521719.text:
There are giants in this place long ago. There was a giant in Inch Island one time. He was very big and everyone was afraid of him. There was another giant living in this place. The one did not like the other. One day the Inch giant threw a big rock over to this side and it is still to be seen in a (fier) field of ours called "Creag Mór."There was another giant in this place who had a bed up on Patrick Doherty's hill, up above Inniskill. He was a terrible big man and the people were all afraid of him. He lived away up in the hill
(continues on next page)

4493679/4410118/4521721.title: Local Giants
4493679/4410118/4521721.text:
In Olden Times giants roamed about the country. Giants were great big men that went from place to place, some looking for fight and others were civil and some of them had two or three heads.Giants went about here because in fields and places we have giants beds and people come from Dublin and places to view these beds. There are stones standing in the places where there are beds and it is said that it was the giants that put up these stones. There are stones standing in Patrick Doherty's field and there is a giant buried under the stones. There are three stones standing and
(continues on next page)

4493708/4413349/4526289.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4493708/4413349/4526289.text:
It is said that there was a giant who lived in Donegal. This giant lifted a giant stone in one of his hands that ten men could not move. He threw the stone into Foy’s bog, which was more than ten miles from where he was standing. The stone is there still and it is nearly covered with grass.	Once upon a time there was a little travelling tailor who took on a bet of one hundred pounds that he could kill two giants. He was only four feet six inches in height and he was very weak.	One day two giants were walking through a wood, the little man went up a tree and took a lot of stones with him.
(continues on next page)

4493695/4411786/4526470.title: Giants
4493695/4411786/4526470.text: There was once upon a time a giant woman who carried a big rock, about ten tons weight, in her apron. Wher she first stepped her foot made a hole in the ground. It is an island on the river Finn near Cloghan.The same giant stepped from from Altnapaste hill to the Gory. There is a giant buried in one of our fields along the river Finn.

4493750/4416469/4530936.title: Giants
4493750/4416469/4530936.text:
There is supposed to be a black place up on Glengollan where two giants were fighting. They wounded one another, and their blood turned the ground black. There is an underground tunnel going from the Scalp hill to Burt hill. The people say that the Giants made it, and still live in it.The giants are supposed to have built Inch Castle. The giants are  sup
(continues on next page)

4493755/4416920/4531113.title: An Old Story
4493755/4416920/4531113.text:
(continued from previous page)
between Umricam and the Croosroads at Shandram. It is still supposed that that noise is to be heard when you go by there at the late hours of the night.



There is a giants grave in Ballynary hill. There was a flag door on it and it was ten ton weight. This giant was supposed to lift a huge rock and throw it from the hill to Lisfannan Hill where it still remains. There is another giants grave in Ludden and it is marked with a flag sixteen feet in length and nine feet wide. These giants did not fight except to keep themselves
(continues on next page)

4493755/4416923/4531116.title: An Old Story
4493755/4416923/4531116.text:
(continued from previous page)
man did this and no sooner was he finished when the woman came for the milk tub. He reached for his gun and followed her, she never bothered him again from that time.



Once upon a time there were two giants one was smaller than the other. They arranged to fight each other and the winner was to get a purse of gold. The big giant was coming to arrange for the fight and the small giants wife got a large cradle made and put the small giant into it. When the big giant came she told him that this was her
(continues on next page)

4493758/4417358/4535283.title: Fairy Forts
4493758/4417358/4535283.text:
(continued from previous page)
cow and at night when he went out for her she was not in the field. He never seen her again but another man got her and she stayed with him for a year and then she left him and he never saw her again.There was fairy cats and fairy dogs seen round the fairy fort in Drumanoir. The dogs were not the same as other dogs but the cats were nearly the same but they were all white but the dogs were all grey but there was a ring of white round there necks. The fairys was seen out with them one day. There was lights seen at this fort every night for seven nights but there was no light seen after that night but the cats were seen out after that.The owner of the fairy fort in Drumanoir worked the land where the . fairy fort was once. He was ploughing the field one time when the fairys came out and one of them asked him what he was doing with their den but the man did not bother and he set potatoes in the field. When he went out the next day the drills was all trampled flat and the potatoes never grew and the man never worked the land again.



There was a giant lived in our district long ago. This giant threw a rock from Gortyarrigan Buncrana to Dan Ree hill. This giant fought with another wee man and the man beat the giant. This man that beat the giant lived in Leafin. it is in the townland of
(continues on next page)

4493783/4420447/4536087.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4493783/4420447/4536087.text: Stories of Giants and WarriorsThere once lived two great giants in County Derry. One day they tried feats together One of these was to throw a huge stone from a place known as the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim to Donegal. One of these threw many stones which are still to be seen in Donegal. These are still to be seen in Shrove + Ballybrack. The stone which the other giant threw never landed but it is believed that they landed on the tonns Another giant was known as Mananann MacLiz when he died he was supposed to have been buried in the tonns. When the tonns arise it is believed that McLin is angry. The giants did not fight against each other These never lived hags in this district. Giants do not hurl rocks from place to place.

4493792/4420908/4536938.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4493792/4420908/4536938.text:
Stories of Giants and WarriorsOnce upon a time a Giant lived over at Magilligan Point. One morning he waken very early he thought he heard the war cry. Without waiting for his breakfast he ran out of his cave and lifted a large stone weighing two and a half tons.He threw it across Lough Foyle thinking it would have killed some people in its falling it fell three miles from where the giant threw it. The giant said if he had got his breakfast he would have thrown it further. It fell at a place called Ballybrack. It gets the name of the "Standing" Stone" today
(continues on next page)

4493811/4422825/4538627.title: Giants and Warriors
4493811/4422825/4538627.text:
There is a big stone lying in a field about one hundred yards from our school.It is also near Aughaclay chapel.There are five finger marks on this stone.  A story is told about it.  Here it is:-Once upon a time a giant was standing on top of Sliab Sneact.This big stone was lying in his way.  He "stooped" down and lifted it up and threw it with force that it lit in a field in Aughaclay.There is another story told about a stone that is at the Strand Steads.Here it is:-Once upon a time two giants were fighting.  One of them was from the Isle of Doagh and the other was from Malin.The giant from the Isle of Doagh threw a big stone at the other giant.  The stone fell at the edge of
(continues on next page)

4540646/4421909/4540684.title: Story
4540646/4421909/4540684.text:
(continued from previous page)
know how the police found out At last they found out that it was the man that was coming to the every night that saw telling the guards on them. One night (they) he came and the men gave him plenty of whiskey, and after that they dug a whole and they threw the man into it, and buried him alive.



GiantsThere was, a Giant one time and he lived in Rashenny. he used to come round at nighs, and kill the peoples cattle but he was not to be seen in the day-time. He had his hiding place in Arna Mure Mora. There used to be a big holly bush, and he used to ride on it, and he left the mark of his spear on it which he had for fighting. One night the people sat up to watch him. He came, and he
(continues on next page)

4540646/4421935/4540716.title: Giants
4540646/4421935/4540716.text:
GiantsThere was a giant living in Biron hill long ago, He was supposed to throw a stone before his breafast, and he threw it from the hill to the main land. A part of this stone is in for a gevil of a house. There was a man out hunting one day and he rose a Large hair. He fired two shots at her but he did kill her. He then put a sixpence in the gun, and he was about to fire when the hare turned into an old witch, and the man got afraid. There was a woman one time, and she was on her way from Ardaugh to Poland, and she was lifted down by a witch.There was a Giant in Coolcross, and it is said that he threw a stone from Mara-Mor to Coolcross hill, and this stone is to be seen yet. It is said that the
(continues on next page)

4566058/4563262/4570758.title: A Story
4566058/4563262/4570758.text: There was an old woman who lived on the top of Cnoc Mágha. During her life there was a tower built in Turloughmore. She did not like that so she resolved to knock it.She started to gather stones. It is said that it is she who gathered the large heap of stones on the top of the hill. When she had them gathered she started to fire them. The first one took the roof off it and the second one knocked it to ruins. The men of Turloughmore began to build but one day as they were building a shower of fire fell from the sky and it burned them all.

4562124/4561498/4571885.title: Cloch Bhreac
4562124/4561498/4571885.text: Cloch Bhreac is a great big stone situated on the side of the road that is leading to Clooninagh. It is a big speckled stone and that is the reason it is called Cloch Bhreac. It is about as high as a man and as stout as a cock of hay. There are many stories told about this stone.It is said that two giants lived near this place, one in Knockroe, south of this school and the other in Knockma north of this school. Each giant stood on top of his own hill. It is said that they were fighting and that the giant that was standing on Knockroe threw a stone at the giant on Knockma. The stone did not go any further than Doonbeg and that is the stone that is there to-day.There is another story told about that stone. The two giants were said to be throwing stones at each other and the two stones met and stuck and fell in Doonbeg.

4566083/4565606/4573250.title: (no title)
4566083/4565606/4573250.text:
Bhí fathach ann uair amháin agus bhíodh sé ag goid uan agus caorach agus beithidheach agus chu[?] rud mar sin. Oidhche amháin bhí an fathach i n-a chodladh agus tháinic duine ag an doras agus sé poll ins an talamh agus do chuir sé an féar glas ae uachtar an phuill ionnus nach n-aithneóchadh an fathach go raibhan poll ann. Nuair a bhí sin déanta aige do bhuail sé ar an doras agus chuaidh sé i bhfolach taobh thiar de chrann mór a bhí i n-aice leis an teach. D'éirigh an ffathach, chuaidh sé amach agus nuair a chonnaic an duine a bhí taobh thiar de'n chrann é rith sé agus thug sé buille do'n fathach agus do mharbhuigh sé é agus bhí chuile duine san gcomhasrasnacht buidheach de'n fhear.



Bhí figheadóir ann fadó agus bhí mac aige agus ní choinneóchadh an páiste síos uaidh nuair a bhíodh sé ag obair agus uair dá raibh sé ag caitheamh na spóllaí amach uaidh buaileadh ceann de na spóllaí sa tsúil ar an páiste agus thosuigh an páiste ag gáiridhe. Tháinig olc mór ar an máthair mar gue cheap sí gur ag gol a bhí sé. Dubhairt an fear go
(continues on next page)

4566085/4565908/4574736.title: (no title)
4566085/4565908/4574736.text:
Long ago there was a witch in Ireland and she had a big holding of land. She had all the people in the place where she lived frightened to death. When she had any work to do anybody she asked had to do it and if they were not any better than herself she would turn them into anything she would like. There was one family of three brothers who were great workers. They lived a good way from her. They made up their to have it out with her because they were very anxious for land. The bargain was that whoever would be the best worker would get the land. The oldest brother came for the week. It was the time of mowing the hay. So he started off first and it was agreed that if he could not keep in front of the witch she would cut the legs from under him  In the olden it would be the last mower who would call for the sharpening. So she had him and what was more she had wire pins stuck in the meadow so that he could not keep in front of her. She overtook him and cut the legs of the oldest brother. That night he did not come home. Next morning the second brother and his father went to the witches house. There they found him and his legs hanging off.
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: Micheál Ó agus Máire Bean Uí Shuilleabháin

4569068/4568690/4583506.title: Fathach
4569068/4568690/4583506.text:
Bhí fear ina comhnuidhe i nDealgain fadó agus bhí mac an-láidir aca agus aon lá amháin d'imigh sé agus ní raibh fios ag a athair ná an máthair cá raibh sé imithe agus níor sgriobh sé chuca.Tar éis tamaill an-fhada do tháininc sé abhaile agus bhí sé chomh mór agus bhí chomh láidir le fathach. Do bhíséag iarradh ar daoine é a throid cach ní throidfeadh aon duine é. Níor airhnigh an athair é agus do thug sé dubhslán dá mac.Ag droichead Dealgan do throid siad agus d'airhnigh an mac an athair agus nuair a tháinic siad le chéile ag triod ní raibh an mac ag troid ar a dhícheall i n-aghaidh an athar ach ag tabhairt aire dhó féin connus nach raibh an tathair i n-an buille air. Ach cebí cén bealach a b'fuair an tathair seans air do mharbhuigh sé é. Nuair a bhí an mac marbh d'inni márhair an fháthaigh d'on arhair gurb é a mac féin a marbuigh sé. "Anois" ars' an tathair "Ó thárla go b'fhuil gaisg amháin déanta agam tá sé cmhinrinn an ghaisg eile a dhéanamh- tú féin a mharbhugadh nuair nár innis tú dom gurb é sin mo mhac. Chomh fad is tá crann ag fás i nDealgain fágaim mo mhallacht ann" ars athair an fhathaigh "Nuair nár innis tú na daoine no d'aoine dom gurbh é sin mo mhac". Tá cloch ar an Droichead ag taisbáine gut marbuighead duine ansin.
(continues on next page)

4583277/4576026/4584017.title: Story
4583277/4576026/4584017.text: Long ago there was a chief and he had many workmen and each of them had a job to do for themselves. There was one workman who had to drive the cows out in the fields in the morning and bring them home in the evening and milk them. One day the chief told him not to put the cows in one special field and he told him where it was. He was driving the cows out this morning and he said to himself that there was no grass in the other fields and it would not be right to have the cows starving and he put them into the field which he was told not to and he put them in. When he was coming home a giant came out before him and asked him why didn't he obey his master. The boy told him the story that there was no grass in the other fields. The giant was going to kill him and he asked him to wrestle him and if he won he would not kill him. They started wrestling and the giant won. The boy asked him to spare his life and he would give him a magic rod. The boy went for the rod and when he came back with it he struck the giant with it and he killed him.

4583295/4577262/4584818.title: The Rolling Giants
4583295/4577262/4584818.text:
Long long ago, there lived in Ireland, three huge giants. Their castle was builton a hill so steep that no ordinary man could climb it. It was a custom of these giantsto let big rocks roll down the hillsideto the fields below, where they killed cattle and men. Then the giants randown the hill, and gathered the dead. Soon they feasted on man and beast. This was going on a long time, when at last, the people came to-gether in council to try and put, an end to the rolling giants for ever. The elders spokefirst; then the younger. Then suddenlythree youths came in and said "We will put an end to the giants for a hundred pounds!" "A hundred," gasped the people, "we will give ye a thousant if ye rid us of them." "Very well," replied the youths," we start to-morrow morning."Early next morning the youths started out (Early) a long journey to a wise woman who lived very far away. After three days they arrived at the wise woman's abode
(continues on next page)

4583271/4575415/4586449.title: Fathach
4583271/4575415/4586449.text: Once upon a time a giant lived in Castehacket. He was fighting with another giant one day. He threw a big hefty rock at his enemy and it landed in a field in Lissananny. There were words written on the stone but they could not be read now.Someone broke the stone and brought some of it away. There is some of it yet in a style between two fields. There is more of the rock as a corner stone in a stable in Lissananny.Another giant threw a stone from Belmont and it landed in a field in Blindwell.Another giant threw a rock from the top of Castlehacket hill and it landed in Ironpool. The print of his five fingers are on the rock.

4583338/4580889/4588175.title: A Giant
4583338/4580889/4588175.text: There were two giants in Churchill about 400 years ago. One of these giants was very athletic and the other was not athletic. One day these giants has a quarrel and the athletic giant was getting beaten, and he jumped from Churchill and landed in Mr. J Derivan's field in Coolnageeragh. The other giant took up a stone and flung it after the athletic giant, and before the stone fell the [stone] athletic giant jumped again and landed in Killcorban. the stone fell and broke in two in Mr. J. Bruder's field in Coolnageeragh. The stone is about six ton weight and is still in existence.

4583338/4580891/4588179.title: Giants
4583338/4580891/4588179.text:
There was a Giant called at the at time Lick Mollasey. He also had a brother living on the Benn Hill. This Giant's height was 11' 11'' as his brother was also as tall. This Giant's brother came down from the Benn Hill to try which of them was the better man.They picked out two of biggest stones. The bigger giant threw his stone first and then the smaller giant threw his then and the two stones fell in the one field in now John Brobericks and it is in the village of boolnageragh. Then the giant from the Benn Hill went home. The other giant went to his house also. When he went in to his house there was a man there before him. When the giant saw him he said "Fe fá fúm,
(continues on next page)

4583305/4578190/4591937.title: Giants and Warriors
4583305/4578190/4591937.text:
Long ago there were many giants and warriors in Ireland during the reign of the Fianna. One day the Fianna were out in the hills hunting. Suddenly they saw a large giant approaching with a large horse. The Fianna were greatly terrified of the giant when t hey saw him approaching. The giant asked Finn Mac Cumhaill to take him into the army and Finn consented. The giant was called "The Giolla Deachair". His horse was grazing in the same fiend as the horses of the Fianna. The Fianna drove the horse from the field. The giant got very
(continues on next page)
4583305/4578190/4591937.school_info: School: Clochar na Trocaire, Cinn Mhara

4591099/4590755/4593051.title: Fathach Mór - Smig Smutarnach
4591099/4590755/4593051.text:
I bhfad i bhfad o shoin bhí fathach mór millteach ina chomhnuidhe i Gcluain Fiachtna míle go leith  ó'n sgoil seo agus níl cur síos na innsint sgéil  ar an méid dochair a rinne sé don gcómharsanacht fhaid agus a bhí sé beo. Smig Smutarnach an t-ainm a bhí air agus sé an nós do bhí aige na go gcaithfead sé duine d'fághail as gach teach le n-ithe núair a bhéad ocras air agus muna a bhfuigheadh sé an duine gan a iarraid chuireadh sé mí-ádh agus dochar arn na daoine . Bhí fear beag bídeach ina chómhnuighe san áit darbh ainm Seáinín Ó h-eidhin agus bhí sé an-mhór leis na daoine maithe. Bhí sgían draoidheachta ag Séainín agus deineadh as cúamh muice í. Fuair sé ó ná sídheoga é agus la amháín dubhairt
(continues on next page)

4591080/4588628/4593300.title: Fathaigh agus Cailleacha
4591080/4588628/4593300.text: Fathaigh agus Cailleacha.Níl mórán sgéalta faoi fhathaigh thart annseo.  Tá sgéal faoi fathach a bhí i n-a chomhnuidhe ar Cnoc Beanna  Beola agus Beóla an t-ainm a bhí air. Bhí fathach eile i n-a chómhnuidhe ar Cnoc Mordán agus Mordán a bhí air.  Thosuigheadar ag troid lá ag féachaint cé aca ba láidre.  Cháith Beóla cloch le Mordán agus chaith Mordán cloch le Beóla agus marbhuigh sé é.  Tá cloich Bheóla le feiceál fós i n-áit ar a dtugtar Criathrach Cuireall.Tá sgéal faoi cailleach agus caillea  Bhéarra an t-ainm a bhí uirthi.  Deirtear gurabh í an bhean ba shine ariamh í.  Maidin amháin dubhairt sí le n-a h-ingean; "Eirigh suas a inghean, is gabh go dtí dinghean, agus innis di go bhfuil inghean óg ag inghean a h-inghinne ó aréir.  Sin í aois na caillighe Béarra.

4591100/4590947/4593491.title: Giants
4591100/4590947/4593491.text: 1. At one time there lived in the Wicklow hills a giant whose name was Móran Dubh.  At one time he was about to kill a young man who vexed him.  But the young man craved mercy and promised the giant that he would give him a present every year for ten years if he spared him.  This young man lived in Donamon and it was customary with the giant to come on a visit to him.  One day the giant planned to spend the day with the young man but no sooner than he had sat on the brink than he slipped in and was drowned.  It is said that he meant to drown the man.

4591089/4589574/4606294.title: Folklore - Giants
4591089/4589574/4606294.text:
Long ago there lived in the hill in Carranama two giants. One day they had a fight and one of them fired a big rock at the other. The rock was so big that when the people were making the road through Carranama they were not able to stir the stone and they had to blast it. There is still a big stone left the remains of the rock. The stone is still known by
(continues on next page)

4591089/4589586/4606610.title: Folklore - Witches
4591089/4589586/4606610.text:
There once lived in the town of Cloonfad a woman whom people thought was a witch.  The priest came riding on his horse one day to the witch's abode to try and change her by a sermon into a good Catholic woman and if not to give her a flogging for practicing witchcraft.  When he asked her to stop her witchery she refused.  The priest who's anger was arising, wound her hair round his hand and at once proceeded to give her a merciless flogging with his riding whip.  At the end of the flogging, she still refused to give up her witchcraft and the priest beat her again.  He then went out to where he left his horse stretched dead on the road, with a group of country people standing round him.  The priest at once knew that the witch had exercised her
(continues on next page)

4591089/4589587/4606614.title: Folklore - Witches
4591089/4589587/4606614.text:
(continued from previous page)
magic power to kill the horse.  He retraced his steps to the witch's dwelling and he asked her to restore his horse to life again and if she did so he would never interfere with her again.  The witch went out to where the horse was lying and breathed something in his ears.  At once the horse
(continues on next page)



No body gets married in the month of May because it is very unlucky nor on Shrove Tuesday.  Some people invite a lot of people they have a lot of cars.  The boys get an old shoe and tye it to the back of the car in which the married couple are in.  The boys get a lot of straw and dress them selfs up and come to the house where the marriage is. It is very lucky to borrow cloaths.

4591089/4589588/4606616.title: Folklore - Witches
4591089/4589588/4606616.text:
(continued from previous page)
shook his head three times and then jumped up on his feet as lively as ever.  The priest said nothing but mounted his horse and rode away.  He never interfered with the witch after that.



June is said to be the luckiest month of the year to get married.  Side cars and horses that was used for driving home.  The people lit sheafs of straw on the roads.  Old shoes were thrown after the couple for luck.  The bride was to wear something borrowed.   The people round the place dressed themselves up and went to the houses looking for money.  Straw boys came also singing and dancing.

4616628/4594781/4615580.text:
(continued from previous page)
anyone is parelised and to pray to the Blessed Virgin they will be cured.The cure for measels; take hot drinks or anything such as warm. The porous plaster is good for pains. The poor-mans plaster is also good for pains. The muster plaster is good for any animal it is good for coughs and savare pains. When people are born about the end of March or at the end of April can be cured but by certain things



One can see if passing along by Streamstown two rocks, standing, about five feet high and two tons in weight. Tradition tells us that they were used in fight by two giants who lived there once. There are about a quarter of a mile apart and it is said that the giants were that distance apart when they fired the rocks.One of the giants was sowing oats in his field one day and the other seeing him at a distance said "That it may never come up' and the giant that was sowing the oats shouted "That you may never come up now". At that they aimed the rock at each other.
(continues on next page)

4602674/4594406/4615773.title: Fathach an Dá Cheann
4602674/4594406/4615773.text:
Bhí rí in Éirinn fadó agus ní raibh aige ach aon mac amháin. Ní raibh an fear seo ar an bhfarraige ariamh go raibh sé bliadhain is fiche d'aois. Dubhairt a athair leis gan dul ag an bhfairrge an lá seo. D'imthigh sé le dul amach ag an bhfairrge agus níor ghéill sé dá athair. Nuair a tháinig sé chomh fada leis an gcladach ní raibh sé i bhfad ann go dtáinic bean óg agus currach aice. Bhí an currach ag dul chomh sgiopaí is go gceapadh go raibh iomhradh na gcéadtha uirri agus gan innte ach aon bhean amháin. Tharraing sí suas an currach. Labhair sí le mac an Ríogh agus dubhairt an n-imreóchadh cluife cártaí a mhic an Rí. Ní faision liom mo chártaí a thabhairt as baile liom a bhean óg. Níl mise fhéin mar sin a mhic ó. Tharraing sí paca cartaí amach as a cluas agus thosnuigh orra ag imirt. An chéad cluife, chuaidh mac an rí é. Tabhair do gheasa a mhic an Rí arsa an bhean óg. Cuirimse faoí gheasaí thú agus faoi mhór-imirce na bliadhna nuair a thiocfhas mise abaile go mbeidh dúthaigh m'athair dubh le beithighidh. Féach anois agus feicfidh t iad arsa an bhean óg. D'fhéach an fear agus bhí. And dara cluife, chuaidh mac an Rí é. Tabhair do gheasa a mhic an Rí arsa an bhean óg arís. Cuirimse faoí geasa tú go raibh seomra i dteach m-athair lán le ór. Tá sin déanta arsa an bhean óg. An treas cluife chuaidh chuaidh an bhean óg é. Tabhair do geasa a mhnaoí óig arsa mac an Rí.
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: An tSr. M. Treasa Ní Bhriain

4602685/4595151/4616650.title: Ruins of Gráinne Ní Mháille's Castle
4602685/4595151/4616650.text: There are ruins of an old castle down at the sea in the village of Bunowen. A river runs beside it. Tradition has it that a number of giants lived there. It was said one of the giants was as big as a stack of hay. There was a hole under the floor of the castle into which prisoners was put.Another giant lived over in the mountains. One day he was "throwing" a leap and he went one hundred feet of a standing jump. As he rose in the sky he caught sight of the towers of the old castle, so he called his warriors to him, and they marched to Bunown. They attacked the castle, killed the inhabitants and put their bodies in the hole. Then they took possession of the castle.

4613683/4608319/4623480.title: Fathaigh agus Cailleacha
4613683/4608319/4623480.text:
Bhí driam daoine i liosceannanátha fadó agus nuair a cailleadh duine acu bheadh an bean-sidhe ag caoineadh na daoine a bhí ag an tórramh thíghiadh siad amach ag éisteacht léithe ag caoineadh agus ba bhéagh an caointóir i. Is géarr go ndeachaigh sí go áit éile agus thosuigh sí ag nigheacháin. tá an bean-sídhe suas arsa Paidín le na atháir ag bualadh slis. Ba mhaith liom dul suas chun i a fheicéal arsa Paidín. chuaidh sé suas cuir sé a cheann ós cionn
(continues on next page)

4613690/4609121/4624094.title: An Reilig
4613690/4609121/4624094.text:
(continued from previous page)
sídheóga isteach agus an chuinneóg nó rud éicint eile a sciobadh leob.  Tá scéal ag na daoine i dtaobh daoine eile nár chuir crann Bealtaine suas sa teach.Uair amáin níor chuir daoine crann Bealtaine suas sa teach. Tháinig na sídheóga san oidhche agus scuab siad leob an chuinneog acht thug siad arais arís í.  Cuirtear crann Bealtaine suas i ngach teach ó shoin mar gheall ar sin.



Fathaigh agus Cailleacha.Ins an mbaile s’againne fadó bhí cailleach in-a cómhnuidhe i dteaichín i n-aice locháin nó puill ar bhruach locha Coirib agus bhí seilbh uirthí ar an mbarúntacht timcheall, agus bhí draoidheacht éigean ag baint léithí.  Ní rachadh éinne  ag obair di mar chuirfeadh sí fá dhraoidheacht iad.Chaoi ar bith phós sí fear a bhí beagnach chomh gránda léithí féin ach bhí searbhóntaí aige sin agus cineáil fathaigh a bhí ann.  Do bheir sé ar each uisce uair agus seo é an chaoi gur bheir sé air.  Chuir sé láir dá chuid féin i n-aice na locha san oidhche agus nuair a chonnaic sé an láir i meadhon oidhche tháinig sé ar an talamh tirim ‘na h-aice.  Annsin bheir an
(continues on next page)

4591083/4588820/4625190.title: Scéalta Greannmhara
4591083/4588820/4625190.text:
(continued from previous page)
Tá fhios agamsa gur tú, asa an minisdeara leis agus marbuigheadh e Seán ar scatas a fhág sé de beo ann. chuaigh Seán abhaile chuig a mháthair agus níor thémuigh sé an gadaidhe dubh o shoin.Lá amhaín bhí fear ag siubhal cnuic. Bhí gnota [?] aige i áit eicint. Bhí sé ag subhaill agus ag sior imtheacht nó go dtanaic sé go dtí cnocan árd sléibhe. Do shuidhe sé síos ag leigint a sgíthe. Is gearr go bfhaca sé fear dubh ag triall air. Do bhuail fiathchíos é ar dtus act nuair a bhí sé roinnt gar dó labhair sé leis. Bhiodar ag cainnt i b'fad nuair a bhí a sgíth toigthe aca d'imigh leobh ag siubhal an cnoc arist. Bhíodar ag cainnt is gearr gur dtánaic an oidhche. Bhí siad i gcruadh chás annsin. Is gearr go b'fáca siad solus i bhfad uathaibh. Triall siad air. Nuair a shroich síad é ní raibh glas ar bíth ar an doras. Chuadar isteach. Bí póra feóla ar an tine.



Lá amhaín bhí fear ag siubhal cnuic. Bhí gnota aithride aige i áit eicint. Bhí sé ag subaill agus ag sior imtheact nó go dtanaic sé go dtí cnocan árd sléibhe. Do shuidhe sé síos ag leigint a sgíthe. Is gearr go b'fhaca sé fear dubh ag triall air. Do buail fiathchíos é ar dtus act nuair a bhí sé roinnt gar dó labhair sé leis. Bhiodar ag cainnt i b'fad nuair a bhí a sgíth toighthe aca d'imigh leobh ag siubhal an cnoc arist. Bhíodar ag cainnt is gearr gur dtánaic an oidhche. Bhí siad i gcruadh chás annsin. Is gearr go b'fáca siad solus i bhfad uathaibh. Triall siad air. Nuair a shroich síad é ní raibh glas ar bíth ar an doras. Chuadar isteach. Bí póta feóla ar an teine.

4613674/4607355/4625993.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4613674/4607355/4625993.text:
In this district there are several stories connected with giants and warriors of long ago. Amongst these is story of a huge giant who lived in the Glynck castle. One day while he was eating his dinner a great army came towards the castle but on seeing the giant the ran for there lives. When the giant had eaten he rushed out seised a huge rock and threw it with all his strength after them but it went too far and it fell in Jack Swift's field Curries. The rock weighs about three hundred and was threw about two Irish miles. The rock is split in two halfs and the track of the giants finger are still to be seen in the rock. The field in which it fell is call Carrigeen meaning a rock.
(continues on next page)

4602689/4595352/4626055.title: Giants
4602689/4595352/4626055.text: Once upon a time there lived a giant in Rockfield.  He used to go on a visit to another giant in Letter.  One day the two giants had a fight, and one of the giants said "get two stones and whoever would fire the stones the farthest would have all the land around the place."So the two giants got the stones the same weight and they stood in the same place and each of them fired the stones. One of the stones landed in Giarraunbawn and the other landed in Rockfield.The stone that landed in Rockfield was the Letter giant that threw it, and he got all the land.  On that same evening he went to clifden on a penny half penny bike and on his way home just on top of Cuo na Rar  he fell off his bike and got killed.  About six years ago a man was cutting turf and he found the giant's bons near the road.Francis KingTold by my father who lives in Rockfield Mayard

4602689/4595354/4626077.title: Giants
4602689/4595354/4626077.text: Three giants lived in Rockfield hundreds of years ago.  One giant got killed d at the top of bnock na rar as he was cycling on a penny half penny bicycle towards Letterfrack. He tried to stop the bicycle but he could not stop it.When a man was cutting turf at cnock na rar he got the bones of that giant in his bog and he left them there, the bog is 400 yards from the road.  Another giant threw a big stone from Fetter hill to Diamond hill.There is a field owned by Peter Coyne where there is a stone and the shape of a giants foot is on that stone.  It is in the field where the blessed well is and it is three hundred yds. beyond it.There is another (giant) stone in Gannons land that a giant threw from Letter hillI got this from my mother who lives in MoyardSarah King

4602689/4595356/4626079.title: Giantess
4602689/4595356/4626079.text: Once upon a time a man called Feicu, killed a giant.  One night Feica and Finn Mac Cool heard a great noise ocming near the house finn looked out the door, and the gianless was out side.  And she said finn man Cool O(tery usresc me) and he let her in, Fercu had a big souw hanging to the f roof and she asked him for a piece of the souw and he gave her some, and she made another grab and swallowed the whole lot.  She stood on the floor and asked feicu to fight her so he did and, She beat him.  finn Mac Cool caught her and but her to her knees in the floor and cut her head off.Ballinakill

4622961/4617088/4626961.title: Fir Láidre
4622961/4617088/4626961.text:
Minnchir is MeanncharBeirt dearbhrathair a bhí ionnta agus d'ith Meannchar na súbh-chraoibh ar Mhinnchir agus theastuigh slat ó Mhinnchir le é a bhualadh. Theastuigh bealadh uaidh le h-aghaidh ioscadaí ealla. Ealla a shnámhfadh uisge. Uisce fhliuchfadh cloch. Cloch a ghéaróchadh tuagh. Tuagh a bhainfeadh slat. Slat a bhuailfeadh Meannchar a d'ith mo chuid súgh-chraobh.



Pisreógaí1. Nuair a bhíonn daoine ag dul ar thórramh itheann siad gráinne salainn.2. Nuair a ghearann daoine lámh nó cos cuireann siad cuide de'n fhuil 'na bhéil leis an ordóig dheis.

4613697/4609777/4627062.title: Giants
4613697/4609777/4627062.text:
There were big giants in Oughterard long ago and the lied on on top of the mountains.They used to eat the marrow of the beef and the meat of the hen. When the came into a house they said they got the smell of an Irishman. He was too big for one bite and two small for two bites, but if they had a grain of salt on him they would eat him in
(continues on next page)

4613697/4609786/4627066.title: Giants
4613697/4609786/4627066.text:
GiantsLong ago there were two giants in Oughterard. The Connemara Giant and the Galway Giant. They had it settled that one day they would come to fight. The Connemara Giant came a nd the Galway Giant came. When the Galway Giant saw the Connemara Giant he got afraid and he ran home. The Connemara Giant got vexed and he took up a rock and he threw it after the Galway Giant and the rock fell in the Plantation where it
(continues on next page)

4613697/4609788/4627069.title: Hags
4613697/4609788/4627069.text:
There were two hags long ago in Oughterard. One of them happened to be one side of the Corrib and the other on the opposite side. They began firing stones at one another until they had two great heaps of stones one at either side of the Corrib. Other people say that it were giants that were buried there. Cailleach Bhéarac was another old hag that was living in Oughterard. She was always minding a cow.At that time there was no fence between each person's land and the
(continues on next page)

4622994/4621887/4628973.title: A Story about a Giant
4622994/4621887/4628973.text: This story is about a big rock that is over on the Ballinasloe side of Ahascragh  It is several tons in weight and it is said that there was a giant in Ballinasloe and his name Killupan and the peoples he threw this Rock over to this field from Ballinasloe and some people say that he threw it from Mt Mary.  It is about 15 miles from here and it is about 21 miles from Ahascragh and Ballinasloe is about five miles from Ahascragh and after that the field and the village is Killupan

4622990/4621513/4629404.title: Giant Stories
4622990/4621513/4629404.text:
Giant StoriesOnce a giant lived on a high cliff that stood on the bank of the Shannon.  He built his castle there.  He killed and ate the people's animals.  He left a lighted candle outside his door every night, and every person who looked at the candle would die before morning.  A young man named Regan sat out one night to kill the monster.  He put on a magic cap that shaded his eyes from the candle.  He found the candle blindfolded and threw it into the Shannon.  Then the cap fell from his eyes.  The giant ran out and Regan, who was six feet in height, was only up to his knee.  Regan struck the giant with his sword, but the giant's skin was so tough that it broke Regan's sword.  The giant paused for a moment after receiving the blow.  While Regan had a chance he dived into the Shannon and swam across.  The giant picked up a bit of the cliff about two tons weight, and threw it at Regan.  As he did so he slipped and fell over the cliff.  The stone fell on him and killed him.Once a king lived in the North of Ireland.  He had only one daughter whom he wished to get married.  At this time there were three princes in Ireland.  One lived in the East, another in the west and the third in the South.  They were known as Prince Sunrise, Prince
(continues on next page)

4622992/4621786/4629731.title: Giants
4622992/4621786/4629731.text: It is said that there was a giant in Mt. Bellew one time and another in Skehana. They both had a fight one day and the giant in Mt. Bellew threw a big stone from Mt. Bellew to Skehana and the mark of his five fingers were on the stone.There was also another giant named Conán Maol and he came to a hag's house one day. He was not dressed as he usually was and he thought that the hag would not know him. But she said she knew him well and he said he would kill her and he killed her.

metadata.Teacher:: M. Ó Dubhláin, M. Ó Muineacháin

4622998/4622182/4629775.title: Story
4622998/4622182/4629775.text: There is a big stone in the village of Ballyskea and it is said that a giant flung it to cover a pot of gold that was buried in the ground, but it slipped when the giant flung it. You could see the track of his boot and his shoulder in it. Some people say that if it was stirred he would get alive again. Others say that he flung it to knock the castle in Monivea. Some people would be afraid to pass it at night.

4622999/4622289/4630033.title: The Houses Long Ago
4622999/4622289/4630033.text:
(continued from previous page)
no hanger for hanging the pot or kettle on. There were two or three doors in every house, one in the front and another in the back and another in the room. There were three small windows in the front. The floor was made of stones and smoothed with "doib duibe". There was a half-door in every house long ago to keep out the hens. The fire was made of turf and timber. The light they had was a stump of dry timber in the middle of the floor and when it was lighting well this was the light they had.



There was once a giant who lived in Athenry and he wanted to throw a stone from Athenry to Monivea and it fell in a place called Ballydavid about a mile from Athenry and it now marks the first mile stone. The was another giant who
(continues on next page)

4602718/4598184/4630204.title: (no title)
4602718/4598184/4630204.text: Long, long years ago in the days of mighty men two giants decided to have a little bottle. It was with stones they fought. One of the giants stood on Leawn moutain (Glenague, Leawn P.O., Manorhamilton) and the other was on Trush Mor. (Highest mountain in Country Leitrim). The giant on Leawn flung a large stone at his opponent. The other then flungh one up at him, but it fell some two thousand yards from Leawn, in "ault mor" a big ault in Glenague, Glencar, Manorhamilton. That ault is about a half-mile long. The big stone is still there and is overgrown with grass and weeds. There are some holes in the stone and they are probably the tracks of the huge giant's fingers.

4622997/4622093/4630359.title: Giants
4622997/4622093/4630359.text:
About five hundred years ago there was a giant living in this parish and he used to go wandering over Ireland very often. One day he was standing on top of Knock Ruaḋ. He caught a big heavy stone and fired it from Knock Ruaḋ to this parish. The stone is called bloc breac. When he caught the stone to fire it he sunk his hand into it and he put the track of his five fingers and the palm of his hand on the stone. It landed in Higgin'ssfield Colemanstown, Ballinasloe, County Galway. The stone is there yet.



About one thousand years ago there was a giant living in this district. One day he was standing on Cloonkeen hill Colemanstown, Ballinasloe, County Galway and another giant said to him. "you are not able to fire a stone as far as I can". The giant took up a stone and he fired it to a field called "Móinín a' cró in Mount Hazel, Castleblakeney, Ballinasloe, County Galway. The other giant did not send the stone as far. The stone is there yet.
(continues on next page)

4622997/4622093/4630360.text:

It landed in Higgin'ssfield Colemanstown, Ballinasloe, County Galway. The stone is there yet.



About one thousand years ago there was a giant living in this district. One day he was standing on Cloonkeen hill Colemanstown, Ballinasloe, County Galway and another giant said to him. "you are not able to fire a stone as far as I can". The giant took up a stone and he fired it to a field called "Móinín a' cró in Mount Hazel, Castleblakeney, Ballinasloe, County Galway. The other giant did not send the stone as far. The stone is there yet.
(continues on next page)

4622997/4622095/4630361.title: Old Hags
4622997/4622095/4630361.text:
Old Hags There was an old hag living in Keave, Ballymacward, Woodlawn, County Galway long ago. Her name was Kitty. The people of the district was very kind to her except one family and they never spoke to her. She used to cause a lot of trouble to this family.When they used to go milking the cows the cows would have no milk. This was going on for a long time until the man of the house went out early one morning to see if anyone was milking the cows. He waited a long time and at last who came but the hag with two big cans and a stool. She sat under one of the cows and started milking but the man never stirred. When she had one milked once she started to milk the other. The man ran out from where he was hiding and said "What are you doing". The hag ran away and the man set his dog after her and he gave the hag a bite in the leg. When he went to where the hag was living which was a little hut he said "Why did you milk my cow Kitty". She said "I did nothing out of the way" "Well" said the man "dont I see where the dog bit you when you were running away".This story was told by John Kelly aged 58years of
(continues on next page)

4622997/4622096/4630362.title: Old Hags
4622997/4622096/4630362.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



2. There was an old hag living in Poll Bawn in a little hut. The hag's name was Judy and no one used to see her out at all. One day their was a hunt in Poll Bawn and when the huntsmen and dogs were drawing near the hut they rose a big black cat and the dogs followed the cat into the hut and they bit a piece of the cats leg. When the men went into the hut they saw an old hag within in bed, They asked her what was wrong with her and she said that dogs bit her leg. This old hag was a witch and she could take the shape of a cat.



3. There was an old hag living in a field which is now owned by Martin Barry of Cloonkeen Kerrill, Colemanstown, Ballinasloe, Co Galway. The neighbours built a wooden house for her. She had no stock or land. The neighbours gave her food, clothes and turf.The people called her "Old Bridget". She was a small woman with grey hair. She used to stay nearly all her time in her own house praying.

4622997/4622096/4630363.title: Old Hags
4622997/4622096/4630363.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



2. There was an old hag living in Poll Bawn in a little hut. The hag's name was Judy and no one used to see her out at all. One day their was a hunt in Poll Bawn and when the huntsmen and dogs were drawing near the hut they rose a big black cat and the dogs followed the cat into the hut and they bit a piece of the cats leg. When the men went into the hut they saw an old hag within in bed, They asked her what was wrong with her and she said that dogs bit her leg. This old hag was a witch and she could take the shape of a cat.



3. There was an old hag living in a field which is now owned by Martin Barry of Cloonkeen Kerrill, Colemanstown, Ballinasloe, Co Galway. The neighbours built a wooden house for her. She had no stock or land. The neighbours gave her food, clothes and turf.The people called her "Old Bridget". She was a small woman with grey hair. She used to stay nearly all her time in her own house praying.

4622997/4622097/4630364.title: Old Hags
4622997/4622097/4630364.text: 4. There was an old hag who lived in a field beside the Menlough road and she had a child.
