When the old hag was going anyplace she had a hold dug in the ground and she used to put the child down in the hold and she used to put a bit stone over the child and leave her there until she would come back.This story was told by Patrick Finnerty aged 56 years of Cloonkeen Kerrill, Colemanstown, Ballinasloe, County Galway5. There was a man working on a railway line, One evening as he was coming  home from work he saw an old hag sitting on the railway line and she was combing her hair. He snapped the comb from her and brought it home with him.That night when he was going to bed the old hag came to his window and she was crying for her comb. He gave it to her and she told him to put out his hand to her and they would never fight again. He put out the sock of a plough he got under the window and she put the track of her five fingers on the sock of the plough.This story was told by Patrick Finnerty aged 56 years of Cloonkeen Kerrill, Colemanstown, Ballinasloe, County Galway

4623000/4622400/4630411.title: An Chailleach
4623000/4622400/4630411.text:
(continued from previous page)
in his ear to fight on, then he broke one of the giant's necks and the giant lost all his strength. Then he promised Murtagh everything he had Murtagh said he would have his his heads too. Murtagh killed the giant and he married the beautiful girl.



It is thought that a giant called "Merál [?] gráine" was living in Tiaquin long long ago.  One day he invited Fionn and his men to a feast.  When Fionn arrived at the castle there was no one there but he went in all the same.  No sooner were they within when they fell in a heap on the floor and then the whole house began to get small and a voice outside said that unless the "Fianna" could kill the 200 inhabitants of Tiaquin before sun rise every man in their ranks would die.  The 200
(continues on next page)

4623000/4622401/4630412.title: A Giant
4623000/4622401/4630412.text:
(continued from previous page)
inhabitants of Tiaquin were quartered into bands of nine and were fixed at certain points.  One man "Diarmuid" was late in coming and so on hearing Fionns tale of woe from inside the walls of the doorless house he attached each party just as the sun was rising he had the 200 people killed.



Long ago all the football and hurling matches used to be held in Attymon. There were people in the district for driving the players to the field. The man who owned the side-car for driving the players in this district was Thomas Mahon, Newcastle. The players used to be bare-footed and used to wear flannel  "baneens" embroidered with green thread and small knitted  caps on their heads and soft knitted belts. The games used to be played between two villages and if both parties got the same amount of "points" the race home between the two side-cars would decide the matter.

4623000/4622408/4630442.title: The Leprechaun
4623000/4622408/4630442.text:
(continued from previous page)
minds a pot of gold under a tree and spends his time shoe making. One day a woman who lived in Newcastle caught him and put him in her apron but because of his cunning he got away, he pointed to her house and said it was on fire she looked up and when she looked up he was gone because of you every take your eyes off him he will disappear.



A giant is supposed to be thirty feet in height who could lift a house and pull a tree out of the ground and make every one afraid of him. There was a giant living in a castle, every day he used come out and eat men, women and children. One day two brave men named Mark Fagan and Antony Marston one disguised as a bear and the other as a tiger, when they got near the giant they jumped at him and killed him.

4602708/4597351/4631116.title: Fathaigh - Gioll Sciath
4602708/4597351/4631116.text:
Seán dé Faoite, aois 13, as Cill-Sgeachach, Turloch Mór, a fuair an sgéul seo ó na athair, Seán de Faoite.Tá fothracha sean-chaisleán i gCill-Sgeachach agus creideann muinntir na h-áite go raibh fathach in a chomhnuidhe ann fadó. Tá daoine ar inntin fós, gurb é "Gioll-Sgiath" an t-ainm atá ar an mbaile agus gurbh o'n bhfathach a fuair sé an t-ainm.Pé sgéul é, nuair a bhí Gioll-Sgiath in a ghasúr bheag, bhí an ghrádh ag a mháthair do, mar ní raibh aici acht aon mhac amháin agus ní raibh san gcaislean acht an bheirt aca. Bí rud amhain ag chur imnidhe uirthí, bhí an-ghoile ag Gioll, agus bhí croidhe a mháthar beagnach brisde ag iarriadh a sháthach a coingbeál leis, acht nior chlis sí air. D'fás sé suas go raibh sé ina a fhear óg, agus bhí sé chomh mór, chomh árd agus chomh laidir sin go raibh faithchios ar 'chuile duine roimhe.Lá amháin dubhairt a mháthair leis go gcaithfheadh sé tosnú ag obair chun a bheartha a shaorúghadh. Ceard a ndearna sé? Rinne sé cliabhán mór, chuir sé a mháthair sios ann, d'árduigh sé ar a druim é, agus rinne sé a bhealach go Baile-Átha Cliath.Ag sroichint na cathrach sin
(continues on next page)

4602728/4598819/4631526.title: A Giant
4602728/4598819/4631526.text:
Scattered here and there through out this district are graves of giants. Once upon a time there lived a giant near Hugh McSharry's house Aughavohill Kinlough Co. Leitrim.Once a land Lord who lived in Manorhamilton sent thirteen men with swords and spears to kill him. It was on a snowy Winters night and when they reached this district they were covered with snow. When the giant heard them coming he put out the light and
(continues on next page)

4602728/4598822/4631527.title: A Giant
4602728/4598822/4631527.text:
More than a century ago there lived a man in the town-land of Aughavohil, Kinlough, Co. Leitrim. He lived to be very old and he was very wealthy. He was also a brave and heroic man and he done many a brave deed. The following is one of them-One day a poor old woman came into his house and asked him could he give her any alms. He gave her some alms but he was suspicious about her and he thought she was a spy and so she was. The old woman lifted
(continues on next page)

4602731/4599351/4631869.title: Story
4602731/4599351/4631869.text: Long ago there lived in this townland on the top of the hill a giant. The place where he lived was called Ketty Carr. The lived another giant on the top of the hill in the opposite direction. The giants had a bet on to see which of them would throw a stone about three tons weight the farthest. Each of them stood on the top of each hill and threw the big rocks into John Foxs land. The rocks are still to be seen in the Jhn Foxs landThis townland was noted for the fairies. There are several stories in connection with the fairies long ago.

4602740/4600023/4632855.title: A Local Giant
4602740/4600023/4632855.text:
There lived a Giant in Silver Hill about the year 1540.There was a woman who had 3 sons and a daughter.  They were very poor and they had nothing to eat only sheep.  One day the youngest of them said to his mother "I better go away to earn my living.  Kill one of those sheep for me."  When the sheep was killed his mother said to him which would you sooner have the whole of the sheep and my curse or the half and my blessing.  He said if I would have to go a far journey the half would be no good to me.  On he went till he came to a castle he went up to the Giant and said "I want work please."  The Giant said to him what sort of work can you do he said every king of work.  The next day the Giant brought him out to train
(continues on next page)

4602740/4600026/4632857.title: A Local Giant
4602740/4600026/4632857.text:
There lived a Giant long ago in the district.  I do not know what his name was.  One day a band of Soldiers came to look for him he was at leath-tóin.  They got him and the shot him in the thigh.  That is how the district of leath-tóin got its name.  The meaning of leath-tóin is one thigh.He was brought up to our farm and he was buried on a big hill in it.  The name of the hill is Tullach an Fhir Mhór.  The meaning of Tullach an Fhir Mhór is the hill of the big man.  There were two other Giants in this district from which two districts took their names.  The names of the two Giants were Corr and Stran.  They were in Bundoran.  One of them wanted to kill the other one.  A Mother of one of the Giants was in Bundoran and the other Giant heard this and he got her.  He threw her from him and she landed midway between Bundoran and Stran na Coille.  He caught her again and she
(continues on next page)

4602746/4600593/4633168.title: A Story
4602746/4600593/4633168.text: In the townlad of Lios-Ross there is a mountain where a giant pulled a plank a ton weight and it left a track a yard deep and a foot wide.

4602743/4600390/4634197.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4602743/4600390/4634197.text: Stories of Giants and WarriorsMy grandfatehr who is two years dead now, told me that there is a giants grave on the "stone pound Bog" He said it was covered with stones and it was about ten foot long and about four feet in width. he also said about twenty yards away from the grave there is a big rock and the track of a hand and five fingers on it. The hand is about three times the size of a man's hand and the fingers the thickness of a child wrist. The Stone Pound Boy is near the town of manor-hamilton.A number people cut turf on it.By Mary McPartlinMeenymore N.S.

4605934/4603772/4643525.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4605934/4603772/4643525.text: Stories of Giants and warriors.There are no stories of giants and warriors in this locality.

4649679/4646012/4650103.title: Scéal
4649679/4646012/4650103.text:
There was once a woman who was very rich. She had a horse with beautiful bells and a gold basin and a big knife. This man lived near her and he was trying to steal the horse but she had seven men minding her. This night he came and brought a few bottles of whiskey and set them all drunk. The man that was riding on her he put him riding on a post and he fell asleep. Then he stole the horse. In the morning the woman came out and asked "Where was the horse" and the man said "here she is Mam". He thought he was riding on the horse but anyway she sacked him. Then a few nights after she was sitting beside the fire making porridge but the man went up on top of the chimney and brought a bag of meal with him. When she would turn her back to the fire he would throw the meal down the chimney. So then the woman saw it was getting very thick so she brought the basin out for water. When the man saw her coming near the well he ran and pushed her in and brought home the gold basin. But she got up and said
(continues on next page)

4649679/4646066/4650322.title: Scéal
4649679/4646066/4650322.text: There was once an old witch and she lived alone in a house in the wood. Not many people passed there until one day a little girl and a boy passed the way. The house was made of oranges and they went near the house and she called them in and she kept them there. She put the lad down in a room and kept the girl working and her job was to bring turf and the witch to bring water. One day she was gone for the water and girl was home before her and she had a wand and the girl got it and opened the door of the room and they went off with the wand and the witch came and she gave very long steps and she was very near up to them and she very vexed and she was going to catch them and the girl turned the place into water and she got drowned and they turned themselves into swans. They changed themselves into their right form again.

4649700/4648365/4650946.title: A Giant Story
4649700/4648365/4650946.text: Near Drumsna, Co. Leitrim there is a farm called Belmont. It is said that a giant threw a rock from Shee Mor and it fell in Belmont. Shee Mor is a small mountain about four miles distant. There are five pieces strewn around and in one there are three finger-prints. One of them is going right through the rock for the distance of one foot. The other two are on the of the rock. They are supposed to be the first and second fingers of the giant.

4649681/4646240/4651151.title: (no title)
4649681/4646240/4651151.text: Feabhra 1938Some time ago there lived a giant in Belmont and another in Cnocma. They had a quarrel and it ended in a terrible fight. The Cnocma giant flung a huge stone at his enemy. He, seeing the stone approach, stuck it with a violent blow of his sword and broke it into three parts. Two parts of it remained on the hill with the marks of the giants fingers on one of them. The other part rolled down the hill to a field in Ballyglass and there they remain to the present day.

4602763/4602387/4651500.title: A Witch
4602763/4602387/4651500.text:
(continued from previous page)
and took a mouth-ful of skin off her back and the people went in after her and the house was all covered with blood, and they took the clothes off her bleeding and the skin off her back in the same place as the dog caught the hare. Dr Johnston put her from his farm and told her if he ever saw her on his farm he would burn her alive.



A giant threw a finger stone from Nock-na-re to Cairns View near Sligo. The finger stone was about twenty ton weight. His name was Milre - Mór. The stone is still to be seen at Cairns View and trade of the giants fingers on it.

4649701/4648583/4652301.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4649701/4648583/4652301.text: There were two giants and they lived on Corn Hill and they both wanted to marry a girl and one of the giants went away with the girl and the other threw a stone and it fell in a field of ours in Dromod Beg, Dromod. There are finger marks on it.

4649696/4648176/4652850.title: Local Giants
4649696/4648176/4652850.text: Once a women had three sons she was very poor. One day she sent the sons to look for work. The walked and walked till it was near night and they saw a light in the distance they went there and asked for work. There was no one there but a women sitting at the fire. She told them her husband was a giant and she feared they would stay. This giant had three sons also. The giants sons had red caps and the others had none the boys took the caps of the three sons and put them on their own heads. The giant did not come till near morning when he came he took out his own son and killed him. The other boy escaped while he was killing his own son.

4649702/4648658/4658800.title: Folklore - Giants
4649702/4648658/4658800.text: In olden times there lived in this district two giants.  One lived in Ruskey, Co Roscommon, and the other in Sheemore, Co Leitrim.Those two giants had quarrelled with one another.  The giant that lived in Ruskey threw a large stone at the giant in Sheemore with the intention of killing him.  The distance from Ruskey to Sheemore was twelve miles.  The stone did not reach its destination.  It fell about eight miles short.  The stone fill in a field belonging to Bernard Shanley, Fearnaught, Dromod, Co Leitrim.  Only half the stone is to be seen as the rest of it is buried in the ground.  The giant's finger prints are still to be seen on the stone.

4658423/4653850/4659452.title: Giants and Warriors
4658423/4653850/4659452.text:
A giant lived in Bornacoola and he was buried in the graveyard in our field. The grave was about on perch long and a yard wide. It was called "Diarmuid's bed", because that was his name. There was another giant living in Bornacoola also. He weigh twenty tons. He used to travel the coach road walking or sometimes on a coach. Essen was his name. He had no house or shelter He used to go Kilglass lough to swimOne day while he was swimming he thought he heard someone talking. He looked up and forgot he was swimming  and got drowned He was brought to Lisagenal  and buried in  Mr Mc Garry's field, The grave is fourteen feet long and ther is a stone at each end and a blackthorn each side.It is said that Fionn Mc Cumaill threw a lump of dirt at another giant and where it fell Lough Neagh now lies. A giant wanted to throw a big  stone at Ruskey bridge but he was not able to throw it far enough you could see the track of the giants fingers and the joints of his fingers on the stone also.
(continues on next page)

4591084/4588947/4660043.title: Paidreacha
4591084/4588947/4660043.text:
Paidir é seo a n- abruigheann na sean daoíne ag dul a chodhladh dhoib:Siothchan ar d-tigearna iosa críostBhrigh a Pháise beannuighthe Fiocmhar na croíse ro namhtha. An tiodhal caithreimeach. Iosa An Nasared. Rí na N-Iudach Maighdean as Múire. Mathair Choimirce na naomh Aingeal Eadarghuidhe ar Uile Firéin idir mé agus na Namhaid go léir istigh is amhuigh Anois agus ar uair mo bháis.Paidhir ag dul a colad duithA Brighidh a muire na ngaedhil. A Brighidh leataid orm do brath is connuigh faoí do teim mé go bhfuig mé bás i gcairdeas déRoimh labhairt.A Íosa a mhic dé a bhí ós comhair geoláir ná leig duinn ar dteanga a luasgadh gan smaoineadh ar cad atá againn lé rádh agus cionas é a rádhAg teacht abhaile dhuit.Osglaigid dorais an chirt agus ar mo dhul isteach dom deanfadh adhmain dom a Thíghearna.I dtosach oibre.A Thighearna tabhair grasta dam an saotar seo do déanamh cun do glóire-sé cun m' anma ag do réir mar ata orduighthe agat-sa.
(continues on next page)

4591084/4588948/4660044.title: Paidreacha
4591084/4588948/4660044.text:
(continued from previous page)
Duan an t-Slánuightheóraag dul isteach i dteach an phobail duit.Mo ghrádh-sa mo dhia mo ghrádh i mo luigheMo ghrádh gheal mo thíghearna throchaireachMo ghrádh mhilis Críost is grádhaim é lem chroidheMo ghrádh thú a rí na nglóire,Mo ghrádh-sa do shuil, mo ghrádh-sa do shiubhalMo ghrádh-sa do clú is do chomhachtaMo ghrádh-thú le fhonn ciodh táim bun-ós-cionnIs ní dheárna mo chumha do chomhairle. Amen.Páidir ar maidinA Iosa is duitse gach nídh is gach focal is gach smaoineadh uaimse indiu. Amen



Seo páidir le rád nuair a beiteá sa leabaidhLuigimh ar an leabaid seoMar luighimh ins an uaighDéánaim m'faoistín leathÍosa go cruaidh.Tré gniomhartha mo cholnaTré smaointe mo chroidheTré amarch mo shúilTré labairt mo bhéilTré siubal mo chos
(continues on next page)

4591084/4588949/4660045.title: Paidreacha
4591084/4588949/4660045.text:
(continued from previous page)
Tré gach ní adubhairtIs nach raibh fíorTré gach níd gheallasIs nár chóimhlíonasGach níd do rinneas i gcoinne do dligheNó do thola naomhthaIarraim-se maitheamhnas ort a Rí na Glóire. Amen.



Ag dul a chodhlad do duine deirtear an páidir seo.Go luigímid le Dia is go luigeadh Dia linnSgát Dé ós mo cionn. Crois na n- Aingeal fé mo chomCá luigead tú anocht idir Muire agus a MachIdir Bríghid agus a brat. Idir Columh cille agus a sgath. Idir Dia is a lamh dheas Cá luigeadh tú amaireach. Éireóchadh suas le Naomh Pádraich. Cá iad sin ar aghaidh. Aingeal Dé. Cá iad sin indiaidh an oireadh seo eile de muinntír Dé.D'innsighídís duinn fá ifreann agus oscail geatha flaitheas dé. leig an t- ulcas mó amach is an t-anamh truaigh isteach. Ó a Dia déan trócaire orainn agus mach na hóige go bfuireadh ar a n-anam.

4658462/4657999/4660781.title: Giants
4658462/4657999/4660781.text: In olden times there were two giants who lived in Clincorac Castle two miles this side of Carrigallen. There is a field at the Castle and it was called the Kings field these giants long ago never went under the name of giants they were always called Kings but they were that big and strong they could nearly lift a house. They arranged for the fight between the two kings to take place at the castle and each giant made his own grave before the fight started and they fought till they died and each giant was buried in his own grave. There is a headstone over each of their graves weighing three ton weight. A sky lark was never known to this day to sing over Clincorac Castle since the two giants fought, and grass was never known to grow on the spot where they fought. Now this is a true real story it is there plainely for anybody to see it.

4658457/4657573/4661224.title: The Care of Our Farm Animals
4658457/4657573/4661224.text:
(continued from previous page)
made off, Myles caught the foal and trained him. He was supposed to be the fleetest horse in the country, no soldier on horse back could catch him. It is said that one day when he was letting him out he hit him with the bridle; he made off and was never seen again.



Giants and Warriors lived in this district in former times. They generally lived in caves and often fought among themselves. It is said that they used to move rocks from one place to another. There once lived a giant in Scotland and he came over to fight an Irish giant. (defeted the) The Irish giant was the stronger
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589039/4661234.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589039/4661234.text:
Ta se tamall fada o shoin ó bhi fathach ins an áit seo. Ní raibh sé ina comhnuidhe i bfad ó'n áit seo. Bhí faithcíos mór ar na daoine roimhe agus bhíodh sé ag goid cearcha agus géana uatha san oidhche nuair a bhíodh siad ina gcodhladh. Ní theigheadh an fathach seo a chodladh chor ar bith ach amháin sa lá. Bhí sé ina chomhnaidh ar oileán agus do thóg sé balla mó timceall air agus do rinne sé sórt teach beag le clocha istigh ina lár agus is ann a bhíodh sé ina chodhladh. bhí madadh mór aige freisin agus bhí an oiread faitchíos ag na daoine roimhe is bhí aca roimh an fathach féin. Ní bhíodh an fathach seo ag déanamh cáidreamh le h-éinne de'n na daoine a bhíodh ina gcomnaidhe timcheall air. Nuair a ghoideadh sé cearc ó dhuine ar bith aca do bhíodh faitchíos ortha rud ar bith a rádh leis. Nuair a bhíodh an fathach ina codhladh sa lá do bhíodh an madadh ag faire an áit. Dá dtiocfadh duine ar bith i ngar do'n oilean nó ar an taobh amuigh do leanfadh an madadh é. Bhí an madadh i ndhan snamh a dhéanamh agus sé an chaoí a dtéigheadh an fathach amach is isteach ná uair amháin nuair a tháinig sé go dtí an áit. Do goid sé bád beag ó duine éigin agus do choinigh sé í go bhfuair sé bás. Ní leigfeadh faitchíos do dhuine a theacht ag iarraidh an bháid ar an bhfathach. Do mhair an fathach tamall maith blíanta agus bhí na daoine creachta aige sul a bhfuair sé bhás. Sé an bás a fuair sé ná do báthadh
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589040/4661256.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589040/4661256.text:
(continued from previous page)
é agus é ag teacht isteach ar an oileán agus an bád lán aige le cearca lachainn agus géana. Bhí an aimsear garbh agus bhí an oidhche ann nuair a bhí sé ag teacht agus buaileadh an bád in aigheadh cloch agus briseadh an bád. Do bathadh an fathach agus do sgaip na cearca agus gach rud a bhí aige ar fud an locha. Bhí an madadh in dhán é do sabalta acht bhí an madadh ar an taobh amuigh nuair a bhí se dhá bathadh agus níor srois sé é i nám. Do theip air é a shábhalt. Do mhair an madadh chúpla mí in a dhiadh sin acht do caileadh é leis an ocras. bhí ann athas ar na daoine nuair a bhí deire leis an bhfhathach agus leis an madadh. Tugadh oileán an bhalla mar ainm ar an oilean a raibh sé ina comhnaidhe ann.



Do bhí fathach timcheall na h-áite seo fadó agus bhí teach aige ann agus bhíodh sé ag fiadhach i gcomhnaidhe. Do bhí go leór craoine timceall ar an teach agus chuile bhlian bíodh go leór lé nithe ortha. Ba crann ubhla is mó a bhí timceall air. Lá amháin chuaidh sé amach ag fiadhach agus dhuan sé an doras. Dfan sé amuigh ar fead an lae agus an faidh is bhí sé amuigh dith duine eicínt na h-ublaí ar. Nuair a táinic sé isteac
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589041/4661257.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589041/4661257.text:
(continued from previous page)
chonnaic sé go raibh na h-ubhlaí ar fad ithte. Dubhairt sé leis féin go bfuigheadh sé amach cé dith iad agus muna ninnseocfaí dó é go gcuireadh sé cath ortha. Thosuigh sé ag siubal thart ins na tighthe agus ag fiafruigh de na daoine faoi na h- ublaí. agus féacaine a bhfuigheadh sé tuairisg ó duine ar bith. Táinic sé isteach i dteach. Ní raibh san teach ach bean agus buachaill. Dfiafruigh sé an buachaill ar an mbean agus thug sí dó é. Nuair a táinic siad chomh fada leis an teach chuaidh an buachaill suas san gcrann. Agus nuair a chuaidh sé suas chonnaich sé daoine shuas san gcránn. Dinnis sé don fathach é agus lean an fathach iad acht san deire sheas na daoine annsin agus taréis píosa mór troda mharuigheadar an fathach agus bhí an teach agus an talamh aca féin uaidh sin amac.



BHí fathach in a comhnaidhe amuigh ar an gcroc lé taobh sruthán uair amáin. Bhíodh sé ag teacht anuas ins an mbaile agus ag goid geabha agus cearca. Sa deire bí an baile creachta aige ag goid chuile short. Bí pluais déannta aige faoi bun aille lé taobh an t-srutháin. Lá amain socruigh daoine
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589042/4661289.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589042/4661289.text:
(continued from previous page)
an bhaile an fatach a mharbhú. Oidhche amáin cuadar amach ag dhul ag marbhú an fataigh. Nuair a tháinic siad comh fada leis an bpluis ní raibh sé ann agus séard a rinneadar na an áill a caitheadh anuas i mullach na plúise san áit nach bfeadfadh sé dul isteach ann. Annsin chuadar abhaile agus nuair a cuadar abhaile ní raibh chearc na gé fágtha aige Maidin lá ar na báireach cuadar amach arís agus fuaireadar e ag doras na pluaise Chuaidh an céad fear amach agus chladheamh. Lean an fathach é agus mharbhuigh se é. Sa deire cuadar uilig amhach agus marbhuigheadar é. Agus is é an tainm athá ar an áil ó soin na Áill na bhFatach.



Bhí fathac san áit seo san t-'Sean aimsir. Tháinig an fatac agus cuaid sé isteac ar oileán agus chuir sé balla thar timcheall air agus sé an t-ainm atá ar an oileán ná oileán an fhathaigh. Nuair a tháinaig sé ar dtús nuair a thaghad sé isteac idteac beag íseal leagadh sé é bhí chomh h-árd sin Nuair a bí na daoine go léir faoi na smact aige chuaidh sé ar an oileán. Thagadh
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589044/4661320.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589044/4661320.text:
(continued from previous page)
tafann chuaidh an fear beag in-áit an madadh agus nuair a chuir an fathac a cheann amac bhain an fear beag an ceann de.



Bhí fatach mó ina comnuid ins an gceantair seo tuairms cead bliain ó soin. Sé an t-ainm a bhí air Tadhg na Búille. Bá fear mór láidhir fiadhain a bí ann agus ní raibh fear ar bith in-an é a bualadh le rúd ar bith a bead siad a déanamh. Bhí bád mór seoil aige agus sé an áit a mbíodh sí feisidhe aige ná i gCoillsaile. Bhí sé féin ina comnuidhe ná ins an Áird. bhí an bádh tuairmh dá míle deag uaidh agus ní bíod sé acht leat uair ag dul soir go dtí í. bíodh sé amuig ar an bfairrge inntí leis féin agus bíodh sé ag dul go cúile áit inntí. Sé an áit a mbíodh sé ag baint a cuid móna ná air an Áirdmóir. Bhí sé ag sparáil an áit a bhí gar do mar bhí sé ag ceapadh nach bfuigheadh sé bás go deo. Nuair a bíodh sé ag teacht ag baint na móna bíodh mná an baile ag crít le faítcios roimhe mar cáithfeadh cúile bean cáca agus cróca ime a béith acú dó agus baine, agus loistín ins na tighe. Teac ar bith a mbead sé ann cáifeadh siad dá leabhadh a cur as a chéile.
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589045/4661331.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589045/4661331.text:
(continued from previous page)
Ní feadfad duine ar bith codhladh ins an teac sin act ag éiseacht leis ag srannadh. Dá mbeadh teach eile roint gar do cluinfeadh siad freisin é. Da mbead aon blás den caca dóghte ná aon ribhe ins an im marbochadh sé iadh. Is minic a bíodh trí no ceathair de cacaí déanta acú ag iarradh ceann ceart nach mbead doighte a déanamh. Nuair a taghadh an Nodlagh cáithfeadh chúile bean ins an Áird pota ime a thabairt cuige agus é a bheith go glan nó marbhocadh sé iad. Bhí bean ann uair agus níor thug sí aon im cuighe. Bhí sí posta agus bhí aon mach amháin aici. Bhí an fatach le í a marbú agus d'imtigh sí leití. Sé an áit a ráibh sé féin agus a fear agus an paíste ná i lár na h-Éireann. Bhí siad sgáthamh blianta ann go raibh an paiste sin in a fear. Nuair a d'inns a máthair do é dubhairt sé go mbainfeadh sé a sasamh dé. D'imtigh sé leis lá agus bhí sé ag siubal go dtáinig sé go dtí an Áird. Ní ráibh fhios ag aon nduine a ráib sé ann. Nuair a fuair sé an tátach in a codhladh cuaidh sé isteach ag rug sé ar a túadh agus bain sé an ceann dé. Bhí taibhse le feiceál ann in a diaidh.



Bhí fathach in a comhnuidhe Timcheall na h-áite seo fadó agus biodh sé ag fiachac i gcomhnuidhe. Bhí teac aige annseo agus ní raibh
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589047/4661334.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589047/4661334.text:
(continued from previous page)
an fathac. Dubhairt sé leis an bhfathac go dtáinic  daoine go dtí an crann ag it na n-ublaí agus gur marbhuigh sé duine acu. Nuair a bhí a suipéir ithte aca dubhairt an fathach leis an mbuacaill go gaobhfadh sé feín amac an t-am seo agus cuaidh ní raibh sé i bhfadh amuigh nuair a táinic daoine agus connaiceadar an fathac suas san gcrann. Táinic siad go dtí an crann agus tosuigh siad dá crathadh ba gcarr gur tuit an fathach anuas agus mharbhuigheadh é. Nuair a fuair an buacaill shuas san gcrann iad fuair sé a guna agus cuaid sé amac agus marbhuig sé iad agus bhí an teac agus an talam aige féin annsin.



Bhí bean ann fadó agus bhí mac aice. Lá amháin dubhairt an mac go raibh sé ag dul ag saothrú Cuaid sé go dtí an gabha agus dubhairt sé leis claideam a déanamh do agus sgriobh orta go mo é féin fear marbugadh na ceadta le buile amháin Rinne an gabha e sin agus thug sé do é. Dimthig sé leis agus casadh fear do. Spáin sé claideam do agus
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589049/4661356.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589049/4661356.text:
(continued from previous page)
agus táinigh an fathac. Buail se cloc air Bhreathnuigh sé suas sa crann agus connaic sé an buachaill. Bhí sé ag dul suas sa crann agus bhuail an buacaill é. Thug sé a ceann go dtí an fear agus fuair sé a saidhbhreas.



Tá sé timcheall is céadh blian ó soin anois ó bhí aon fathach na comnuidhe ins an áit seo.  Uair amháin bhí fathach in an comnuidhe i Ruisin na Manach acht gur amuig ar oilean a bíodh sé ag coladh ins an oidhche.  Tá an t-oilean seo suidhthe amuigh i lár na locha tamhall amach ó cnoc Ruisin na mbanac.  Is i loch na sgaineamh atá sé.  Oilean béag iseadh é agus balla mór déanta timcheall air.  Oilean deas iseadh é freisin, agus caoillthe beagha ag fás air.  Deirthear go be an fathach féin a rinne an balla cun an (t-oilain) t-oilean do cosaint agus an t-uisce a comnail amac.  Tá sé iseal ar an taobh istig agus an árd ar an taobh amuig.  Nuair a tóg sé é d'fhág sé áit ar an taobh ó tuaidh dhí le dul isteach is amach dhí.  Ins an amh sin ní bíodh aon bád ann mar áta anois.  Sé an caoí a bíodh ag an bhfathach le dul isteach
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589051/4661359.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589051/4661359.text:
Do bhí fathach timceall na h-áite seo fado. Do bhí teach aige ann agus bhíodh sé ag fiach i gcomnaidhe. Ní raibh aon duine san teach acht é féin. Do bhí go leór cruinnte timcheall air agus chuile blian bhíodh neart le n-ithe orra. Ba cruinn ubhlaí ba mhó a bhí ann. Lá amháin chuaidh sé amach ag fiach agus dhúin sé an doras ina dhiaidh. Nuair a bhí sé imthighthe chuaidh na daoine isteach san teach agus ghoideadar gach rud a bhí ann. Goideadar an meid a bhí aige uaidh agus bhriseadar na soighthe. bhí go leór airgead aige freisin. 'Sé an fáth a rinneadar é sin mar bhí an fathach an droch-mhúinte agus ag troid leis na daoine. Annsin roinn na daoine Bhí sin go maith no go dtháinigh an fathach san tráthnóna. An céad rud a chonnaich sé na bhí an doras oscailte acht cheap sé gur duine eigin a bhí isthigh. Annsin chuaidh sé isteach acht ní raibh aon duine isthigh roimhe agus choinnaic sé an sgrios mór a bhí deanta. Chuaidh sé go dtí an seomra agus thóruigh sé a chuid airgead ann acht ní pinghean ann. Tháinig fearg air annsin agus níor ith sé aon bhlas mar ní raibh dada le nithe aige. Chuir na daoine i bhfolach an airgead a bhí aca acht pinghin nó dhá pinghin. Chuaidh an fathach thart an na tíghthe agus nuair nach bfaca sé aon airgead acu chuaidh sé go dtí an teach arís acht níor mhair sé i bhfad mar níor raibh dada le n-ithe aige. Annsin caileadh an fathach agus fuair na daoine na h-ublaibh a bhí irna cruinnte. Agus bhíodar go suimneach as sin amach
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589052/4661361.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589052/4661361.text:
Bhí fathac timhceall na h-áite seo fado. Fathac an droc mhuinte do bead é. Bhí sé ag marbhú na ndaoine agus na bpaistí agus cúile dhuine ga gcastaí air. Lá amháin bhí sé ag marbú páiste agus chonnaic na daoine an fathac ag marbú an paiste Annsin socruig na fir mhóra láidre an fatac a mharbu. Lá amháin tháinic na fir láidre le ceile agus d'éaluigh siad air. Tughadar cloca móra leo. Níor airigh an fathac iad ag teacht isteach agus marbhuigheadar é. Bhí án bhrod ar na daoine go lear nuair a bhí sé marbú. Togadar na meid airgid a bhí aige uaidh agus thogadar gach rud a bhí sa teach uaid. Annsin bhí na daoine go lear sásta nuair a bhí sé marbú. Leagadar an teac a bhí aige freisin.



Bhí baintreach ann fadó agus bhí aon mac amháin aichi. Séan an t-ainm a bhí air. Bhí sé ag meadú go raibh sé in a fear acht ní raibh sé ag déanamh aon bhlas maiteasa dá mátair. Lá amháin chuaidh sé amach san ngarraidh ag cur fataí agus nuair bhí sé an am. dinnéir ní racach sé isteach bhaile chuig a dinnéir. Chuir a mátair plata fataí amach cuige san ngarraidh agus luigh cuilleóga ar an bplata. Chuaidh sé isteach abháile arís agus fuair sé sleagh. Nuair a chuaidh sé amac tarraingh sé an t-sleag agus marbhuigh
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589052/4661385.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589052/4661385.text:
Bhí fathac timhceall na h-áite seo fado. Fathac an droc mhuinte do bead é. Bhí sé ag marbhú na ndaoine agus na bpaistí agus cúile dhuine ga gcastaí air. Lá amháin bhí sé ag marbú páiste agus chonnaic na daoine an fathac ag marbú an paiste Annsin socruig na fir mhóra láidre an fatac a mharbu. Lá amháin tháinic na fir láidre le ceile agus d'éaluigh siad air. Tughadar cloca móra leo. Níor airigh an fathac iad ag teacht isteach agus marbhuigheadar é. Bhí án bhrod ar na daoine go lear nuair a bhí sé marbú. Togadar na meid airgid a bhí aige uaidh agus thogadar gach rud a bhí sa teach uaid. Annsin bhí na daoine go lear sásta nuair a bhí sé marbú. Leagadar an teac a bhí aige freisin.



Bhí baintreach ann fadó agus bhí aon mac amháin aichi. Séan an t-ainm a bhí air. Bhí sé ag meadú go raibh sé in a fear acht ní raibh sé ag déanamh aon bhlas maiteasa dá mátair. Lá amháin chuaidh sé amach san ngarraidh ag cur fataí agus nuair bhí sé an am. dinnéir ní racach sé isteach bhaile chuig a dinnéir. Chuir a mátair plata fataí amach cuige san ngarraidh agus luigh cuilleóga ar an bplata. Chuaidh sé isteach abháile arís agus fuair sé sleagh. Nuair a chuaidh sé amac tarraingh sé an t-sleag agus marbhuigh
(continues on next page)

4591084/4589055/4661400.title: Scéalta faoi Fhathaigh
4591084/4589055/4661400.text:
(continued from previous page)
agus fuair sí mála builiní agus túg sí leithe abháile iad. Táinic sí abháile agus nuair a táinich sí chuir sí an fatach agus Seán ag ithe. Cé agaibh an fear is fearr ag ithe adeír sí. Sé an fear is fearr ag troid é. Bhí mála mór ag Seán taobh istigh agus bhí sé ag caiteadh na mbuiliní isteac ann.agus ni raibh sé ag ithe morán. Bhí an fatach dhá tactha féin leis an méid a bhí sé ag ithe. Dubhairt an fatac le na máthair nac bfacha sé aon fear ariamh chomh mhaith le Seán. Chuaidheadar amac agus bhí an fatach dhá tabhtha le na raibh ithe aige. Chaith seán na builiní as an mála bhí taobh istigh aige. D'iarr an fatac ar Seáin na builiní a caiteadh amac dhó feín. Fuair Séan sgein agus saith sé an fatach agus marbuigh sé é. Bhain seán an ceann do'n bfatac agus chuaidh sé go dtí an Rí. Táinich iontas ar an Rí nuair a connaic sé Séan ag teacht agus ceann an bfathaibh aige. Chuir muinntir an tighe fáilte roimhe aghus pos ingean an Rí é. Cuadh sé go dti teach a mátair agus chuir sí fáilthe roimhe nuair a táinic sé isteac mar ceap sí go raibh sé marbh fad ó an lá ag na faiteacaibh.



Bhí fatac na comnaidhe ar oileán i loch sginimh. Bhí balla mor déanta aige ann agus is ann a bhíodh an fatach ag codhladh san oidhche bhí an balla iseal taobh istigh agus bhíodh sé árd taobh amuigh. Ní raibh bád ar bith aige Sé an caoí a theigheadh sé isteach agus amach ar an oileán. Bhíodh piosa fada leathann amaid aige agus dá piosa beaga eile. Shineadh sé an
(continues on next page)

4666594/4665202/4668156.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4666594/4665202/4668156.text:
It was so long ago that no one living remembers him. His name has come down to us and his deeds seem to have happened only yesterday. The giants name is Strong Jim Careu. Strong Jim was born Somewhere in North Kerry. No one is quite sure in what part but Ballinagar, Rathea and Duagh lay claim to him. He worked as a farmers boy going from place to place as he found work. As a boy he was able to throw men several years older than himself. He was attacked once by a wolfhound that everybody feared. He grappled with the hound and choked him.At another time Jim
(continues on next page)
4666594/4665202/4668156.school_info: School: Baile an Chlochair, Lic Snámha

4666594/4665205/4668158.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4666594/4665205/4668158.text:
Long  ago there lived a brave man in Killorglin and his name was Tom Hurley. The people round about used to call him Tom Hurley the giant. This man had great courage and strength. He used to lift a bag of meal off the ground and put it on his back. He could carry a twenty gallon tank on his back also. This man used to make bottles for the people and he used to make crosses of glass and put them into the bottles. All the people used to wonder at this and he would not let anyone see how he did it. Many people tried to do it but they failed. This man never went to school and he pretended he was a fool. His people believed him and
(continues on next page)
4666594/4665205/4668158.school_info: School: Baile an Chlochair, Lic Snámha

4666594/4665208/4668165.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4666594/4665208/4668165.text:
Once there was a Giant living in the district of Derrevrin. It is said that he threw a stone from Tom OConnors to Daniel OConnels marsh in Clohercannon. the stone is a lime-stone and is an inch long and very wide and heavy. It is said that the print of the Giants thumb is on it. Another story told to me by my Grandmother about a Warrior that was living in the Old Court in Lixnaw. His name was James Fitzmaurice he was a very cruel man and he thought a great of himself. It is said that one day a poor beggar-man asked him for alms and he asked in the name of God by any chance could he give him a penny. He looked at the beggar-man with two eyes of fire and said how dare you ask a King like me for money in anu [?] un-
(continues on next page)
4666594/4665208/4668165.school_info: School: Baile an Chlochair, Lic Snámha

4666594/4665210/4668212.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4666594/4665210/4668212.text:
Long ago (about one hundred years ago) there dwelt a giant in the boundary of Rathscannel and Ahannacrinagh. He was an awful height, and he was so tall the people used to call him. "Sunlight Bobby". Every day this giant used to travel around and knock at every door. When he knew that anyone would not leave him in, he began to play tricks on them. There dwelt at that time a woman in Rathscannel. She lived all alone in a little house on the side of a "boreen". This giant used to make her, make big cakes of bread for him. He used to be out by day and by night. Old people say that this giant fought a
(continues on next page)
4666594/4665210/4668212.school_info: School: Baile an Chlochair, Lic Snámha

4666594/4665212/4668215.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4666594/4665212/4668215.text:
Long ago there lived a giant in causeway. This was a very strong man. It is supposed one when he was walking near the ruins of an old Castle a small man said to him "will, you fight a giant for me, and the giant said he would. This man carried him to a place where there were no giants, but ordinary men. When the giant went to the place that the man told him he saw about a hundred  men with sticks and pikes and all classes of things. The giant had nothing, but he caught the corner of a rock and threw it at them and killed the most of them. He held pulling rocks until he had
(continues on next page)
4666594/4665212/4668215.school_info: School: Baile an Chlochair, Lic Snámha

4666594/4665214/4668222.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4666594/4665214/4668222.text:
There once lived a giant who had his abode in the southern side of Connor's Hill in ballinclogher. He lived in a large cave worked in between rocks of stone. At the entrance to this cave a large stone about ten feet long served as door or protection. It is said of him that at night he would travel the country near him and he would take from the people their sheep and cattle to his cave. All the people were afraid to go out by night. So at last ten men volunteered to lay siege to the caves. On the morning of the attack a great storm arose which caused  this giant to awake from his sleep. He looked out over the large stone that barred the
(continues on next page)
4666594/4665214/4668222.school_info: School: Baile an Chlochair, Lic Snámha

4666594/4665216/4668226.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4666594/4665216/4668226.text:
There was a giant living in Derrevrin  in olden times. He was very huge this giant. He had very big hands and he could cock you up on his finger. He used make such a roar that the people used think that it was thunder. He was very bad friends with some giant. One day the giant went out and the other giant knew where he was living so he went on and went into the cave and upset it. Then he heard the giant coming and he tried to escape but the other giant ran and struck him with his sword and killed him.Another day a small
(continues on next page)
4666594/4665216/4668226.school_info: School: Baile an Chlochair, Lic Snámha

4672099/4669962/4682022.title: Old Irish Tales
4672099/4669962/4682022.text: Once upon a time there was a giant in Sweden and he heard about Finn's greatness. This giant had beat all the champions in the country and he wanted to beat Finn too. He sent Finn word that he was coming and when Finn got this news he was hunting on the Ox Mountains in County Sligo, and he had no one with him but his wife and son. Finn did not know what to do, but his wife thought of a trick. There was a cradle in the house and she put Finn in the cradle. When the giant came in he went over to the cradle and said, "Who is this in the cradle" "That is my son," said the woman. Then the giant put his land down to see the baby, but the baby opened its mouth and bit off the top of the giants finger. The giant said "Upon my word if all the Irish children are as wicked as this baby they are a terrible lot" The giant then asked the woman for someting to eat and she baked a cake on the griddle.

4672099/4669967/4682040.title: Stories of Giants
4672099/4669967/4682040.text: Once upon a time there was a warrior named Fionn Mac Cual and he was a great hunter. One day while he was hunting on the Ox Mountains and he saw a huge stone and he said he would throw it into the sea. He threw the stone but it did not fall in the sea. Finn was very angry and he split the stone with his sword. The stone was afterwards called "The Split Rock," and it is beside Killeen School. There is an old legend about the rock, that if you walk through the rock three times it will close on you the third time.

4666609/4666410/4682351.title: The Giant and the Leprechauns
4666609/4666410/4682351.text: About 90 years ago there was a giant living in Kilmore, and he was a terror to all the people. He used to rob them, and carry away all their crops, and kill anyone who tried to stop him. At that time there were lepreachains in the district, and they used always be making shoes, and they had hammers and awls etc. One day the giant attacked one of the leipreachains, but he escaped from him and told the rest of his companions. One day they told the giant that they would fight him on a certain day. The giant consented, and the captain of the leipreachains collected an army and went to fight the giant. When they met the giant in the field that they had appointed to fight in he was surprised to see such a large army of leipreachains against himself. He had consented to fight them, and he said he would keep his word. The giant was armed with a sword and the leipreachains were armed with awls and hammers. The fight started early in the morning and the leipreachains were winning. Towards evening one of the leipreachains fired an awl at the giant's eye and blinded him. THe fight lasted for three days, but the leipreachains got the victory, and they buried the giant in a field in Kilmore called the Booleen[?] field.

4666609/4666416/4682375.title: Local Story of a Giant
4666609/4666416/4682375.text: Long ago there was a giant living somewhere near Rattoo. One day he went out in the wood looking for food. There was a house in the wood and there was a field in front of it, and in this field there was a young child playing. The giant took the child and carried it to his own house. He carried it up-stairs and wrapped it up in a white sheet. He went away then looking for more food. When he went away the father of the child came looking for it. He told the giant's wife that if she told him where his child was, he would get a pig and put it in place of the child. She told him, and he got the pig and killed it and wrapped it in the white sheet that the child was in. He came downstairs and he turned for home. Just as he was going out the door who should he see coming but the giant. The giant followed him. The man knew that there was a concealed jump on the path that he was going. He made for this and jumped over it as he was a great jumper. The giant came on after him and not knowing it was there he jumped right into it and was never seen again.

4605953/4605445/4682636.title: Story of Prevago Stone
4605953/4605445/4682636.text: Once upon a time it is said that two giants had a quarrel. One of them was on the Arigna mountain, and the other was on Slieve-an-Iern. They began to throw stones at each other, and the giant that was on Arigna Mountain threw a stone to Slieve an Iern. This stone is supposed to be fifty tons weight and the prints of this giant's fingers are still on this huge stone. It is called Prevago Stone and one man can shake it at his ease but two hundred men would not lift it.On the last Sunday of July, Garland Sunday, it is the custom of young people to go to the mountain to pick bilberries and often four youths go up and dance an Irish Reel on the Stone. It is said also that the Arigna Giant killed the other giant with this stone and that he is buried under it.Francis Moran,DrumhallDrumshamboTold byMargaret DohertyDrumhall

4672100/4670076/4682939.title: Stories
4672100/4670076/4682939.text:
(continued from previous page)
may.



The castle at the mouth of the Gleneasky river which flows through Gleneasky was inhabited by a Giant and his wife. The giantess was one day out walking when she met a man named O'Dowd and she put him in her apron and carried him home to the castle. She had a cradle made a O'Dowd put into it. There he had to stay as the Giant had no children of his own. A giant from Scotland came one day in answer to a challenge to Roslea castle, to fight the Roslea Giant.The day he arrived the Giant was
(continues on next page)

4672101/4670187/4683305.title: Buying and Selling
4672101/4670187/4683305.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Many years ago there lived a family of Giants, named O'Donnells in the parish of Templeboy Co Sligo. There lived a tailor also in the same district. One day this tailor went out in the field and he saw a great number of flies on the ground, so he got a flat stone and threw it down on top of them and killed them. He then got a sword and printed on it "Able to kill one hundred with one blow." Next he went to the castle and he was not long there till one of the Giants ran out to kill him, but when he showed his sword he did not do anything to him. After a while the Giant's mother came out and invited him in as she was afraid he would kill them. That evening the Giants went out throwing an anvel, each one of them was able to throw it two. When it came to the tailor's turn to throw the anvel he took a grip of one side of it and stood there thinking as he did not know what to do, as he was not able to throw it. One of the Giants asked him what was he thinking about and he said he had a brother in New York and
(continues on next page)

4672101/4670189/4683323.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4672101/4670189/4683323.text: There were once two Giants who lived in the townland of Grangebeg under a cliff near a lake called loch D Croidhe. One night as those two giants were asleep a man was passing by the cave and he heard the giants snoring and he knew that they were asleep. He went in and killed one of the Giants with a stone that he got outside the cave. The other giant awakened by the noise got up and ran out to kill the man. But the man was hidden behind the cave. The giant being in such a hurry ran into the lake and was drowned. The man on seeing this went into the cave and got the money and gold that was in it.

4672101/4670191/4683327.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4672101/4670191/4683327.text: Long ago there were two giants living in a house. There were two stones on a hill. One day they made a bet to see which one of them would throw the stones the farthest. Each stone was as big as a house. One day they went up on a mountain to throw the stones.One of them threw the stone halfway out in the sea, and the other threw it into Easkey and he was so vexed that he got a sword and split the rock in two halves and it is called the "Split rock" ever since. It is about two miles and a half from Dromore West Co Sligo and on the side of Easkey road.The people often measured it and they said the sides were the same size.

4672101/4670192/4683331.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4672101/4670192/4683331.text:
Sixty years ago there was a great Warrior's living in Masshill outside at loc Easkey in County Sligo. He was living alone in a house on a mountain. The neighbours provided him with food, and the men had to bring him home turf.He used to come to this district and steal cattle from the farmers, and lixing them out to his own home and (and) skin them. Then he roasted them. He had twenty soldiers and he provided them with meat. At last the farmers found out, that the warrior was bringing the cattle. The king and his men killed him one night when he was coming to lixing another animal.



In olden time there was an old hag living on Keavanys hill which is situated in Dunbekin Dromore West Co Sligo.It was called Keavanys hill because
(continues on next page)

4672101/4670192/4683333.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4672101/4670192/4683333.text:
Sixty years ago there was a great Warrior's living in Masshill outside at loc Easkey in County Sligo. He was living alone in a house on a mountain. The neighbours provided him with food, and the men had to bring him home turf.He used to come to this district and steal cattle from the farmers, and lixing them out to his own home and (and) skin them. Then he roasted them. He had twenty soldiers and he provided them with meat. At last the farmers found out, that the warrior was bringing the cattle. The king and his men killed him one night when he was coming to lixing another animal.



In olden time there was an old hag living on Keavanys hill which is situated in Dunbekin Dromore West Co Sligo.It was called Keavanys hill because
(continues on next page)

4701658/4690653/4707801.title: Cnocán na Cú
4701658/4690653/4707801.text:
One time a man on horseback was coming through Gortnarung and he had a bag of gold with him.When coming  near a hill he saw a black hound. After hiding the bag of gold the hound began to fight him. It is said that the hound is buried in that hill. So the hill is called Crucán na Cú



2 Long ago a great giant lived round here and he did wonderful deeds. He threw a monster stone from the mountain  down to Michael Clancy's field in Cliffoney about three  miles. The giant also jumped from where he threw  the stone and its is said that he is buried in Andrew McGowan's field



3 In Andrew McGowan's field in Rasberry Hill there is as graveyard  There are headstones in it and on them are letters but in is very hard to make the letters out. My father told me these stories. Thomas Coen, Raspberry Hill, Grange , Sligo

4701710/4694897/4708023.title: A Giant
4701710/4694897/4708023.text:
A Giant Long long ago in the townland of Gurthakeerin in the parish of Killoran and in the Co. Sligo there lived a mighty giant.  He was seven foot high and was about twenty stone in weight so that everybody was afraid of him. He was very rich and had many servants to work for him. He was very cruel also to them when they did not please him. One day he was away at a fair with cattle and when he came back the servant had not his dinner ready and he was very hungry so what do you think he did but ate the servant and started telling everyone of the great dinner he had.Then he got no servant for a long time and when he did get one he was still cruel to her. One day she broke a gold cup and he tied her to a tree and left her there until she died with hunger so she was the last servant ever
(continues on next page)

4701710/4694918/4708056.title: A Giant
4701710/4694918/4708056.text: Long ago in Ireland, there lived at Tara giant who had there heads Every day this giant would go to Tara and stand there and he would shout out in a loud clear voice, "Is there any man who would come and fight me" This day he did the same thing. There was a young lad living near and he heard this man shouting and he up to him and cut the three heads off him.

4701666/4691215/4713330.title: A Story about a Giant
4701666/4691215/4713330.text: There is a story about a giant who carried a stone from Benbulben mountain and left it in one field and therefor it is called the "Big Stone Field". The weight of the stone is about three tons.Sued Finn is a resting place that Finn had out on the mountain for resting when he used to be hunting the wild beasts and killing them on the mountain.

metadata.Teacher:: Tomás Ó Hodhráin, Bean Uí Hodhráin

4701667/4691373/4713843.title: An Old Story
4701667/4691373/4713843.text: A giant and his wife were climbing the side of Barnaribbon Bray on Benbulben one day, they had a quarrel and she fled from him. He took up a stone weighing about seven tons and fired it from Barnaribbon Bray to the sea field in Lissadell at her a distance of five miles. The stone is still to be seen there yet.

4701669/4691538/4714098.title: Old Stories
4701669/4691538/4714098.text: No.5.  Once upon a time there was a giant, and he was forty feet in height, and they called him Big George.  One day he went to a top of a mountain in Co. Mayo. He brought his big sword with him, and when he was going up he met a man with whom he was very friendly.  He said to the man," I am going to throw this sword into the sea", and the man said to him that he would not be able to do it, as the sea was too far away from the mountain. He made an effort to throw it in but it stuck in a rock not far away. He rushed down the mountain very angry and vexed, and he pulled it out with such force that he split the rock into halves.  He said,"I will leave my curse on this rock, and that whoever passes through it it will close upon them, and that curse is left on it from that day to this.Told by father.John Gilmartin.Age 14Class 7th

4701669/4691546/4714109.title: Old Stories
4701669/4691546/4714109.text:
There were old hags long ago, and their names were Ellen Gargan who lived in Ballyglass, and Kitty Calway who lived in "Bail na h-abhainn", and Biddy Meenan who lived  in "Bail na Breothain".The people were afraid of them, because every where they went, they carried a broom with them, and any person they might see they used to hit them. They were kind of witches, and they could fly on the brooms.



Mermaids are lovely girls dressed in green and long golden hair. She was often seen combing her golden hair on a rock. Leipreachans sometimes marry mermaids, because of their beauty.She can swim and has a tail like a fish. She cannot talk, but she can make signs with her hands, and some people understand her.

4701669/4691546/4714112.title: Old Stories
4701669/4691546/4714112.text:
There were old hags long ago, and their names were Ellen Gargan who lived in Ballyglass, and Kitty Calway who lived in "Bail na h-abhainn", and Biddy Meenan who lived  in "Bail na Breothain".The people were afraid of them, because every where they went, they carried a broom with them, and any person they might see they used to hit them. They were kind of witches, and they could fly on the brooms.



Mermaids are lovely girls dressed in green and long golden hair. She was often seen combing her golden hair on a rock. Leipreachans sometimes marry mermaids, because of their beauty.She can swim and has a tail like a fish. She cannot talk, but she can make signs with her hands, and some people understand her.

4701741/4697825/4714160.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4701741/4697825/4714160.text:
Stories of Giants and Warriors 21.12.'38Long ago there lived a giant at Kesh and another one at Geevagh. The two giants were enemies. The giant in Geevagh took up a rock 20 ton weight to throw at the giant in Kesh. When the giant was throwing it slipped out of his hand and fell a Highwood. There is supposed to be gold under this rock. He took the second rock and threw it and it fell at Kesh and killed the other giant.Once there ived three witches at Kesh. Fionn Mac Cumall and Oisin followed a badger into their cave. At the door the witches spun yearns of thread. Whoever touched the thread feel under a spell. Fionn and Oisin broke some of the threads and fell to the ground exhausted. The witches bound them and carried them away into the darkness. Other Fenians followed in search of them and they were also seized by the spell. At last all the company were captured only Goll Mac Morna who was far on the hill side. Thehounds knew that something was wrong. They stayed outside the cave barking for their masters. Goll heard them
(continues on next page)

4701765/4700855/4724129.title: Giants
4701765/4700855/4724129.text:
GiantsThe following is a story about two giants. One who lived in Munster and the other in Connacht. The one who lived in Munster was a very strong man and said he was able to kill every giant that ever lived. Once upon a time the giant in Connacht asked the giant in Munster to come to his house and that they would fight and  they would see who was the stronger. So the latter told him he would go next day. When the giant told his wife that the Muster giant was to come next day to fight him, she got very frightened and said to him, "perhaps he will kill you." So she put him into the cradle and told him to stay there until the would go. It was not long till the giant came. He asked the other man's wife where her husband was and she told him that he was gone out working and that they would not be able to fight that day. So the latter asked his dinner, and the woman told him to go out to where the herd was.
(continues on next page)

4701756/4699791/4724661.title: A Giant
4701756/4699791/4724661.text:
12Many years ago Joe Ferguson was going up his own hill. It was just getting dark. He was counting his cattle when a big giant walked by him and he struck the cattle with a stick. He caught Joe by the shoulder, and he asked him what had taken him out that time and that time of the night. Joe said he was looking at cattle. The giant put a rope round Joe, but he did not want to go.The giant threw him up on his back and carried him to the Owenbeg. Here he threw him in. John Davey was near by. He heard Joe shouting and roaring. He came to where Joe was.  He asked him who he was. Joe told him. John pulled him out and asked him what happened Joe told him the
(continues on next page)

4701761/4700426/4726131.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4701761/4700426/4726131.text:
Once there was a traitor named Glas whome Fionn sent into exile. He went to the king of world and offered him knowledge of the harbour of Ireland and told him to come and capture it. Fionn got word that the king of the world had sailed and he called the seven batalions to arms and also the seven reserves.He hurried watch-men forth to every headland. On the round hill over the white strand, a youth names Conm Crither was put on guard. He lay down to rest and the scent of the grass cast a haziness upon him and he fell into a deep restfull sleep.He was awakened by the crashing of keels upon shingle and he looked down in alarm and saw hundreds of glittering shining sheilds
(continues on next page)

4701768/4701195/4726255.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4701768/4701195/4726255.text:
Once upon a time there lived two giants. One of them lived in the caves of Keash and the other in Bacah, near Charlestown. There two giants were opposed to one another and one day it was decided that they should fight between themselves. On the specified each of them took up a rock and flung it towards the other and it happened that both rocks clashed together at Doon which is approximately ten miles from Keash hill. These rocks can still be seen and they stand between six and seven feet over the ground and it
(continues on next page)

4706330/4703275/4726279.title: Giants
4706330/4703275/4726279.text:
Giants are very tall men. Somepeople say that they have two heads.Once upon a time there lived a tailor. One day he was eating his dinner, and a crowd of flies gathered on his ford. He hit them and killed seven. He made a belt, and wrote on it. "killed seven with one blow".He went to the wood he carried a piece of cheese and when he went the yard he met a hen and he took her also. He met a giant, and the giant got astonished at the writing on the belt.The giant threw a stone up in...
(continues on next page)

4713233/4709759/4726332.title: Lore of Certain Days
4713233/4709759/4726332.text:
(continued from previous page)
in animals



In the olden times, there lived a giant in a fort near my house. He is buried in a field near-by. The fort where he lived is semi-circular in shape. There is a stone at the side of the fort which bares the print of two human eyes. The giant is buried in a field near the fort. There were two crosses over the grave, but a priest ordered them to be taken down as it was no harm, and he took them away with him. There is an old-time cookings place near the grave.

4713243/4710955/4726768.title: Old Houses
4713243/4710955/4726768.text:
(continued from previous page)
candles themselves with the tallow of the cow's fat. They also had dips for giving light. These were made by dipping a splinter in a crock of melted tallow and letting it cool.



Long ago a giant lived near Rathmore at a place called [?] arrigaline. He was a very huge giant. People say that it was this giant threw the stones from the top of the two paps. These stones are very big stones and signs of the five fingers are to be seen on them. Those giants used to fight against one another. Once upon a time a Scottish giant challenged the world to get a man to fight him. An Irish giant said he would fight him, and the Scottish giant came over to Ireland to fight the Irish giant. The Scottish giant was defeated and in his hurry to get away the Irish giant tore up a big portion of earth and hurled it after him, and it fell into the sea, and it formed Ireland. A large lake was formed where he tore up the earth.One upon a time a giant met a little tailor and
(continues on next page)

4701681/4692396/4726973.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4701681/4692396/4726973.text:
One time there lived a great giant whose name was Balor of the Evil Eye. This man was also a great warrior. He had one eye in the middle of his forehead and another at the back of his head, so that he could see both back and front at the same time. With the eye in the middle of his forehead he could kill a person by merely looking at him. He always kept this eye covered except when he went to battle. One one occasion he fought a great battle. He took the cover off his eye, and by looking straight at his enemies he killed all of them. At length one of his enemies killed him. A number of people went over to see his body, but as many as went over were killed instantly by the evil eye.
(continues on next page)

4701762/4700652/4727079.title: Old Graveyards
4701762/4700652/4727079.text:
Toomour churchyard is now disused.  Knockbrack and Templevanny are square in shape.  Templevanny slopes towards the West, Knockbrack towards the East.Marie Burns,Knockalough,Keash.



Giants and Warriors - continuedThere are a number of stories concerning giants in this locality.  The following story, rather pointless, was told to me by my father.Once upon a time a man was building a house.  There were seven giants living at the time in the neighbourhood.  All that the man built during the day the giants came and demolished it by night.  The man didn't know what to do until one day a little man came to him and said, "I will stop the giants from throwing down your house."  That
(continues on next page)

4701762/4700661/4727139.title: Giants and Warriors
4701762/4700661/4727139.text:
There is a hill in this locality called Keash Hill. Caves at the back of this hill are still pointed out as places where giants lived. Nearby there is a hollow with a flag flooring which is called the "Giants' Table" and likely it is here they cooked and eat their food.Running parallel to this hill and at the back of it is a place called "Dun Ui Bhéara" where the Cailleach Bhéara is supposed to have lived.Old people tell stories of a fight between the Cailleach Béara and one of the giants. He stood on the summit of the hill and fired stones down at her. She lifted stones and earth and fired them up at him. The stones that reached the top of the hill form a "cairn" which is still to be seen. The place from which
(continues on next page)

4701769/4701304/4727175.title: Giant Story
4701769/4701304/4727175.text:
Once there lived on Keath hill two giants andthey were the biggest ever seen. One day theywere sitting on the hillside. One of them tookup a few small stones and began playingJack-stones, The other man saw a big rockand it weighed 23 tones and he said to the other man "Would you play with thatstone" and he said he would not. The gianttook the rock and sent it 13 miles, The stoneis three miles outside Ballaghadereen.



There is a story told about two men of theMcLoughlins that whent across the lake in a boatto Killaraght to look at cattle they had grazing.When they came to the shore to go home theirboat was gone and as there was no bridge acrossthe lake at Cuppanagh they had to walk aroundthe shore to a passage where Allens in to-day.They went up the avenue and when they came out on the gate and turned for home a big
(continues on next page)

4701769/4701308/4727201.title: A Fairy Story
4701769/4701308/4727201.text:
Once a man named Tom Scanlon was goingthrough a bog in Taverane at a very late hour.Suddenly he saw two small men with red jacketsand one of them asked him to dance but he saidhe did not know how to dance but even if he didhe could not dance in the bog. One of them stoopeddown and scraped the ground with his finger and a flag came up. After a while dancing the menasked him to play the flute. He was a very badplayer but when they asked him to play a tune hewas able to play it and before long he was a greatplayer and dancer. Then they said they would leavehim home and just as he was about to tell themgo they had disappeared.



Once upon a time two giants lived on Keashhill. One day they stared fighting and one of theGiants left his hand on the rock to jump it and hekilled the Giant. He left the impression of his handin the rock and ever since it is called the Giants
(continues on next page)

4701682/4692440/4727491.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4701682/4692440/4727491.text:
Stories of Giants and WarriorsThere was an old woman who lived long ago and who had one son. When he was twenty-one years he was a big giant and he sent his mother to the town to bring him a stick, so that he might go and earn his living. She went and brought two ton of iron home in a stick and when he put it to his knee he broke it. She went back again and brought home five tons in a stick. He put it to his knee and bent it, but he said it would do. Then he went away to earn his living.One day he came to a king's house and the king said he would keep him to mind the cows during the day. He showed him his room and his bed where he was to sleep. Next morning the king showed him cows that he was to mind, but he told him not to go near the giants' field.When the king was gone he broke a gap into the giants' field and allowed the cows in. Then he climbed to a big tree and hid himself in it. After a while a giant came up the field and shouted "Who let the cows into my field?" He saw the fellow in the tree and he said "Come down and I will kill you". "I will be down soon enough" said the other fellow, so he came down and killed the giant
(continues on next page)

4701772/4701519/4727989.title: Local Giants
4701772/4701519/4727989.text:
Long ago no giants love in our locality but I often heard of two giants, one of whom lived at coolevin and the other at croghan. Many a time the coolavin giant sent a challenge to the croghan one.At last he accepted it, and came to meet his enemy.  When the Coolavin giants mother seen the  their coming she got afraid and said to her son.You will never be able to fight him, he is twice your height and many times your strength.    I advise you hide.  So in he jumped to bed and covered himself with the bed clothes.  When the other other giant came in he said "Where is my enemy"  The woman said "he's not at home my friend.   "What is this, said ho, going over to the bed and putting down the clothes. Oh, that's the baby, said the woman
(continues on next page)

4713255/4711859/4743816.title: Gortdearg
4713255/4711859/4743816.text: There is a great big rock in the neighbourhood of Gortdearg with the sign of a giants hand on it.  One day it is said the giant was walking along the top of the paps and he hurled the rock into the air and it fell in a field about one hundred yards from the mountain.  It stuck five foot into the ground and the sign of the giants hand is still on it.

metadata.Teacher:: Bean Uí Spealáin, Máiréad Ní Laoghaire

4701726/4696499/4743981.title: Giants
4701726/4696499/4743981.text: Once a giant was standing on Born [?] hill which is near the school and another giant was standing on Keash hill, which is over ten miles away.  The giant on Born fired a stone at the other giant and it fell near Geevagh crossroads in the townland of Ballinashee.  It is a very high stone- about nine feet high.

4701691/4693084/4744216.title: Rocks
4701691/4693084/4744216.text: There are three rocks in Nead bog almost as big as little houses.One day when a giant was walking on the bog he stepped on them and his weight was so great that they sank down in the bog, only the tops of them are to be seen now.

4701692/4693237/4744513.title: A Giant
4701692/4693237/4744513.text: The old people of ages never wrote down the old stories but hear is one that is nearly forgotten.There was a giant in Tipperary who lived at Templemore on a mountain called Devil's Bit because he took a big bite out of the mountain. He carried it as far far as Cashel and dropped it there and from that day to this it is called the Rock of Cashel.It is to be seen anytime. Many people to see the Devil's Bit as it has fine scenery and many stories are told about it but they are nearly all forgotten.

4701692/4693238/4744519.title: Giants and Warriors
4701692/4693238/4744519.text:
There are many stories told about giants and Warriors who lived in mountains in former times. Once upon a time here was a giant who lived in the Ox mountains. he took up a lare rock and he wanted to throw it into the sea, but it fell a Killenduff and he was so angry that he came down with his sword and cut it in two, which may be seen to-day and it is known as the split rock.There were two Giants who lived in Ireland long ago, one was tall and the other small they lived together on the top of a hill. They stole a lot of animals from the people who lived about and they made the men bring them turf.There was a tiny hut and in it lived a widow and her son Seán. One day Seán saw the King "What will you give me," he asked. "Fifty cows a new house and the biggest farm in the land." Seán had only a mouse and a bee so they went to the giants house. The giants were in bed. They reached the top of the bed, the bouse bit one ear and the bee stung his nose. "Stop," said he, if you do that again I'll cut your head off. The mouse kept biting and the bee stinging till the giants jumped out of bed and they took up their big axes and cut the heads off other.
(continues on next page)

4723853/4719228/4744761.title: Stories of Giants or Warriors
4723853/4719228/4744761.text: There is only one giant of whom there is any mention in this district. His name was Edward Gull. From him this town land is named Edraguil. There are no stories of the type of person he was, where he lived etc. His memory lives because of the "Giants Grave" which is poinled out at the top of Edraguil Hill and because of the name of the town land.There are no accounts of local warriors. There is a townland Drom-fhionntan it is supposed that it derived its name from Fionn but there are no stories told to verify the supposition.

4701729/4696279/4759077.title: (no title)
4701729/4696279/4759077.text:
The man tried to pull the Mushroom and spent a long time at it but all was in vain.



In this locality there are stories told about giants. There is a grave in Drum and the people say that a giant is buried there. This grave is composed of a big flat stone supported by other smaller ones.On one occasion two giants were fighting. One of them mortally wounded the other who after a few hours died. Then he was buried in that grave. They put a flat stone on top of other smaller ones. Afterwards money was got in his house and they buried it in the same grave. Some time after a man heard there was gold in the grave and he went to find it. When he had the grave open there was a black cat minding it. Then he had to close the grave again.

4758478/4747397/4760100.title: The Windmill
4758478/4747397/4760100.text:
(continued from previous page)
seen near the mill.A man named Culligan, who died about 15 years ago, said that the Windmill had not been worked for eighty years before that.



Finn Mac Cumhaill and Scottish Giant were standing on Sliabh an Iarainn. The Scot challenged Finn to a stone flinging contest. They took two stones, Finn taking the heavier. He flung it from there to Elphin and it rested outside Feeneys door. It was standing high at first but is now lying on the "toe path". It is
(continues on next page)

4723857/4719625/4760359.title: Stories
4723857/4719625/4760359.text:
1. A giant once threw a stone five feet high from Carron Rock Mountain near Lisnaskea. The stone fell a short distance from Ballagh and is called Clough Big Stone. A man is supposed to have gone one night to steal a sheep. He tied the sheep with a rope to the stone and lay down to rest.Becoming entangled in the rope he was lifted up by the weight of the sheep, and when found he was dead with the rope round his neck.



2. During the celebration of the election results in Clones a man had indulged too freely & collapsed outside the gas works. One man seeing him carried him inside and placed hi before a huge furnace. In the early hours of the morning the man awoke. His rescuer asked him where he lived, and he said "while I was on earth I lived in Newbliss"Mr Jones - I'm sure there's a burglar downstairs, go down & see.Mr Bones - Keep Calm, let him do the worrying. He'll get nothing here but practice

4723857/4719625/4760360.title: Stories
4723857/4719625/4760360.text:
1. A giant once threw a stone five feet high from Carron Rock Mountain near Lisnaskea. The stone fell a short distance from Ballagh and is called Clough Big Stone. A man is supposed to have gone one night to steal a sheep. He tied the sheep with a rope to the stone and lay down to rest.Becoming entangled in the rope he was lifted up by the weight of the sheep, and when found he was dead with the rope round his neck.



2. During the celebration of the election results in Clones a man had indulged too freely & collapsed outside the gas works. One man seeing him carried him inside and placed hi before a huge furnace. In the early hours of the morning the man awoke. His rescuer asked him where he lived, and he said "while I was on earth I lived in Newbliss"Mr Jones - I'm sure there's a burglar downstairs, go down & see.Mr Bones - Keep Calm, let him do the worrying. He'll get nothing here but practice

4723815/4716036/4760423.title: Léim Gulsion
4723815/4716036/4760423.text: One upon a time there was a giant who stood on a hill in Dooagh and he stepped to the next hill in Cornalaragh where there was formerly an old fort. A white thorn bush grew on the rim of this fort, until the present day. If a branch was broken off this tree and was tied again with a rope it would be growing before a week.He then stepped from Cornalaragh Hill to Greaghwillian Hill and from that to Lisdrumturk fort. His bed was found in Lisdrumturk one hundred years ago. It was twelve feet long and six feet wide and there is one of the sides in Lisdrumturk fort to the present day.

4713237/4710167/4778458.title: (no title)
4713237/4710167/4778458.text: There is an old fort in Pat Leary's land in Gullane. In the middle of it there is a big stone about eight feet high, and about five fet wide. There is an old stone ditch around it. The people around say that the danes were there long ago. They say too that a Giant from the Two Paps about ten miles away, threw the stone there. One morning an old woman saw a naked child leaving it and he crying and after a week he was seen coming back again. The  people around say too that music is often heard under the stone. On the stone there is the print of a man's fingers and toes. Children who died before Baptism were burried there.

4758477/4747345/4780507.title: Giants
4758477/4747345/4780507.text:
GiantsLong ago there were many giants in Ireland.Finn Mac Cumhaill was the greatest giant of them all.It is said that he was one day standing on Sliabh an Faraimh with a Scotch giant.The Scotch giant asked him to go throwing stones.They got a stone each the stone Finn had was the heavier.Finn threw the stone and it stopped in Elphin outside Feeney's door.It is now lying in the footpath and it is said if it is taken away that the town would be flooded on that account it is left where it is.The stone that the Scotch giant threw fell a quarter of a mile short
(continues on next page)

4742079/4733513/4782008.title: The Leipreachán
4742079/4733513/4782008.text:
(continued from previous page)
then said that he would but to mind that the dog would not bite him. As soon as he looked away the little man was gone. He thought as he went home that he heard all of the Clocracáns of the parish laughing at him.



Long ago when giants were living in Ireland there were two living near Kenmare. One lived at the north side of Roughty and the other at the south side of it.
