They were enemies and so one day they had a dispute. They giant on the north side threw a big lime stone at the giant in the south side and strange to say where it fell there is not another stone there like it.Then the other giant threw a big green
(continues on next page)

4758457/4746010/4782277.title: Giants
4758457/4746010/4782277.text:
(continued from previous page)
1. Giants were not so common in olden times. There were three old hags in Ceis and they were giants. It is said that a giant from Ceis carried a big rock from Ceis to our town land at Brislagh and it is to be seen there yet and it is called the 'Giant's Rock." It is left down in the slopes of a hill and to look up at it you would think it would tumble down the hill it is so big



2. There is a place in this district connected with a
(continues on next page)

4758594/4757597/4784372.title: Giants and Warriors
4758594/4757597/4784372.text:
There was once a Giant who lived in a house at the back of Mr Tom Greenan’s Quarry.The remains of the old house are to be seen yet, and a hundred years ago the walls and doorway were still standing. It is said that the door way was ten feet heigh and four feet wide.He was supposed to be nine feet, nine inches tall, and weighed fifty five stones.He was buried in the old graveyard beyond the rectory at Killeevan. His name was Seamus McCaffery.The stone steps at Killeevan School house door way are parts
(continues on next page)

4758594/4757599/4784375.title: Giants and Warriors
4758594/4757599/4784375.text: There was a giant in Scotland and a giant in Ireland, but the giant in Scotland was far bigger than the giant in Ireland. The giant of Scotland was far stronger. The two of them fell out and the giant of Scotland waded over the sea to Ireland to fight the Irish giant. The Irish giant overcome the other giant, and the Scottish giant (overcome) thought it better to run away home, so he ran back to the sea. The Irish giant was not fit to overtake him. he got a rock and flang it after, the Scottish giant and it formed the Isle of Man, and the cave left in Ireland formed Lough Neagh.

4758594/4757600/4784377.title: Giants and Warriors
4758594/4757600/4784377.text:
There are many old graves about the country supposed to be giants' graves. There is a giant's grave in one of Mr. Hamill's fields. There is a big stone near the top of the field where his head is supposed to be and there is a small hawthorn bush near the bottom of the field where his feet are. The stone and the bush are about twenty or twenty-two feet apart. Fairies are supposed to be seen dancing about the grave. The giant was supposed to be about two hundred years old when he died. There is the ruins of an old castle a few fields from where the giants is buried, In this castle he lived. There is only the entrance of the castle left now which is covered
(continues on next page)

4758594/4757602/4784379.title: Giants and Warriors
4758594/4757602/4784379.text: There is an old giant's grave up in Newbliss in one of Mr Duffy's fields.  My father used to live there on that farm long ago.  The giant was ten feet in height, and had his hair down his back.  He is supposed to be dead near a hundred years ago.  He lived in an old wooden hut by himself.  He was supposed to eat a stone of potatoes and a whole sheep for his dinner every day.

4758594/4757603/4784411.title: Giants and Warriors
4758594/4757603/4784411.text: There was a giant long ago who lived in Clones.He was called the Dwarf giant and it took boots a yard long to fit him.  His shoulders were so broad that he could not go through a door.He was very quiet and he did not care for fighting.There is a giants tombstone in McGuirks field and there is writing on it yet.

4713223/4709055/4813977.title: (no title)
4713223/4709055/4813977.text:
(continued from previous page)
then noticed that he moved from the chair and then vanished.When the boy was getting into bed a heavy weight fell on his legs, and they were swollen for weeks.He went to America afterwards, but did not tell the story until the night before he sailed.



subdivision of the townland of Kilmurry. Lord Raymond who lived in Kilmurry house, and in whose immediate property was Kilmurry Castle took 8 acres of land from each of the neighbouring tenants. Land thus grabbed constituted a new townland called Baile an Caisleáin,



Diarmuid Donn is supposed to be a giant who is buried on the top of Cnoc [?] a little mountain on the [?] side of Glountaune. The grave is covered with five flags one in the centre, two lying parallel to this
(continues on next page)

4713223/4709057/4814030.title: (no title)
4713223/4709057/4814030.text: A couple of hundred yards to the east of the old creamery on the Kilmurry Road, and on the Creamery side there is a huge stone about 2 feet wide standing up inside the fence.It looks like an old rough hewn headstone, but is supposed to have been pitched by Conán Maol from the the top of Crocán to this spot, a distance of about four miles.  He meant it to reach Slíab Mis but by mischance it fell in a spot from which it has never been removed.Mr Curtin maintains that a party of giants living in Sliab Mis had a quarrell with a party of giants living in Crocane, and that a giant in Sliab Mis threw the stone intending it to reach Crocane. It fell however five miles short of  its destination. (Sliab Mis a mountain in the west of Kerry is about 46 miles from Kilmurry,)

4723848/4718543/4814792.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4723848/4718543/4814792.text:
About four miles from here Fionn Mac Cubhal and his wife and their son lived in a house in Farney. Fionn was a very mighty giant. He had fought all the giants in Ireland. There was a very mighty giant living in Scotland. His name was Monover. Monover told Fionn he would come over and fight him. When Fionn saw Monover coming he got into the cradle and Fionn told his wife to say he was not there. When Monover came to the door Mrs. Mac Cubhal told him Fionn was not in.Mrs. Mac Cubhal said to Monover 'there's a wind on the door and if Fionn were here he would turn the house round.' Monover turned the house round. Monover and Mrs Mac Cubhal asked him in. He came in and he sat down beside the cradle and he put his hand over the cradle and Fionn bit off two of his fingers. Mrs. Mac Cubhal asked him if he would were hungry. She sent him out to where
(continues on next page)

4770034/4768234/4815289.title: Local Giants
4770034/4768234/4815289.text: There was one giant here namely Ned Delaney.  He was known as Red Ned because he was very dangerous.  He used to choke people with his thumb & small finger.  He was born in Trumera.  Everybody was afraid of him & the police could not overpower him.  One day he saw two people going to a fair (a) with pigs.  he demanded the pigs but the people would not give them so he choked them.  He was put in iron bars in the Asylum & they flogged him but he choked the warders.  He escaped afterwards through a drain pipe but died shortly afterwards

4742168/4741765/4815727.title: Story
4742168/4741765/4815727.text: Once upon a time in a cave on the top of a mountain in Cornwall, there lived a giant called Cormoran. If three tall men stood  one on the top of another, they would would be the height of this giant. He was so fat too that it would take some time to walk round him. Now at the foot of the hill, where the giant lived, were several farms. When the giant wanted a meal he walked down the hillside and robber the farmers.Sometimes he carried off half a dozen oxen and a dozen sheep at a time. The oxen he slung over his shoulders, and the sheep he tied round his waist. The poor farmers were almost ruined, when a brave boy, called Jack, the  son of one of them, determined to put an end to the giants visits. One dark night Jack dug a pit at the foot of a mountain. Across the mouth of the pit he laid sticks, and mud, and straw, till no one could know there was a pit beneath. Early the next morning Jack blew his cowhorn, and the giant woke with a start. "Who is disturbing me at this time of the day" he asked, and dressing quickly, he strode down the mountain-side. At the foot of it sat Jack on a big stone. The giant fell into the pit and was killed.

4770044/4768915/4818611.title: Giants
4770044/4768915/4818611.text:
There was a giant living in Ballinclea. He was huge and very strong. He used to sit on a spot on Mr Fingletons HIll, Ballinclea. It is always called the giants seat. It is a little depression about 3 feet deep beside a pond. When he sat down he was so heavy that the ground sank underneath him forming the seat.



There was a giant one time who got very hungry. He seized a man and took him to his cave. The man was kept in the cave for three days. Each morning he got a pot of stirabout to eat. He was always thinking of some plan to escape. He thought of one in the end. One morning he got a bag and instead of eating the
(continues on next page)

4770044/4768915/4818612.title: Giants
4770044/4768915/4818612.text:

It is a little depression about 3 feet deep beside a pond. When he sat down he was so heavy that the ground sank underneath him forming the seat.



There was a giant one time who got very hungry. He seized a man and took him to his cave. The man was kept in the cave for three days. Each morning he got a pot of stirabout to eat. He was always thinking of some plan to escape. He thought of one in the end. One morning he got a bag and instead of eating the
(continues on next page)

4742170/4741890/4822483.title: Folklore - The Local Patron Saint
4742170/4741890/4822483.text:
(continued from previous page)
One time when, in a quarrel with other priests he blew his breath on a candle it lit and any of the other priests present could not blow it out again. I do not know where Father Moore is buried.I got this folklore from my mother: -(Age 48 years) Mrs. TiernanSigned. E. Tiernan.Milltown, Droichead Nua, Co. Kildare.



About two hundred years ago there lived an old hag. She lived by herself in a little house under the bushes, and she could turn herself into a hare with her magic wand and run across the fields and suck the cows, and once when the farmer was coming for the cows he saw the hare and he set the dogs after her and as she was jumping in the window of her house the dogs caught her leg.The farmer was surprised and went in and there he saw a little old woman with her leg bleeding; and whatever happened, the farmer nor his dog were never seen again.I got my information from my mother; -Mrs. Mary Gorry (age 49 years)Hawkfield,Droichead Nua,Co, Kildare.Signed: - Teresa Gorry
4742170/4741890/4822483.school_info: School: Baile an Mhuilinn, An Droichead Nua

4798679/4789644/4922873.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4798679/4789644/4922873.text:
533Stories of Giants and WarriorsTomas Lardir was a giant who lived in Castlemore long ago. He was noted for his immense strength and feats of running, jumping, and stone throwing. One day he was invited to a party in Castlemore. As the banquet was on the people tried to kill him. They leaped on his back and shoulders. He shook them off like a cow would flick off a fly off her back with her tail. There was a large tree nearby and catching it he pulled it up by the roots and cast it at the people killing most of them. Then he strode off angrily and ever afterwards he was left in peace by the people.There was another giant who lived in Castlemore but the name of Liam. Liam was (was0 the tallest and thinnest man that ever lived in
(continues on next page)

4769975/4763580/4928937.title: Storms
4769975/4763580/4928937.text:
(continued from previous page)
they were covered up completely in the snow and alas the three perished. Three crosses mark the spot, when they met their tragic fate and the crossroads is now known as Hackets' Cross.



Ainm an duine a fuaireas an scéal sin uaidh: Sara RowanA seolaidh. Kilberry National School, Athy, Co KildareA aois. 50 yearsA ghairm beatha. Oide Scoile.Cár tógadh é agus cár chaith sé a shaoghal: 1) i mbeirt, Ath I, Co. Cille Dara.2) San aít chéadnaAinm an duine ó'r chuala sé an scéal:Séamus Ó'Riadháin (nach maireann).Cé méad bliadhain ó shoin: 40 yearsAois an duine eile fá'n tráth sin: 40 yearsAn áit a raibh an duine eile 'na chomhnuidhe: i mBeirt, Áth í, Co. Cille Dara.An data ar a scríobhadh an scéal san leabhar seo: 11th April, 1938.
(continues on next page)

4758551/4754146/4929610.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4758551/4754146/4929610.text:
There are no accounts of giants or warriors who had any connection with this district. There is a stone in Brownsford, about five miles from Inistioge and under it there is a giant buried There are stories told of giants who hurled rocks from place to place. A giant threw a rock from one peak of the Blackstairs mountains to another peak. No old hags lived in the district formerly.



A giant came up from Wexford to Inistioge one time to meet another giant to see which had the most power. On the way he went into a forge for a spark to light his pipe. The blacksmith put the spark on an anvil and gave it to him. When he was putting the spark into his pipe the blacksmith asked him was he as strong as that giant on the horse. He looked around and saw another giant on a horse and said, I am not nor ten like me." So he did not go to meet the other
(continues on next page)

4921574/4880946/4932305.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921574/4880946/4932305.text:
Once upon a time there was a giant living in a castle and he used to have a candle lighting, and whosoever would look at that candle would be dead before sunrise the next morning. A boy named Regan made up his mind to kill the giant and he went to the castle with a spear.He covered his eyes so that he would not look at the candle, and he climbed the rock and he gropped for the candle. When he left hands on it he threw it down into the lake near by, and the name of the lake was the Shannon. Then the giant came rushing towards him, but Regan struck him with the spear on the hand, but alas! the spear broke in two. The giant tore up a piece of rock and through it at the boy, and he took up a stone and he hit the giant on the foread and the giant fell dead. The boy lived about a hundred years ago. They fought against one another. There are stories told about giants who flung
(continues on next page)

4769998/4765333/4932454.title: (no title)
4769998/4765333/4932454.text:
(continued from previous page)
"Good night sir", he said louder."It's a poor and a pitiful case that a person wouldn't answer you at Christmas time" said he walking away.



There is a large stone in a place called Garron.  Garron is a place near Sheirke. A man named Sampson threw the stone here. The print of his fingers are on the stone. It is  nine feet in height, This big stone is called Moran's Rock.



Long ago a man was coming from a dance. He set out for home between twelve and one o' clock. He came to a rath and he saw a whit lady standing near by. He ran back and two other men put him past the woman, When he looked back  at the woman he saw it was only a white ass beside the rath.



One night a man was coming home from
(continues on next page)

4769998/4765333/4932456.title: (no title)
4769998/4765333/4932456.text:
(continued from previous page)
"Good night sir", he said louder."It's a poor and a pitiful case that a person wouldn't answer you at Christmas time" said he walking away.



There is a large stone in a place called Garron.  Garron is a place near Sheirke. A man named Sampson threw the stone here. The print of his fingers are on the stone. It is  nine feet in height, This big stone is called Moran's Rock.



Long ago a man was coming from a dance. He set out for home between twelve and one o' clock. He came to a rath and he saw a whit lady standing near by. He ran back and two other men put him past the woman, When he looked back  at the woman he saw it was only a white ass beside the rath.

4921957/4913206/4935051.title: Story about a Giant
4921957/4913206/4935051.text: Mary Lynch,Ballylin,Ardagh,Co. Limerick.Told by Mrs. James Dillane,Glenastar,Ardagh,Co. Limerick.Story About A Giant.I have been told a short little story about a giant.Convenient to my home there is situated Ballylin hill.  The top of this hill is very high, and it is said that a giant stood on it, and threw a big stone about three ton weight, down into Mr. Stephen Ambrose's field. Which is situated about one mile form the top of the black hill, and about a hundred yards form the village of Ardagh.The stone is still to be seen there, and the print of the giants five fingers are in it, also his feet, and the ferrule of his stick.The giant who lived behind Turn hill, jumped from the top of the hill down to Dunganville and the print of his foot can be seen today on a rock there.

4769999/4765491/4939007.title: (no title)
4769999/4765491/4939007.text:
Long ago there was a land league meeting in Borris-in Ossory. The soldiers came on horseback to stop the meeting.The priest went out along the road to meet them. He shook a piece of Palm before them. The soldiers could not get the horsed to pass that spot. They went pack and told their comrades that there was a little white man on the road and the horses would not pass him.



One time there lived a miller. He had a daughter named Narda. She had lovely silver hair growing down her back. One day she was picking flowers beside the river when her foot slipped and she fell in. Count Oleran was passing by on horseback and he dived in and got Narda out. Narda asked him where she was going he said he was going to the castle to kill the wicked giant there. Narda said "O Count Oleran he will kill you".
(continues on next page)

4811607/4801356/4939386.title: Fathaigh agus Cailleacha
4811607/4801356/4939386.text:
No account of any giant having ever frequented this locality. However, there is evidence of one of Fionn Mac Cumhail's famous feats.    On the way out to Dursey Sound, between the townland of Scriomóig & Gleann na Ráth is a long  deep gorge thro' which the main road passes. It is called Forthair Caol or Furkeel Gap but should not be confused with Furkale Harbour. Really they are part of the same "crack" across the peninsula & are connected by a ravine called Gabhann.     The hill on the Scriomóig side of the Furkale Gap is called Foisteán, because it rises
(continues on next page)

4723869/4720925/4941319.title: Giants and Warriors
4723869/4720925/4941319.text: There are two giants graves in this district. One is situated in the townland of Carnbane (about 1 1/2 miles from Smithboro). the other is situated in the townland of Killabura (about the same distance from Smithboro)These giants were supposed to be great warriors and could not be surpassed as athletes. The grave in Carnbane is maked by a cairn of stones and the one at Kiltalina is situated in the middle of a field, and trees grow around + over it. In the centre there is a raised part, oblong in shape, and the giant is supposed to be buried directly underneath

4742060/4731814/4942075.title: A Story
4742060/4731814/4942075.text:
There was  a giant who lived in a hut on a hill. He stole hens and other things. The men had to bring him turf and the women had to bake him bread. He never gave the people any peace. The king wanted to get rid of him. He sent out warriors to control him. But the giant killed every one of them. The king was angry at this. Then the giant died.



There were two giants that lived in a wee house. There was a widow living beside them. They killed all the people. The widow had a son and he had a pet mouse and a pet bee. They went up to the king and asked him what would he give them if they killed the giants. The king said that he would give them a farm of land and fifty cows. The boy said that he would do it. So they went to kill the giants. When
(continues on next page)

4723844/4718168/4942589.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4723844/4718168/4942589.text: On Mullyash Mountain there is a large stone about 4 ft by 12. On this large stone there is the foot print of a giant.The mark of the foot is still to be seen. Some people say that there is a giant buried near spot. The town land of Lurganearly gets its name from this mark - Lorg an Iarla the foot print of the Earl.

4723844/4718169/4942597.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4723844/4718169/4942597.text: Long years ago there used to live in this Country, big men called Giants. They were very powerful and strong. There is a story told about a very large stone that is on top of a mountain at Warrenpoint. A giant was supposed to have stood in O'meath and thrown the stone over to Cloughmore Mountain.

4921983/4915355/4943393.title: Why Cratloe (Abbeyfeale) was so Called
4921983/4915355/4943393.text: Two mighty giants had a fight long ago on the top of the hill. After a fierce fight one was killed and his body lay on the hill which is called Cratloe ever since and his legs reached down to the Gale river to the place which is called Lurga.
4921983/4915355/4943393.school_info: School: Cnoc Uí Choileáin, Mainistir na Féile

4921990/4915897/4946021.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921990/4915897/4946021.text: There were two giants living in Co. Limk long ago.  One lived on the Clare side of the Shannon and the other on Limerick.  The Clare giant made up his mind to kill the Limerick giant.  When the Limerick heard this he went into the cradle.  The Clare giant came and asked for him.  The servants told him that he was out but his son was in the cradle.  When the Clare giant saw the size of his son he said to himself that his father must be a terrible size and he fled home as quick as he could.

4921674/4889177/4947362.title: An Fathach ó Éirinn
4921674/4889177/4947362.text:
Bhé Pádruig Mac Coitir an fear ab' airde dar mháir sa tír seo riamh. I gCionn t-Sáile a rugadh é sa bhliadhain 1760. I dtosac a shaoghail bhí sé ar nós aon bhuachalla eile. Ach nuair a bhí sé timceall seacht mbliadhna deag d'aois tháinig athrú air. An t-am san chuireadh ag obair é mar phríntíseac ag saor cloice. Tamall 'na dhiaidh sin buaileadh breoidhthe é. An fiabhras a tháinig air. An fhaid is a bhí se 'na luighe d'fhás sé cómh mór san gurb éigin an plannc a bhí ag cos na leabhthan adhmaid do ghearradh cun slighe do dhéanamh dá chosaibh. Do bhí sé ag fás leis go dtí go raibh ocht dtroighte is seacht n-orlaigh aoirde ann agus é in aois a naoi mbliadhna déag. Is mó eachtra greannmhar atá i mbéalabh na ndaoine fós i dtaobh an Fhir Mhoir iongantaigh seo, mar shompla   Ag gabhail tré lár Sráide an Mhargaidh do, dfhéadfadh sé cimilt leis na tigthe ar gach taobh de gan aon duadh ach a dhá láimh do shíneadh amach uaidh, bhí sé com mhór leathan san. Uair éigin eile thagadh sgannradh ar an bhfear bhfaire san oidhche, nuair a chífeadh sé an fathach agus
(continues on next page)
4921674/4889177/4947362.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire, Ceann tSáile

4922086/4851089/4948501.title: Stories of the Holy Family
4922086/4851089/4948501.text:
(continued from previous page)
and immediately the sores vanished. Another story: When Our Lord and the B. Virgin were on this earth. One day they were passing through a field, and the men were setting seeds next day, a number of soldiers were looking for them and they asked the men if they had seen them. They told the soldiers that they had and the soldiers proceeded until they came to crossroads. Here they were puzzled which road to take. Then a wren came along and hopped about the road Our Lord and the B. Virgin had taken. Then the soldiers followed on but Our Lord avoided because it wasn't the time for Him to die yet.



Long ago, near the village of Nicker Pallasgreene there lived a giant, it is said he was nine feet high and five feet wide. He had his Castle on Hill of Nicker and there is some of it to be seen yet. Just a few stones on top of one another, but it is said it is the exact spot where the castle was once situated. The giant was very ugly and it is said that he was married to a woman as ugly as himself.
(continues on next page)

4922001/4917001/4950373.title: (no title)
4922001/4917001/4950373.text: Tradition tells that there once lived three giants in Bruree castle. One day a Tipperary giant came to challenge them and when they saw him coming two of them concealed themselves. The third pretended he was a very old man. The strange giant enquired what food they generally ate. The old man prepared a cake put a griddle into the middle of it, baked it and gave it to the giant to eat. He then asked what exercise they usually had and he said they bent their backs and received three strokes of a sledge every day. The giant asked to give him three strokes the same, and he killed him at the second one.

4742123/4738093/4951220.text:

Fathaigh:Deireann na sean-daoine go raibh fathach nó gur ghaibh sé treó fadó agus taisbeántar rian coise leis i bpáirc Liam Uí Mathghamhna fé láthair agus fós i bpáirc Mhichíl Mhic Cárthaigh. 4758504/4749501/4951463.title: A Fairy Fort
4758504/4749501/4951463.text:
(continued from previous page)
hole, he saw a little man, about one foot hight, with a red light following Neil. It is said that when the light fell on Neil he got blinded and slipped into the river. On some nights of the year a light is seen there. It goes around the rath three times and then disappears.



There is a flat stone on the side of the road in Shanbough (Sean-Both) which is known as the blessed stone. Shanbough is in this parish about a couple of miles from New Ross on the road to Mullinavat.Long ago there was a giant, who was a saint, leaping from Tory Hill to Brandon. When the was passing over the stone he fell to the ground. One of his feet rested on the stone. Being so heavy, his foot-print remained on the stone and is still to be seen. There is always water in the hollow of the stone. People bathe sores or cuts in the water and are cured.

4758506/4749863/4953231.title: The Old Graveyards
4758506/4749863/4953231.text:
(continued from previous page)
around the graveyard, in the townland of Farrentemple, also.



There is an old legend of an event which happened some years ago concerning a giant, who spent some time around Brandon Hill and Mount Leinster. After viewing the hills fairly well, he decided he would be able to throw a stone from hill to hill, so he climbed up to Mount Leinster, as it was higher than Brandon. He caught a stone in his hand, and, with one mighty swing, he let go. The stone slipped from his hand and fell in a field in Ballyogan, about a mile and a half from Brandon Hill, and is there still, and it is called "The Giant's Stone" ever since.



The The Rower village there is an old graveyard which is the burial place of The Rower people. It is there that the famous William Shea is buried. His monument is still to be seen there. In the graveyard there is a
(continues on next page)

4758509/4750268/4953444.title: Story
4758509/4750268/4953444.text: In a field on Long's farm in the Townland of Coolmeen, there are three very huge stones equally even in size and shape. These stones are believed to have been trown by three giants from a place near Harristown for a bet. The three giants threw the stones in a field near Coolmeen and the stones are standing near each other and are wedge shaped.In late years two of the stones were broken down and put in the wall but one of the stones is still to be seen and I am sure will remain there for many years.some people say one of the giants is buried in Leacanscail in the townland of Harristown.

4758516/4750719/4955116.title: The Blessed Virgin and the Corn
4758516/4750719/4955116.text:
(continued from previous page)
His mill was never empty until the crops of wheat grew in abundance and then he had plenty to grind, so the Blessed Virgin ended the famine.



One  time there lived a giant in Sliabnamaon. One evening he went out to try his strenth at trowing stones. Two of his big rocks landed in Balllintee there is writing on the rocks and it is said no one can read it.

4758521/4751171/4955891.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4758521/4751171/4955891.text: "Loughnascail" is situated in Kilmogue. It consists of two big stones standing up which are fifty feet high and across these two is a flag which is supposed to be twenty tons weight.It is said that it was a giant who lifted the flag up on the two high ones. The priests used to hide and say Mass there during the Penal Days. It is covered over with ivy now. It is situated about four fields from farmer's house but you could see it from the road. It is partly on a slope and the flag is only barely reaching the big ones across. Many people would be afraid to go under the flag for fear it might fall on them.

4758521/4751172/4955905.title: Giants and Warriors
4758521/4751172/4955905.text:
Once upon a time a giant was on the top of Tory Hill and he had a stone in his hand. He meant to throw the stone to Slieve-na-mban but it slipped off his little finger and it landed in a field in Ballynooney, which belongs to Mr. John Cashin. The stone is 12 feet high and it is said that it is as many feet down in the ground.Once upon a time a man lived in Inistiogue. He used to rob money and other things from the rich and give it to the poor. When the police found out this they were trying to catch him but when he heard this he turned the horse's shoes back to front and if he went in a northerly direction the shoe
(continues on next page)

4758521/4751174/4955906.title: Giants and Warriors
4758521/4751174/4955906.text:
In Listrolin, Mullinavat, there lived a great warrior named Drolan. One day himself and a great crowd of his soldiers were walking in the lane which is called "Sean eaglais" and the heat was so great that he fell in the land and died. He was buried there and a great stone was placed over his grave. It is not know where the stone came from but it is supposed to have come from a foreign country. It is standing about five feet high over the grave. LIstrolin got its name from this great warrior "Drolan". About eight months ago the grave was opened and when the people had it dug they found the head of the warrior and many other bits of bones. They also found gold and
(continues on next page)

4701658/4690653/4956771.title: Cnocán na Cú
4701658/4690653/4956771.text:
One time a man on horseback was coming through Gortnarung and he had a bag of gold with him.When coming  near a hill he saw a black hound. After hiding the bag of gold the hound began to fight him. It is said that the hound is buried in that hill. So the hill is called Crucán na Cú



2 Long ago a great giant lived round here and he did wonderful deeds. He threw a monster stone from the mountain  down to Michael Clancy's field in Cliffoney about three  miles. The giant also jumped from where he threw  the stone and its is said that he is buried in Andrew McGowan's field



3 In Andrew McGowan's field in Rasberry Hill there is as graveyard  There are headstones in it and on them are letters but in is very hard to make the letters out. My father told me these stories. Thomas Coen, Raspberry Hill, Grange , Sligo

4922129/4854804/5009878.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4922129/4854804/5009878.text:
Once upon a time there was a poor woman who lived near to a wood.  One night herself and her husband were talking together and her husband said to send the children to the wood and leave them there.  The next morning they took the children to the wood and left them there.  When the boys saw that they were alone one of them said he would take them to some place where they would be able to get food and lodging.  When they came to the house a woman opened the door and gave them food and then put them to bed.  When the giant came home he said that there was children in the house, one of the boys sneezed and the giant made up his mind to kill them.  When one of the boys heard this he got out of the bed and took the nightcaps
(continues on next page)
4922129/4854804/5009878.school_info: School: An Clochar, Buirgheas Uí Chatháin

4922057/4848227/5010056.title: Giants
4922057/4848227/5010056.text: There is a story told in Aherlow that a great giant stood on a hill nearby and threw a very large rock meaning it to go to the top of the Galtees.  It fell on the side of the mountain.  He followed it with his sword, and split it in two.It is to be seen at the present day and is called the Giant's Rock.

4922062/4848927/5010225.title: (no title)
4922062/4848927/5010225.school_info: School: Gleann na gCreabhar (Anglesboro), Baile Mhistéala

4922138/4855981/5011445.title: An Old Song
4922138/4855981/5011445.text:
(continued from previous page)
Connemara.It was composed by Mr. Ryan of Bansha.



There was a giant by the name of Michael Mc Cormac.  He lived in Rathenny years ago he was a very strong man.  He was over six feet high.  One day he was in Nenagh and there was a faction fight going on.  He went into some yard and he brought out the body of an asses car and he made peace.  One morning he was going to Templemore fair with a big load of pigs.  It froze very hard the night before.  The roads were very slippery.  He was going up a steep hill and the horse was not able to take it up the hill.  He took the horse from under the car and took the load up the hill himself. He was an old man when he died and he was buried in Cullenwain.
(continues on next page)

4770008/4766537/5012802.title: (no title)
4770008/4766537/5012802.text:
In olden times the people said there was a giant named Billie Grant who lived in a hut on the top of a hill in Coolowley, and every night he lit a fire on the top of the hill and any one that looked at the fire took a fit of sneezing and died.



There is a weed called hounds tongue for rheumatism. Garlic is supposed to cure asthma.

4770008/4766540/5012869.title: Cures
4770008/4766540/5012869.text:
(continued from previous page)
them on the road, and the first to pick it up will get the warts.



There is a big rock on Garron Hill called Moran's Rock with the marks of arms and fingers on it. There is an old story told of a giant who is supposed to have thrown the rock from the top of the Devil's Bit Mountain to the hill.



At about a hundred yards from my home, there stands the ruins of an old castle. It is in ruins for the past sixty years. My Uncle was up in it often. There was a false step in the stairs of it, which if a robber stepped on would go from under him and he would be killed. Everyone going up the
(continues on next page)

4758540/4752939/5014126.title: A Story about a Witch
4758540/4752939/5014126.text:
(continued from previous page)
of the candle he caught it and threw it into the depths below. The boy was near down when old Granna missed the candle. She ran out of her house very vexed but before she had time to do anything the boy leaped from where he was to earth. When old Granna saw that he was escaping she flung herself off the cliff and was killed below. The young boy went home satisfied because he had killed the witch that killed his father.



There lived a poor boy and his mother. A giant who lived around their place killed the boy's father.When the boy was big he went to seek his fortune. One night when he was passing by the Giant's Castle he knocked at the door and the maid came.The boy asked her to put him up for the night. The maid said she could not for there was a Giant living there. Then the boy said that she could put him in a press. The maid put him up for the night
(continues on next page)

4758526/4751838/5014146.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4758526/4751838/5014146.text:
A giant threw a rock from Sliabh na mban to Ballygown & it landed in Mr Conways field where it was to be seen up to about three years ago, when it was taken & broken as the field was being tilled.



There is a slope in a mountain near Sliabh an mban & it is said that a giant took the piece out of the mountain with his mouth & placed it in Cashel. Hence the Rock of Cashel.



A giant lived in Currahill Castle?



One evening in the month of Oct., two boys were coming home after a day's hunting. They had to pass the old castle at Castlemorris. Just as they were passing it, they heard the most awful sounds up in the sky. They were so frightened that they had to sit down. The noise continued for a long timeWhen the boys were ready to go, out walked a big giant, as they thought, out of the castle,
(continues on next page)

4758534/4752451/5015131.title: Giants
4758534/4752451/5015131.text: Giants.Long ago there was supposed to be a Giant living in Grange. He said he could knock Bally Burr Castle from the top of Sliab na M-Ban with a stone.The stone is to be seen in the old road still. It has an oval shape. The is a hole in it and it is said that it was made by the Giant's little finger. There is supposed to be gold hidden under it. Some time ago it was dug but they could never get to the end of the stone.

4758546/4753523/5015573.title: A Giant Story
4758546/4753523/5015573.text: Once upon a time there was a giant standing on Brandon Hill and another giant standing on Blackstairs Mountain. They were arguing with one another and the giant on Brandon Hill took up a stone to throw it at the other giant. When he was in the act of throwing the stone it slipped out of his hand and landed on Andrew Murphy's ditch in Ballyogan. This stone is still to be seen and it has five sides on it. It is about one ton in weight.

4758547/4753682/5016308.title: A Giant Story
4758547/4753682/5016308.text:
A Giant Story.One time there was a giant and his name was Henry.  He had a horse and her name was Dun Dinah.  He always carried two pistols when ever he went to rob.  When on his journey to rob he was always heard singing:-"I'm Horrible Harry.  I gallop alongSinging a verse of my terrible songI want your money or else your life"I give no credit I want your cash.  One night he met a coach and the man said "What do you want" and he fired at the giant and he fell off the horse.  Another night he met a poet who was on his way to London.  This man was a very brave poet.  When he heard the cowardly giant he said "Did you
(continues on next page)
4758547/4753682/5016308.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire,  Gráig na Manach

4758547/4753685/5016313.title: A Giant Story
4758547/4753685/5016313.text:
A Giant StoryOnce upon a time two giants met in Graignamanagh.  They were great friends, so they went into a public house to have a drink.  They remained drinking for a long time, and late in the evening they quarreled.  Then they went home.  One of the giants on his way home, had to cross the Blackstair Mountains.  The other giant, living in a different direction, had to corss Brandon Hill Graignamanagh - As this giant was crossing Brandon Hill he saw his friend afar off on the Blackstair Mountains.  His friend looked and he saw him, and called him terrible names.  Then the row started again. The giant on Brandon hill, picked up a stone to throw at the other, but the stone slipped out of his hand and it fell on Andrew Murphy's farm Ballyogan.  The people who heard it fall, thought it was
(continues on next page)
4758547/4753685/5016313.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire,  Gráig na Manach

4770054/4769780/5017179.title: Folklore - Monuments
4770054/4769780/5017179.text:
There is a monument in Kilgorey. It is in honour of St. Lon who lived in Kilgorey. He used to live in a tent beside the church. Maggie Earl built this monument in Kilgorey.



There is a an old house at Mr Dogues Balliinakill. It is made of clay and stones. The chimney is and the floor made of clay. There is no windows in it.



There was a boy Jack was his name. His mother was a widow. Since his mother was a widow the were poor. One day Jack took the cow to the fair His mother told him to get the highest penny
(continues on next page)

4922178/4858762/5018999.title: Old Houses
4922178/4858762/5018999.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



There are one Giant in my district & his name is John Ryan the Giant he lived in Foilnamon. Borrisolgeih. Co Tipperary  This man lives on the top of a mountain.  There is a bog called after him it is called the Giants bog, Where all the people cut turf  There were warrior's long ago, and they used to fight each other.  And this Giant used to stand untop of a mountain and hurl a big stone down to the bottom.  They were huge big men that is why they are called Ginats.  They used Old[?] hag's live in my district long ago they used to live in cabens & caves
(continues on next page)

4922178/4858763/5019005.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4922178/4858763/5019005.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



It is not known of any Giant or warrior who had lived in my district long ago and it is not known of any river or lake or mountain which have been called after him.  Long ago in the time of the back and tan's there was a great fight at Ross. Parish. Borrisoleigh. and there were a good many people killed in the fight also and this scene is still pointed out it is not known of any giants or warrior who hurled a rock from place to place.Pupil. Harry Cummins Cronovone. Borrisoleigh. Co Tipperary.
(continues on next page)

4922178/4858764/5019016.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4922178/4858764/5019016.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Once upon a time there was a Giant living in the Parish of Borrisoleigh. He fought against a good many and he alway's won. It was said he used to kill every one he would see. He was a very strong man. They used old hag's live in his house and cave's in former times.



There was a giant in my district long ago. His name was John Ryan townsland Foilnamon Parish. Borrisoleigh, Co. Tipperary.
(continues on next page)

4922257/4864829/5021467.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4922257/4864829/5021467.text: The people of Ireland tell a lot of stories about Giants. About two miles from Clonmel is a big hill with a lot of bushes on it. It is a grave of a giant, he is supposed to have been buried there. It is called Giants Grave.
4922257/4864829/5021467.school_info: School: Sráid na Cille, Cathair Dhún Iascaigh

4922308/4868873/5021659.title: Old Houses
4922308/4868873/5021659.text:
(continued from previous page)
the bank of the river the floods used to come out of the river and fill the house. Their names were Ryans.The other old house was a very old thatched farm house, but they have a nice new cottage now. The old house was very bad looking inside. Now a farmer keeps hay in it.



There was once upon a time a very old giant and he came to Ireland. He said that he would do something awful. He carried a stone about with him wherever he went. This stone was about ten stones in weight. He met a man on the road to whom he told stories. A lot of people gathered round to hear the stories. He killed one of the men with the big stone, and then the other men killed him.

4922259/4865043/5022170.title: Stories of Giants
4922259/4865043/5022170.text:
There were several very strong men in my district a few generations ago. The best known of these was a man named O'Donoghue who lived very close to the old church yard in Ballybacon.As hurling matches played in Ardfinnan green at that time he used to strike the ball with the hurley and send it over the rock to the road leading to Ballybacon, which is a height of about one hundred and fifty feet.There was a tierce of porter tapped in at one of thos egames he raised it in his right hand and drank from the top.there was another in Kilgrogy named Linch he used to leap on a horse's back with a harrow on his shoulder, and bring it to where he wanted. He put a hose under a box of potatoes one day and he was unable to pull it out of a soft red field so he untackled the horse, and went under the load himself, and brought it home. He met a man he knew near the house, and he told him how the horse refused to pull the load, and sure, he said, "it was no wonder for it nearly gave myself enough to do."He was able to pick up a cart
(continues on next page)

4922308/4868896/5022230.title: A Holy Well
4922308/4868896/5022230.text:
(continued from previous page)
from "St Patricks Day to America" and he wouln'dt be boiled.This well is said to cure all kind's of sickness.



A giant was carrying a stone to build the castle in Ballinaclough, Golden, Co. Tipperary, Barony of Kilnamanagh Lower. He dropped the stone in Brian Shanahan's field, but he couldnt lift it on his shoulder again The stone is about a ton weight, so he had to leave it there. The colour of it is brownish - red. It is near the road.

4922263/4865383/5054144.title: Houses Long Ago
4922263/4865383/5054144.text:
(continued from previous page)
The furniture in the houses long ago was very plain and dull and scanty. The doors in the houses were only four feet high which was very inconvenient.



Giants, witches etc.Long ago there lived in Ireland a mighty giant and all over the world there was supposed to be no man equal to him. At the same time there was a giant in Scotland who thought himself better than the Irish giant.So a fight was arranged between them to see which of them was best. The fight was fought in Antrim. The Irish giant had the victory. The Scots giant fled towards the sea.The Irish man pulled up a big piece of earth and flung it after him and it formed an island where it fell in
(continues on next page)

4922263/4865384/5054149.title: Giants, Witches, etc
4922263/4865384/5054149.text:
(continued from previous page)
the sea and this island is called "The Isle of Man". And where the piece of earth was rooted up, filled with water, became a lake called "Lough Neagh"



Giants, witches et.Once upon a time there was a giant who used be going fighting with all robbers, thieves etc. His wife got dissatisfied to have him going among these kind of people and she went to a witch to know how she could make him stay at home. The witch told her to bring his shirt to her and that she would put a charm in it. His wife brought her the shirt. She put something in the shirt that when he put it on him it nearly roasted him alive. He got mad, he thought that
(continues on next page)

4922263/4865385/5054152.title: Giants, Witches etc.
4922263/4865385/5054152.text:
(continued from previous page)
it was his wife that did it and so that it could not be said that a woman killed him, he shot himself.



Giants witches etcThere was a giant called Giant Broden living in a cave in the left shoulder of Broe mountain and its door is concealed from mortal sight by magic power. "Broe" mountain is called "Broe" after this giant.There was once an old hag around here called Isable Gowdie. She was a great tormenter, she used cut the tips of her nails and of her hair and scatter them in the air and they would raise ugly sores and ulcers on the people she hated. One day she changed herself into a hare and was met by two dogs
(continues on next page)

4922263/4865386/5054162.title: Giants, Wiches, etc.
4922263/4865386/5054162.text:
(continued from previous page)
Giants, witches etc.who bit her leg off, She changed herself into a woman again. She hadonly one leg and died from the results.



Woman who used to cure Diseases.There lived in Knockperry, Co Tipperary a woman named Síle O Daly and she used cure horses and cattle and all the farmers stock and even the people.She had all herbs growing in her garden, such as "piosac buide", "croib dearg", "cairearbán", etc. She  was called "cailleac Síle". In those days any such woman was called "cailleac".

5008812/4958301/5056074.title: (no title)
5008812/4958301/5056074.text: Story supplied by James McGuire, TempletownStandard V regarding large stone on Templetown ShoreOn the shore at Templetown there is a large irregular rock much bigger than the surrounding rocks. It is situated on the short directly under the ruins of an old dwelling which was until about twenty eight years ago occupied by a family named Mackin. The sea ebbs completely around this stone at Templetown at Spring tides. Tradition has it that in olden days two giants, one at Templetown and the other on the hills over Rostrevor commenced throwing stones at each other - actually a distance of over ten miles. The Rostrevor giant flung the stone now at Templetown at the Templetown giant while the Templetown giant hurled the now famed Cloughmore stone at the Rostrevor giant from Templetown. Seamus states that this story was told to him by his grandfather and that the other old people in Templetown gave the same explanation to him for the prenence of the stone. There is no particular name on it.

4922334/4871131/5058102.title: Fathaigh
4922334/4871131/5058102.text:
Long ago there lived in a country place a husband and his wife who had two sons. Their names were Bill and Edward Salmon. They resembled each other so much that their parents did not know one from the other.They decided to call Bill out of his sleep and then to cut the top of one of his ears. He said that he would not allow that  to be done except by a better man than himself, or another night he would not spend under that roof.At once he set out taking his brother with him a part of the way. They reached a pond of spring water and in the centre grew a sheaf or rushes. He told Edward to come to the sheaf every morning and to pull a rush. While he would live a drop of water would fall from the rush and when he would be dead a drop of blood would fall.Then they parted and Bill went on until he came to a remote part of the country.At nightfall he came near the king's palace and he heard weeping and crying. Near by he met a woman washing clothes and he asked what
(continues on next page)

5008805/4957749/5070956.title: Stories of Giants
5008805/4957749/5070956.text:
Long ago there lived a giant in Omeath named Fionn Mac Cumhail. One time, he heard of a Scotch giant who was coming to Omeath to fight him. Now this Scotch giant was very powerful and Fionn was afraid he would not be able to fight him. He thought for a long time, and at length he hit upon a plan.He got into the cradle, and when the giant would come, he would take him for the baby. When the giant came, he asked where Fionn was. Fionn's wife said, he was not at home, and if he was, he would turn the house, as the wind was blowing, in the direction of the door. When the Scotch giant heard this, he turned the house himself.Then the giant noticed Fionn in the cradle and said, "that is a great baby", you have got. Has he any teeth, and he put his into Fionn's mouth, and Fionn nearly bit the top of the finger off him. Then the giant thought to himself what will Fionn be like. Then the giant said he was hungry. So Fionn's wife baked him a cake and put a piece of a griddle into  it. The giant took half of it and left the other half for the baby. Then he went to a stream to get a drink, but Fionn's wife,
(continues on next page)

4922297/4868069/5072306.title: Stories of Giant and Warriors
4922297/4868069/5072306.text: There is a story told that one day long ago when Fionn Mac Cumhaill was hunting on the Slieve-na-Muc Hills   he was attacked by a huge wild boar. He chased the animal along the top of these hills. Just near the Rock of Thorobh he made a stroke of his sword at the wild pig but missed him and hit the Rock instead and split in two. He then chased the boar through the Glen of Aherlow and killed him at a place called Rathdermot about a mile from the village of Bansha. It is said that the boar's grave can be seen there at the present day.

5008827/4959296/5072562.title: Old Houses
5008827/4959296/5072562.text:
(continued from previous page)
these lights were; candles, rush-kight, and dips.



There are not many giants and warriors connected with this district. There are stories about giants outside of this district. If we look over from our school to the mountains we can see Slieve Gullion where the Cailleach Bearra lived. The is a story about Fionn McCumhail. One day Fionn was out hunting in the woods with his two dogs Bran and Sgeolan. Fionn saw a deer and his two dogs went in pursuit after it until it led them to the top of Slieve Gullion.

5008818/4958804/5073140.title: Story of Giants
5008818/4958804/5073140.text: Long ago there were two giants whose names were Finn Toirneach and Ruscaire. Slieve Foy is called after Finn Toirneach. It is said that one day Finn Toirneach was roasting a boar on Slieve Foy. While he was roasting it he heard a shout and it seemed to come from the sky "I shall go down and kill you" said the voice. It was Ruscaire he heard shouting. Ruscaire was on Slieve Bán and Fin Toirneac was on Slieve Foy. They began to fight and it lasted for three days. First they fought with swords the next day with their arms and the third day Finn Toirneach threw a huge stone over to Slieve Bán and buried Ruscaire in the ground. This stone is to be seen on the County Down Mountains.
5008818/4958804/5073140.school_info: School: Páirc na Rian (C.), Rampark, Jenkinstown

4922365/4874580/5073947.title: Fathach
4922365/4874580/5073947.text:
Fathach.Do bhí fathach ina chomnuidhe ins an bparóiste seo agus do bhí se féin agus a bhean ag dul ó áit go h-ait. Tugtaí Diarmuid agus Gráine orta agus tá a leabaca le feiscint fós.Annsan d'éirig siad tuirseac ó bheith ag dul ó áit go h-áit agus annsan do chuireadhar da lich móire ag seasamh ar an dtalamh agus leach eile ós a cionn agus do cuadhar isteach ann.



Sprideanna.Do bhí fear ag dul go-dtí Liosdúnbheárna agus do
(continues on next page)

4922365/4874603/5074031.title: Seanscoileanna
4922365/4874603/5074031.text:
(continued from previous page)
d'fhoghluim thosuigh se ag gol mar dh'eadh. Nuair d'fhiafraigh de cad a bhí air deirfeadh an buachaill ''Ocras'' agus ní bheadh se ach taréis a bhricfeasta d'ith.Is ar slinne a bheadh siad ag sgríobhadh le sort luaidh a bailócaidís ins an bportach. Bhí cipín timcheall muineál sgoláire agus b'éigean dóibh poll do chuir air agus taréis seachtmhaine fuair sé buile ar gach poll a bheadh ar an gcipín. Bheadh cathaoir súgáin ag an maighistirí saidhbhre agus bheadh píosa crann nó carraig ag na maighistirí bochta.



Fathaigh.Ní raibh aon fathach timcheall na h-áite seo fadó ach do marbhuigheadh
(continues on next page)

4922365/4874620/5074135.title: Fathach
4922365/4874620/5074135.text: Bhí fathach ann uair amháín in a chómhnuide in uachais i gCillcorní agus ní raibh aighe ach súil mhór amháin agus bhí sé sin i lár a chinn. Bhí sé fiche tróig ar airde. Aon lá amhaín bhí tróidh aighe le fathach o Gaillimh?. Bhí an troidh ins an áit go bhfúil baile fearann Gréagáin anois. Bhí an fathach ó Cillcorní ag marbhú an fathaigh eile nuair a fuair an fear eile alán talmhan agus chaith sé é leis an fathach agus mháirbh sé é. An áit gur tóg sé an talmhan as, tugtear Gleann Gréagáin air agus sé Aill Bhéil an Tulaigh an cré a caith sé. Acht níl ann ach scéal.

5008849/4960973/5075521.title: An Old Story
5008849/4960973/5075521.text:
An Old Story, Once upon a time, there were two giants and they had a bet. They fired two stones up to Mullacurry, from Slive Gullín. The two giants came up to see which of them had fired the stone the furthest. One of the giants named Finn Mac Cool fired it the furthest and when the other giant saw that he was betting he lay down and died. He is buried in Stokes field in a mound. some of teh Stokes was putting lime in the field and he or her told someone they were going to mix the lime, the clay of the mound. He or she did, although they were warned not to mix it. When Stokes went for their cows there were three of them dead.Bernard Sands, Dromin Junction, Dunleer____________________A Hungary SpotOnce upon a time there was a girl going to a dance in Drumcondra. The dance was held untill 5 o'clock in the morning. The girl got nothing to eat since 7 o'clock in the evening. She nearly died with the hungr. When she went home she got 4 cups of tea and a loaf of bread. She never went to a dance



Once upon a time there was a girl going to a dance in Drumcondra. The dance was held untill 5 o'clock in the morning. The girl got nothing to eat since 7 o'clock in the evening. She nearly died with the hungr. When she went home she got 4 cups of tea and a loaf of bread. She never went to a dance
(continues on next page)

5008861/4961757/5076995.title: Giants
5008861/4961757/5076995.text:
Once upon a time two giants were fighting in the moat of Rath and one of them ran away for he was beaten and they other giant stooped and lifted up a big stone and hurled it after him and it landed the far side of Dublin and it is said he could go seven miles with every step he took, and where he lifted the stone there is a well now.There are two big stones up at Termonfeckion and some say a giant threw them over from Scotland and others say it was a cow and a calf coming over to drown Ireland with her milk and they were turned into stone and
(continues on next page)

5008861/4961758/5076996.title: Giants
5008861/4961758/5076996.text:
(continued from previous page)
they are called the Cow and the Calf.



Long ago, there was a giant buried on top top of Michael Meehan's Moat. It is said that he threw a stone from Dundalk to Drogheda, and that he could walk very fastI also heard from my G. Aunt that she heard a giant threw stones from Drogheda to Mullacury and they are to be seen yet.
(continues on next page)

5008861/4961759/5076997.title: Giants
5008861/4961759/5076997.text:
(continued from previous page)

Long ago there was a giant down at Cooley, and it is said that he threw a stone from Cooley to Joe Butterly's field and after a while he died so the rest of the giants him in a field near hand the __ road, and it is said that his legs reached across the road and the rest of another field.



I heard that a giant threw a stone from the - "Hill of Carne"

Long ago there was a giant down at Cooley, and it is said that he threw a stone from Cooley to Joe Butterly's field and after a while he died so the rest of the giants him in a field near hand the __ road, and it is said that his legs reached across the road and the rest of another field.



I heard that a giant threw a stone from the - "Hill of Carne"

5008861/4961760/5077000.title: Giants
5008861/4961760/5077000.text:
(continued from previous page)
in Carneystown and killed another giant on top of Sliab Gullion.I heard that a man named John Byrne met the fairies one night and they had a coffin with them and they made him carry the coffin from churchyard to churchyard all night and every churchyard they went to was full, and they all disappeared at daybreak, leaving the man in some churchyard and he did not know where he was.



There was a giant who threw a stone from Dundalk to Butterly moat.
(continues on next page)

5008861/4961761/5077001.text:
(continued from previous page)

There was a giant one time and he threw a stone from Drogheda to the Knockwood on the road to Grange Bellew and it is said that there was a giant walking through the wood and the stone struck him and killed him and people could'nt lift him and he was buried in the wood and the stone that killed him was put over him.Once upon a time there was another giant and he was walking through a churchyard and there was a grave made for someone that died and he was buried in it and it was in
(continues on next page)

5008861/4961763/5077002.title: Giants
5008861/4961763/5077002.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Once upon a time there was a giant who dressed himself with feathers and made wings of brown paper and stuck feathers on them and he went round to everybody and warned them not to shoot a big bird if they saw him flying around. Then he told them what he was going to do and the next day he got a ladder and climbed to the top of the house and let him self drop down and he fell on his head and broke his neck.Once upon a time there was a giant the far side of Dundalk and there was one this side of
(continues on next page)

5008861/4961764/5077004.title: Giants
5008861/4961764/5077004.text:
(continued from previous page)
it and they were trying to see who would shoot arrows the farthest so the one the far side shot it from the far side to Dublin and the one from this side threw into Carlingford Lough. There was once a giant the far side of Dundalk and he threw a stone from there to here.



A giant threw a stone onetime from Cooley to the Knockwood which is on the right hand side of the road that leads from Grange Bellew to the school. When the stone reached the
(continues on next page)

5008861/4961765/5077005.title: Giants
5008861/4961765/5077005.text:
(continued from previous page)
wood there was another giant walking through the wood and the stone struck him and killed him and the giant is buried under the stone now.



The giant that is buried in the big meadow threw a stone from the moat of Rath to Matthew's of Tullydonnell.There was a great battle between him and another giant, and he killed the other giant in the battle. After he had killed the other giant he fought another battle and was killed in it.All the giants buried in the
(continues on next page)

5008861/4961766/5077010.title: Giants
5008861/4961766/5077010.text:
(continued from previous page)
big meadow, and there was a stone put on the head of the Grave.



One night Hugh Fitzpatrick was coming home from Dysart and he heard fairies rattling cups in the wood along the road.Giants were very common in this district long ago. There are giants' graves in the woods and fields along the Dysart road and there are big stones over them.I never heard of giants fighting with men.
(continues on next page)

5008865/4962179/5078729.title: Giants
5008865/4962179/5078729.text: Giants     29. 6. 38In this district there was a giant named Fionn mac Cumaill. There is a well in Brownstown still called Tobar Finn. The people use the water of this well for cattle. Fionn mac Cumaill is supposed to be buried in a field on Fieldstown Hill called Lios Dub. His grave is known as Fionn's Grave.Anna Lambe    13 uearsRiverstownParish of MonasterboiceCo. Louth.

5008889/4964126/5079539.title: A Giant Stone
5008889/4964126/5079539.text:
About a mile from where I live there is a big stone about ten feet high and about nine feet broad. This stone belongs to Smiths of Piperstown. It is there a very long time and the people do not know when it came there but they all say that a giant threw it there, from Carlingford to this field. The tracks of his fingers are on it. There is a lot of names of people cut out on it but it is not easy to read.



No crows ever built in Cartown  wood because one time there was a priest who wanted to build a church in a  field Cartown and Mr. Chester the owner would not give him leave and the priest said "On that account no crows will ever build in Cartown wood and there will never be a rightful owner for Cartown.

5008889/4964126/5079540.title: A Giant Stone
5008889/4964126/5079540.text:

It is there a very long time and the people do not know when it came there but they all say that a giant threw it there, from Carlingford to this field. The tracks of his fingers are on it. There is a lot of names of people cut out on it but it is not easy to read.

5079720/4878834/5080035.title: (no title)
5079720/4878834/5080035.text: There was a man at one time who lived in Ireland and he was a great athlete and people from other countries came across to fight him. So this day a great giant came to fight him and beat him and then giant said he would not beat his brother and then the man put a penance on him to go up on the spire of a church and not to eat so much food that would go through the eye of a needle until he would come back and he went off and on his journey he met a small little man who asked to go with him and he did not want to consent to let him go at first but after a long time he consented and they were going until they met a little house and they went in from the night and she was telling them all about the giant's brother and the things they would have to fight which made them very lonely. The small little man got up early and went off and the first thing he met was a lake and then he met a ram and himself and the ram raced to a rock and the ram struck his head against it and he was killed. When the reached the giants brother's palace there was big gates before them and the little man gave them a kick and they opened when the giant heard the noise he rushed out but he found he could not move and the little man cut off his head and carried it to his brother and when his brother saw it he made off as fast as he could and never returned again.

5079720/4878894/5080260.title: Hidden Treasure
5079720/4878894/5080260.text:
“Once upon a time there was a man living in the west of Clare and his name was Mourishín Fodera and he dreamt three times that there was gold hidden under the bridge of Limerick city. He went early in the morning to Limerick and he spent three days looking for it. On the third day he met a man and the man asked him what he was looking for and he told him he dreamt that there was gold hidden there and the man told him to go home and look under a white thorn bush that was in the meadow in front of the house and he would get the gold there. He went home and got the gold.



Once upon a time there were two giants living in Kerry and one day the two of them came together to see which of them would put a stone the farthest and the stones fell up about Kilmihil, Co Clare and there is about six feet between the stones  and the stones are about six feet high and they are called "leagans" and there is a fort in the same field and it is called "fiana Leagán"

5079720/4878894/5080263.text:

He went home and got the gold.
