5044788/5038295/5082699.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044788/5038295/5082699.text:
Stories of giants and warriorsVery few stories are told of giants and warriors in the district. The nearest spot where they were supposed to be is Burren. Here we find a huge cromlech which was built to mark out the grave of the giant who was killed there. This is the way he was supposed to be killed.          Burren is a very rocky patch of land surrounded on all sides by lofty rags. It is also very wide. It is said two giants met here one day and they started to argue about their own strength. This continued until a puny creature crept from u dear a stone and agreed to settle this dispute.. He defied either of them to jump from the top of one mountain to the other across the width of Burren. This the two giants agrees to do.           One of them succeeded but the other crashed down a rock and was killed immediately. At once his comrade raised a heap of stones over his body and so formed the present cromloch. The other giant met his death there also in attempting to leap across a wide chasm which is still to be seen.On Slíabh Cuilceach there are very ancient monuments. One marks the spot
(continues on next page)

5044781/5037647/5083278.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044781/5037647/5083278.text: In the townland of Burren, about two miles north of Blacklion, Co. Cavan, there are two very high rocks, with a deep valley between them.The story is told that one day a giant was jumping across from one rock to the other, he jumped backwards and forwards several times but at last he fell into the valley and was killed. Since that, this place is known as the "Giant's Leap" and near the "Giant's Leap" are some very high rocks standing on their ends with one huge rock on top, this is where the giant was buried and is called the Giant's Grave.

5044781/5037648/5083280.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044781/5037648/5083280.text:
Long ago a giant lived in the townland of Bureen two miles from Blacklion, Co Cavan.One day the giant was jumping from one rock to the other, across a deep valley, and then he tried to jump backways, but he was not able, and he fell  into the valley and was killed. His grave is to be seen yet, and is called the "Giant's Grave". There are two graves beside the giants grave. They are called the "Lady's Grave" and the "Child's Grave". The giants wife is supposed to be buried in the 'Lady's Grave' and their child in the
(continues on next page)

5080332/4878974/5083609.title: (no title)
5080332/4878974/5083609.text: There is supposed to be a giant's grave on top of Knockerra Hill, in the farm now occupied by Mr Pat O'Shea. It has never been examined by experts. The name of the giant was said to be Faire and he used ro speak across to a giant who lived at Knockanore in Kerry, across the Shannon. They say Knockerra was really Cnoc Fhaire but there is no confirmation of the theory. Neither is there any proof of the correct derivation of the townland's name.

5044787/5038052/5083645.title: An Old Story
5044787/5038052/5083645.text: In Co Fermanagh there is a mountain called Binnaughlan. It is a lovely round mountain and in olden times a giant is said to have lived there.it is told that this giant threw a stone from the mountain into Lough Erne.When the stone fell it sank twenty feet into the water. It is also told about the same giant that he threw a stone from the moate of Cuilcagh to the top of Slieve Russell.

5044791/5038547/5084055.title: Giants and Warriors
5044791/5038547/5084055.text:
We have heard many stories about Giants and warriors of the past. Some of them are of Giants carrying stones from place to place. It is supposed that a Giant carried a stone to put over the grave of a great King. It is situated in Patrick Murrays field Kilnavart. There are two stones in John Foxes field Losehill one on top of another. The story is told that a Giant carried one under each arm to serve as a table and also to make a dwelling place for himself. The Leprechaun is known locally as one of "the good" or the Little Red man. He is supposed to be carting gold under the groundLong ago a man asked one of these little men to care his money or gold for him and to stay with it. (and) Ever since the Leprechaun is supposed to be  caring gold. The Leprechaun is supposed to be fixing shoes under a mushroom  You can hear the tick, tack of his hammer not much louder than the ticking of  a watch.His height is about six inches.He is dressed in a scarlet Jacket
(continues on next page)

5044796/5039276/5084102.title: Old Houses
5044796/5039276/5084102.text:
(continued from previous page)
Mrs M. Byrne. ( same address ).



Once upon a time a giant lived in a house. He was so big that his head was in a room, and the rest of his body was in a kitchen.On day, a boy named Jack, went into this giant's house by mistake, The giant said that he'd kill him if he wouldn't do what he'd tell him.The first job he told him to do, was to go to a wood, cut timber, and carry it on his back.
(continues on next page)

5044792/5038644/5084164.title: The Old Graveyards
5044792/5038644/5084164.text:
(continued from previous page)
Susan DolanCornacleighGlangevlilnCo Cavan Received from James DeLacy age 81MoneensauranGlangevlinCo Cavan



Stories of Giants and Warriors.Once upon a time there were two Giants in Glangevlin in Co. Cavan.  Their names were Sam and Billy.  They were as big as a house.  Some say that Sam used to go about from house to house where he would get plenty to eat.  There is an Ált mentioned after Billy.  It is so called because Billy used to go and stay there after he had his breakfast.  Sometimes they to fight amongst themselves.  There was a man going out the mountain to some town and he met Billy and he said to the man that he would hurl that big rock from the top of the mountain and he did hurl it and broke it into big stones and he hurled it down the mountain side.  In penal times priests used to go about hiding for fear of the Giant's and once there was a priest in this valley and Sam would kill him if he caught him saying Mass.  The priest said to Sam to go out the mountain
(continues on next page)

5044792/5038646/5084166.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044792/5038646/5084166.text:
Stories of Giants and WarriorsThere was an old woman and she reared a son he was twenty one years of age and she never asked him to do any work and she told him one day to go to the wood for a load of brosna, the boy got vexed with him and he told  him to not do that again so he hit it another kick and he tore it into pieces.  The boy hit the giant then and they fought away until they made hallows of the heights and heights of the hallows.  They tossed big trees and made little trees grow and closed spring wells up through rocks.  Then the boy knocked down the giant and when the giant was falling he knocked a clod from his foot and it hit an old woman who was spinning in the Eastern World and killed her.  He killed the Giant and then he came home and told his mother and she was very proud of him. He went to England after that and he earned a great deal of money.  There are accounts of giants who had connection with the district in olden times.  There was a giant in this district locally long ago and he put one huge stone on top of another huge stones and the track of the giants arm is in this stone.  This stone is called "the giants stone" and it is situated on the top of the Derrynananta mountain, in the parish of Glangevlin, Co Cavan.  He lived in a cave in the mountain.  The scenes of such encounters are still pointed
(continues on next page)

5044793/5038787/5084673.title: Old Poets
5044793/5038787/5084673.text:
(continued from previous page)
But the men of Glan this curse must stand; There bright and free for to think. The blessing comes from temperance and the curse that follows drink.A curse that is now raging in our country '02If you look up my records you'll find my statement trueVIISo come on ye men and women, from this open hearted GlanAnd pay attention to what I say and it will lead yo in the lightIf you uphold its [?] it will keep you in Gods sight.



Very few stories are told about Giants and warriors in this district. The nearest spot where they were supposed to be is Burren. Here we find a large cromlech which was built to mark out the grave of a who was killed there.This is the way he was supposed to be killed. Burren is a very rocky patch of land surrounded on all sides by lofty crags. It is also very wide. It  is said that two giants met there and began to argue about their own strength. This
(continues on next page)

5044794/5038908/5085217.title: Fathaigh agus Laochra
5044794/5038908/5085217.text:
Once upon a time there lived in Ireland a giant whose name was Oscar. He heard that there was another giant living and he made up his mind to visit him. When he reached the place there he found the giant himself and his mother sitting at the fire. As the Irish giant was pretty tired he said he would go to bed for a little while. "Alright" said the woman "I will prepare a place of rest for you." When the giant was gone to bed he listened to what the English giant and his mother would be talking about. He heard the woman telling the giant to get a sledge and to go to the room where the Irish giant was and give him three strokes of the sledge. When the giant heard this and he in bed he looked about to see would there be  anything in the bed but himself. He got an old block of wood and he put it into the bed and covered it. Then the English giant came into the room and gave the block three strokes and then went to the kitchen again. In the morning when the Irish giant got up the English giant said to him "Did you find anything last night?" "Yes I got three tiny strokes on the back" replied the Irish giant
(continues on next page)

metadata.Address: Garvalt Upper or Gub, Co. Cavan

5083770/5039677/5085402.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5083770/5039677/5085402.text:
Page 376Stories of Giants and Warriors.There is an old story of a Giant who lived in Aughrim. This monster's name was Bellconnell. It is said that this Giant went to war with another Giant who lived in Lisanover. The two Giants fought a great battle in Ballyheady and the fight ended in a win for Bellconnell, who when he killed the other monster ran home. He however was nearly killed himself. When the Lisanover Giant's Sisters' heard that their brother was killed, they followed up Bellconnell with aprons of stones. Bellconnell in the meantime had died and was buried on the little Island at Ballyconnell. That is how Ballyconnell got its name. When the Giant Woman heard that Bellconnell was dead they threw away they threw away their heap of stones on Ballyheady mountain and
(continues on next page)

5083770/5039678/5085407.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5083770/5039678/5085407.text:
(continued from previous page)
Page 377that is how the cairn of stones got there.



Giants.Old stories say there dwelt a giant in Ballyheady, by the name of "Conal, Finhal Dol. This man was 8 ft in in height and had only one arm and one eye. This Giant lived in the time of the Tuatha De Danann. He was in a feirce battle one day with Gobhair the Laidir. It is said that Conall put his rival to flight and as he was not able to catch up with him he took up a huge stone about 9 cwts weight and hurled it after his foe. We are told it hit him with such force it cut his head from his body.
(continues on next page)

5044845/5043835/5086606.title: Giants and Warriors
5044845/5043835/5086606.text:
There were Smiths in Mullamagavan who were great warriors, and they were called the Niall Cruahers, relations of the present Owen Smith.They fought a great battle and defeated thirty red coats in Mullamagavan rocks with "swords and daggers" in the year 1818.The picture of the sword and dagger is in Lower Lavey old graveyard on a tomb stone, but it is covered with moss now.These warriors lived in Lower Mullamagavan. They fought
(continues on next page)

5086840/4878586/5087535.title: Fathaigh agus Cailleacha
5086840/4878586/5087535.text:
Bhi fathach ann san t-sean aimsir agus bhi caislean aige. Gach duine a chonnaic se do mharbhuig sé é agus d'ith sé é. Bhi fear óg ag gabhail thar a dtig la agus do mharbhuig sé é. Do chuaidh a bhean go dti Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus dubhairt si leis an mnaoi dul go dti an cailin aimsire a bhi i dtig an fhathaigh agus a fhiafruighe di cathain a bheadh an fathach in a chodhladh. D'imtigh an bhean go dti tig an fhataig agus d'fhiafruig  sí de'n chailin aimsire cathain a bheadh sé in-a chodladh. Dubhairt sí leis an mnaoi go mbheadh an fathach ag dul a codhladh i gceann tamaill. Nuair a  bhi an fathach imthighthe a chodhladh thainig an bhean agus an fear eile agus do ghearradar ceann an fhathaig. An áit in-ar thuit an rud amach tugtar Clochan na bhFomorach air.Bi cailleacha annso fadó. Bhi fiacla cosamhail le bata suibhail acu. Dhein na daoine obair dhoibh mar bhi eagla ortha rompa agus
(continues on next page)
5086840/4878586/5087535.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire, Cill Chaoi

5070743/5058933/5092006.title: Short Stories
5070743/5058933/5092006.text: A giant lived on the top of Croghan and another on Knockaroe over four miles apart. They very often exchanged pipes!Saint Patrick came from Co. Tyrone into Mulrine's Bridge (about half a mile west of Lifford) and turned back when he heard of St. Colmcille being in Co. Donegal. The Danes made beer out of heather. The "Wee-Folk" were fallen angels. Those that fell on the earth were "wee-folk". Those that fell into the sea were mermaids. They were supposed to get back to heaven after a certain time and that is the reason they are not to be seen anymore. They need the top pickle of the corn to make meal.

5070789/5063813/5095863.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063813/5095863.text:
A long time ago when Finn was hunting on top of Murmod Hill. he saw a deer beside Mullagh. He threw a stone towards the deer and he hit it and killed it. The stone that he threw is beyond at Mullagh gates.



It is said that Fionn Mac Cool was fighting with a witch that had three heads and the witch fled and hid on Murmod Hill. Fionn followed her and he saw her running away. He lifted a rock a couple
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063814/5095868.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063814/5095868.text:
(continued from previous page)
of tones weight  which he called a pebble and threw it after her. That rock lands at the gates of Mullagh and is still to be seen yet.



The big island is supposed to contain the ruins of a castle where two sons of a chief were left in charge of a nurse for safety, during the early wars of Ireland. But this castle was attacked and they were put to death and an urn of gold was buried in the lake.

5070789/5063815/5095873.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063815/5095873.text:
There lived in Murmod a very famous giant known as Finn Mac Cool. He used to walk from Murmod to Mullagh in six steps. One day another giant challenged him to fight and he went over to Fionn's house and asked his wife what he does be doing. The wife brought the giant out in the garden and showed him a terribly big stone. And she told that Fionn throws that stone across the house and then runs round and catches it at the other side of the house before it hit ground. When the giant heard that he got afraid and ran away. A
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063816/5095878.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063816/5095878.text:
(continued from previous page)
few minutes later Fionn came and he saw the other giant running at Mullagh. Then he got the big stone and he threw it from Murmod to Mullagh where he killed the other giant.



Once lived a great Giant lived in a castle and he was very destructive and destroyed the crops on the people. Once a little boy set out to kill the giant bringing a pick, spade and shovel from his uncle's farm. When he came to the giant's gate he made
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063817/5095881.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063817/5095881.text:
(continued from previous page)
a hole, placed a big stone on the bottom and covered it with bushes and went in to where the giant was. He knocked hard at the door and ran away. The giant came out in a rage running down the path while the boy watched and he pounced on the hole and fell in and was killed. The boy went into his castle and got the money. The people were very glad to hear the news.



It is said that Finn
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063819/5095885.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063819/5095885.text:
(continued from previous page)
buried under it.



There is an old monument in a  field of Mrs. Connell's in the townland of Ballaghanea. There were two giants long ago and they began to fight. One killed the other and he buried him there. This grave goes under the name of the "Giant's Grave. There are two big stones standing up one at each end of the grave. They are about six feet over the clay and the same under it. There was a big flag lying
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063820/5095886.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063820/5095886.text:
(continued from previous page)
across those two stones. This flag was broken and put into the grave to fill it. There is a sloe bush growing at the head of the grave.



Fin  Mac Cool was buried in on the top of Murmod Hill. His thumb is as big as a man and his body is big also and where Fionn Mac Cool was is the highest on the hill. It is easy to know where his thumb is buried. There is a little height of sods along the ditch and
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063821/5095891.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063821/5095891.text:
(continued from previous page)
beside a house that is going to fall and this is on the top of Murmod Hill and where his body is buried there is a height and you can see the country all round.



There is a place in Ballaghanea called the giants grave. There is a large flag on the ground and some big stones round it but they are all nearly built in a ditch now. It is said that a great warrior was buried here but no one knows who he was.
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063822/5095892.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063822/5095892.text:
(continued from previous page)
There is a sloe-bush growing at the head of the grave.



There is a place called "Croc Foladh" in a field of Mrs Garrity in the townland of Ballaghanea. Some warrior hid a treasure of gold there and there was to be a life lost before it could be got. One time people began to look for it and they had a dog with them. The dog began to root the clay with his paws and he fell dead. That was to be the life
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063823/5095894.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063823/5095894.text:
(continued from previous page)
that was to be lost before it could be got. The people ran away and no one ever went to look for it since.



One day Fionn followed a witch across Murmod Hill but he could not catch her. Fionn got tired of following her and he lifted a big rock and threw it at  her.

5070789/5063824/5095898.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063824/5095898.text:
Fionn threw another big stone from the top of Murmod Hill and it landed at the back of Pat Smith's house if Ardnaharnata, Cross. Fionn is also said to have been buried on the top of Murmod Hill. It is said that Fionn had a servant and when Fionn would send to the town he would delay a while when he would come home the giant would kick round the house. One day Fionn sent the  servant to town and he delayed a while Fionn jumped from Murmod Hill to Virginia and caught the servant by the back of the neck and threw him
(continues on next page)

5070789/5063825/5095900.title: Giants and Warriors
5070789/5063825/5095900.text:
(continued from previous page)
up to the top of the hill. He made a jump and aught the servant before he fell on the hill.Eamonn McCabe, Lisnabantry, VirginaPatrick McCabe, Lisnabantry, Virginia



Fionn wandered into the townland of Murmod and he saw a rock and he saw a rock and he fired it to the gates of Mullagh and another day he threw one to Ardlow school and he only called it a pebble.

5070792/5064298/5096778.title: Buying and Selling
5070792/5064298/5096778.text:
(continued from previous page)
The fourpenny, fivepenny and tenpenny bits are gone out of use, and also the four shilling bit, the gold guinea, sovereign and half sovereign.



Once Fionn was fighting with a giant on Murmod Hill, and Fionn put him to flight. The giant fled in the direction of Mullagh, Fionn flung a big rock which was a couple of ton weight after the giant. That rock is still to be seen at the gates of Mullagh. There is a rock on Murmod Hill called Fionn's rock. Fionn's thumb is supposed to be buried under that rock.Fionn Mac Cumhail was a great boxer. Once he got a challenge from a  giant named McCann. McCann was champion boxer of Breffney. Fionn
(continues on next page)

5070792/5064300/5096780.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5070792/5064300/5096780.text:
(continued from previous page)
Fionn fought him and he won him. This boxing was in the townland of Bugesky. It was fought with the bare fists.



Once upon a time a giant and a dwarf were friends and they used to go about seeking adventures. It is said that they came to Virginia and they fought a battle against two Turks. The dwarf who was very brave gave one of them a most angry blow. It did the turk very little injury and lifting up his sword he struck off the poor dwarf's arm. He was now in a sad state but the giant coming to his help left the two Turks dead in a short time. They now went up Murmod Hill and they fought against three monsters who were carrying off a damsel in distress. The dwarf was not quite so fierce now as before. But for all that, he struck the first blow which was returned by another
(continues on next page)

5070803/5065670/5097300.title: Giants - A Giant in Recent Years

5070813/5066630/5098340.title: A Giant Stone
5070813/5066630/5098340.text: There is a large stone about a mile from our house, which is supposed to be about seven or eight ton weight. It is supposed to have been thrown by a Giant from the rock of Carrickleck. The marks of his hands are still to be seen on its surface. People have made several attempts to move it, but it is impossible.

5070839/5069154/5098803.title: Giants
5070839/5069154/5098803.text: There is a story told of a big giant that lived in my locality a few hundred years ago. He was about fourteen feet high, and he was nearly forty stone weight.There is a story told that he used to attack the people of the district with huge poles, kill them, and then eat them. He used to sit on the top of a high rock, and hurl big stones down on the houses in the valley and destroy them. He would not work any to have a crop, but he used to live on the people he used to kill, and also on large animals that he would kill. He lived a long life, and the people would nearly die of fear, when they would hear his name mentioned, and they rejoiced when the heard that he was dead.

5070824/5067830/5099410.title: Stories
5070824/5067830/5099410.text: About a mile outside Bailieboro there is a small road called Uncher Lane. On at the top of this lane there is a track of a giant's foot. It is said that a giant while throwing a stone left his tack in this stone. It is after this that Uncher got (his) it's name as Uncher in Irish means "a shot."

5009140/4990592/5100337.title: A Local Hero
5009140/4990592/5100337.text:
A giant stood at the white gate of Ledwithstown in the year 1887 and threw three rocks over into Dimond Payne's field close by and at the same time he threw a rock into Paddy Feeney's field in Gurteen a distance of two miles and the track of his hand is in the rock. It lies in the field between the two schools.



Maggie McArdles story is about the same rock. It is as follows: A giant stood near Athlone and threw the rock into Paddy Feeney's field a distance of six miles and the track of his hand is in the rock. It is a flat stone and weighs about a ton. This rock is called "the Giant's Rock".

5009140/4990592/5100344.title: A Local Hero
5009140/4990592/5100344.text:
A giant stood at the white gate of Ledwithstown in the year 1887 and threw three rocks over into Dimond Payne's field close by and at the same time he threw a rock into Paddy Feeney's field in Gurteen a distance of two miles and the track of his hand is in the rock. It lies in the field between the two schools.



Maggie McArdles story is about the same rock. It is as follows: A giant stood near Athlone and threw the rock into Paddy Feeney's field a distance of six miles and the track of his hand is in the rock. It is a flat stone and weighs about a ton. This rock is called "the Giant's Rock".

5009144/4991274/5100819.title: A Story
5009144/4991274/5100819.text:
(continued from previous page)
nuts. He ran home and told parson his mother was eating the nuts on the tombstone. The parson said he would not believe unless he saw her. The servant said he would carry him. The servant rolled the parson in a white sheet. When he was coming near the graveyard the thief said: "Is she fat". The servant said: "Fat or lean there she is for you" letting the parson fall down. The parson got such a fright that he leaped up and was at home before the servant. The parson was well able to walk after that.



There once lived in Fermoyle a giant named Fionn Mac Cumhaill. Fionn said he was able to fight any human being.     One day a Scotsman came to fight Fionn but Fionn became afraid a he ran to his mother. She put him into the cradle and pretended he was a baby of Fionn's.   The Scotsman went to examine the baby. He put his finger into the baby's
(continues on next page)

5009144/4991275/5100829.title: A Giant Story
5009144/4991275/5100829.text:
(continued from previous page)
to see if it had any teeth. No sooner had he done so than the baby bit was off a joint of his finger.    The Scotsman ran off terrified crying: When the baby's jawbone is so strong I had no chance of fighting the father.



On one of the Cullentragh shores there is a large stone about six tons in weight. It is sunk in the ground beside a spring well.     There is a story about this rock. On a hill in Elfeet there are the ruins of an old castle. A giant named Forby was supposed to live in this castle. On Slieve Bawn mountain there lived another giant who was Forby's enemy. One day he seized this rock . He stood on the top of the mountain. He aimed at Elfeet castle and flung the rock. He did not hit the castle. The rock fell on this shore and
(continues on next page)

5009141/4990689/5101155.title: Giant Story
5009141/4990689/5101155.text: Long ago there were giants in this district. There were a giant and giantess here at first and then their descendants came. They lived in Creevagh, Parish of Tang; Ballymahon. The ruins of their castle is still there and tracks of rooms of the castle. Mr. Perry owns the field now. Those giants used fight with other giants from other parts of the country. The last giants who cast a spell on them and somehow got rid of them. They are all buried within the ruins of the castle. There is treasure supposed to be hidden under the grounds of the castle somewhere. On some certain nights of certain years at twelve o'clock there is a carriage supposed to be seen going up the drive to the castle and right into the castle, with a coachman without a head and a big black hat a couple of inches over his shoulders and he driving six black horses without heads. They don't make a tick of noise going up to the castle.

5009141/4990720/5101326.title: Giant Story
5009141/4990720/5101326.text:
There was once a giant in Forgney. He was a soldier of Cromwell. One night all the opponents of Cromwell attacked this giant and killed him. Then they went into his cave to get all the treasure. When they went into the cave a big hound belonging to the giant rushed at them and killed one of the men. and with a struggle the rest of the soldiers killed the hound. Then they got the treasure. They buried the giant in a catholic graveyard and the next morning he was seen again, then he was buried again. That night the soldiers watched over his grave and again he rose. This continued for three nights. Then they decided to bury him in the No 2 churchyard. Then he was never seen again.



There was once a giant who knocked at a door and ordered to be let in. A small boy with a big coat on him answered the knock. The giant said to the boy "You will make lovely meat". Then the boy cried for mercy. The giant said. "I will spare your life if you are able to drink as much water as me." The boy began to drink until he was nearly bursting. The boy
(continues on next page)

5009168/4993807/5102953.title: Giants
5009168/4993807/5102953.text: One day two giants met at the side of a big rock and each of them lifted a big handful out of it. The hole which was left filled up with water and became a big lake. Each one of them said that it was his handful that made the lake and they began to fight. One of them killed the other. When he had him killed he threw him up in the air and he fell down on a small house and knocked it.
5009168/4993807/5102953.school_info: School: Coillte Craobhacha, Baile na Muc

5009168/4993808/5102958.title: Giants
5009168/4993808/5102958.text:
There was a giant on top of corn hill years and years ago. It was said that he lifted a bit of the rock and flung it twenty perches away. The track of his five gingers is in the rock yet. WitchesThere was an old woman reading a book years ago. The third night she began to read the book, it turned as black as pitch in her hand. It was said that there was a witch in the house. LeipreacansIt was said that John Lennon saw a fairy fixing shoes under a tree. He asked the fairy for gold. The fairy said, "Look over at the spade beside the tree
(continues on next page)

5009168/4993814/5102970.title: Hag or Witch
5009168/4993814/5102970.text:
(continued from previous page)
was cured.



It is supposed that two giants had a fight on the top of Corn Hill one of them ran away and the other lifted up a piece of rock and threw it after him. It did not hit him and is to be seen on the Clonelly rocks with the prints of the giants fingers on it.



Long, long ago there was a witch supposed to be in Clonaugh, living in a little hut under a big tree.
(continues on next page)
5009168/4993814/5102970.school_info: School: Coillte Craobhacha, Baile na Muc

5009168/4993821/5102997.title: Fairies
5009168/4993821/5102997.text:
(continued from previous page)
was at the stump of the tree the cries were in the branches, when he was at the branches the cries were at the stump. He went back to bed and early next morning he left the tree back he never heard the cries again.



There was once a giant who jumped from Roisins rocks in Gaigue to Slieveaniaran and left the track of his foot which is yet to be seen.There was once a giant who threw a
(continues on next page)

5009168/4993825/5103004.title: Giants
5009168/4993825/5103004.text: Once upon a time  there was a giant about this place who was on the look out for a blanket. He knew a house where there were many blankets and this night he saw the man of the house and he knew he had a long journey to go. When he knew he was a far way gone and the wife was in bed he went in and said "Are you in bed Anne and she said "I am" Then he said " where is the milk for the supper" and she said in a "In a jug on the table. He got the milk and
5009168/4993825/5103004.school_info: School: Coillte Craobhacha, Baile na Muc

5009201/4997326/5103491.title: (no title)
5009201/4997326/5103491.text:
(continued from previous page)
being O'Farrells. They were hanged from a tree near St Johns ChurchOne of the oldest ruins here is that of the old church in Ballymacormack grave yard. There was no glass in that time of its being built as the place of windows show. This ruin was once a monastery and a church. The holy water font is still to be seen and it is believed there is a cure in the water for warts.



Once upon a time there lived a giant on top of a high cliff along the main road. He was a very cruel giant, every night he lit a candle and place it
(continues on next page)

5009163/4993199/5103525.title: Story
5009163/4993199/5103525.text:
Long ago there were a great many giants in this country. Once upon a time a man was going to a fair in Drumlish and he met a giant. The people at that time were very much afraid of giants as they were supposed to be very wicked men.However this man when he met the giant he got afraid as they giant told him if he would not eat as much as him he would kill him. So the man was well able for the giant as he got a goats skin and pur it inside his shirt so the giant and the man started to eat, it was not long untill the giant was not able to eat any more. Then he said he was beginning to die with pain when the man took a big knife and ripped himself open, as the giant thought then all the food bursted out on the floor so the giant did the same thing, and in an instant the poor fellow was as dead as he could be. There was once a giants
(continues on next page)

5009202/4997346/5103848.title: A Giant
5009202/4997346/5103848.text: On the banks of Lough Gara there stands the walls of an old castle where it is said  there once lived a Giant. Those walls covered several acres of land. He had it so well fortified that is was impossible to interfere with him. He sunk a canal round the castle so as to let the water flow around it at night. The people were in great terror of him. Opposite the castle stood Bawn Island where he also had another house where he spent the day. To this Island he built a road from the castle with huge rocks and stones which are also still to be seen there. The water gates burst and overflowed the canal when he was asleep so he was found drowned there.

5009165/4993416/5104072.title: The Three Giants of Cornawn Bawn
5009165/4993416/5104072.text: Once there lived three giants in Cornawn Bawn. One day they were very hungry. One of them went out with a sack to get somethings to eat. He came to a field where three children were playing. He put them into his sack and went for home. On his way he saw a wild pig and he left down his sack to follow the pig. While he was away the children got out of the sack. They put big stones into it. The giant came back without the sack pig and he took the sack and started off. The other two giants had a big pot of water boiling and they were sitting beside the fire. The giant came in and emptied the sack into pot. The stones broke the pot and the water scalded the three to death. There are three big stones over their graves beside Cornawn Bawn.

5009166/4993502/5104431.title: A Fairy Story
5009166/4993502/5104431.text:
(continued from previous page)
man or anybody else never got a chance of catching him or obtaining the gold.



Roísín Ora's rocks are situated in the townland of Bandra in the parish of Drumlish. They are enormous rocks of different shapes and makes. They are so-called because a woman lived in a house for a number of years. Her name was Roisin Ora.     A giant is supposed to have stepped from Corn hill to those rocks - a distance of four miles and thence to Sliab an Iarainn in Leitrim.   At Roisin's rocks there are two imprints of a foot - presumably a giants foot. They are within a yard of each other and are imprinted in the hard firm rock.

5009184/4995578/5104719.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5009184/4995578/5104719.text:
110Stories of Giants and Warriors27th May, 1938.    A long time ago a tailor was working away in his workshop, and he had a slice of bread and jam before him, and according as he sewed he ate the bread. This time he took a mouthful and left it down beside him, and a number of flies lit on it. On seeing this he was very angry, and he took up a piece of cloth, and killed seven of them.     Then he threw the bread down sewing and everything else, and said to himself, "Why is a man like me toiling and mailing
(continues on next page)

5009191/4996095/5106168.title: Old Houses
5009191/4996095/5106168.text:
(continued from previous page)
499in my district long ago, and they are also common now.    Houses were more numerous long ago than they are now because many people emigrated during the time of the Famine and the houses fell for want of repair



499Giants and Warriors   There lived a giant in this district about one thousand years ago named Parshal Von Sickson.   This giant lived in Lisryan and there also lived another giant in Tully named Veralian Musk.    One day the two giants had an argument about which of them was the stronger.   Parshal said he would be able to break an iron bar 20 feet thick by catching it with his two hands and hitting
(continues on next page)

5008908/4965847/5106443.title: (no title)
5008908/4965847/5106443.text:
A little way by Mickie Byrd in Farrell's field there is a big stone.  On this stone there is a shape of a thumb mark.  It is said by some people that St. Patrick threw this stone from Tara, and that it is his thumb mark that is on it.  Other people say that it was a giant that threw if from Tara.Written byFlorence Kavanagh,Walterstown,Garlow Cross,Navan.Given by Michael Byrd (Road-worker)Walterstown,Garlow Cross,Navan.March 1938 A.D.



Christy and Pat Macken every night used to sit at the fire for a chat.  Some of the boys around Walterstown used to go into the hall and listen to them.  Pat and Christy used to wonder how the people would know what they used to be saying.  So this night they were talking and Pat said to Christy "put out that cat the devil must be in him",
(continues on next page)

5008929/4967530/5108675.title: Giants and Warriors
5008929/4967530/5108675.text:
A long time ago there lived an old witch in Baile Rinn lios called "Maura Kishouge". She could cure many ills and she had an evil eye. In fact all the people in the village and neighbourhood were very much afraid of her. But she was in most cases agreeable to cure all sorts of diseases of people and animals. She had a cure for the "cra cree". The patient was put sitting on a sugain with a dish of oatmeal on his knees. The old witch started an incantation and kept it up until the dish of meal disappeared. The patient was cured. An another occasion a young man in the village was bitten by a mad dog and and course "Maura Kishouge" was sent for. There was no cure. So "Maura" acted according to the custom. She opened a vein in the man's arm
(continues on next page)

5008929/4967532/5108679.title: Giants and Warriors
5008929/4967532/5108679.text: Very many years ago there lived a very cruel giant in Tara. The people were afraid of him because he used to knock down their sheds and sometimes their houses. He also killed their cattle and ate them. He had a woman working for him and she used to bake cakes for him. One day while she was making a cake she thought of a plan. When she had the cake baked she split it in the middle and put the griddle in it. The giant was very hungry and he took one savage bite out of the cake and when he swallowed it he did not feel well. In a  few weeks he died.

5008965/4971537/5109596.title: Giants
5008965/4971537/5109596.text:
Once upon a time there lived a woman who was very poor. She had a son and all the people said he would be lucky and marry the Kings daughter for he was born under a lucky star. When the King heard this news he was very angry.So one day when the woman was out the King got her child and put him into a box. He put the box into a river and the box sailed off.It came to a house and someone in the house came out and found the child. The child grew for some years. Until one day the King came by on his horse. He knew the boy and asked the people where they got him. So they told him about the box. Then the King sent a note to the Queen by the boy telling her to have him killed when he came. When the boy was on his way to the Queen he went
(continues on next page)

5008979/4973226/5112824.title: Two Giants
5008979/4973226/5112824.text: It is said that long ago two Giants were fighting near Mullagh hill. The weapons they used were stones. Some of the stones with which they fought rested on a small hill near Mullagh. The place is still known as the gates of Mullagh. These ancient stones are so heavy that no ten men nowadays would move them.

5008991/4974805/5112872.title: A Giant Story
5008991/4974805/5112872.text:
Long ago a mighty giant lived at Kilmainhamwood. He defeated all the giants in Ireland. It is supposed that the village got its name from him. Hearing of him a mighty giant came from Scotland to fight him. When Weena heard of him coming he made inquiries as to his strength and he found out that all his strength was in his left hand.On the day that the giant was coming Weena got afraid and he told his mother of his fears. She told him that she had a trick would save him. She told him to make a cradle big enough to hold him. Then she told him to lie in and she covered him. She got busy making griddle cakes and she put iron in some of them.When the Scottish giant came he asked for Weena and his mother told him he had gone away in a fury as he heard of some giant coming to fight him. The Scottish giant said "I am the man." She told him to take some
(continues on next page)

5009006/4976300/5113307.title: A Giant
5009006/4976300/5113307.text:
Long ago people believed that there were men in this country who were called giants. There was one of these men in the cave at the river Boyne and he had magic power. One day as he was in the cave he leaned up against the wall and the shape of his body is in the wall still. It is said that he used to go around every night and lift people out of bed and leave them lying on the floor. One night as two men were fishing on the river Boyne they saw the giant coming out of the cave and they fainted when they saw him and the boat turned over and the two men were drowned.It is also said that one day a man was riding a horse along the river and when he came to the place where the cave was the horse would not go by. The next day the man went the same way and when he came to the cave the horse would not go by and the man kept beating him and after some time the horse threw the man and broke his neck. The giants name was "Crucket Legs." The reason he was called that is because he had legs as thick as a tree and they were "crucket" and bent. The giant lived in the cave at the river Boyne for a long time until an
(continues on next page)

5009010/4976838/5113863.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5009010/4976838/5113863.text:
In this district there is a large stone on the top of Ward's hill. It is said that when the Giants were in Ireland one of them was standing at Tara and threw the stone from there so it landed on the top of Ward's hill. This stone is on the hill ever since and the track of the Giant's five fingers is on the stone. Some people say that the Giant
(continues on next page)

5009004/4976025/5113971.title: Buying and Selling
5009004/4976025/5113971.text:
(continued from previous page)
buying sheep, pigs, cattle and other animals, this is still done.Money was not always given for goods sometimes things were changed for another or what is known as barter and even to the present day labour was done i.e. men working in shops got goods or their provisions as wages.When exchanging an inferior animal what is known as "boot" was given with it.Sundays bargain is not binding but Friday is considered the luckiest day to transact business. On squares of the towns and in different parts of the district markets were held but not at present.Hucksters, Pedlars and dealers are still plentiful in the country especially the Jewish dealers who around each district buying rags, feathers and old oak furniture. Paper currency was unknown in olden times.



There is only one story told in the locality of a giant playing a part in. Far back
(continues on next page)

5009046/4980786/5116402.title: Giant's Rock
5009046/4980786/5116402.text: 29.6.1939About a half a mile from my home, on the road leading from Martinstown to Southhill on the right hand side, is a large rock. This rock stands as part of the ditch, it is about four feet high and three feet wide, this rock is covered over with moss except where some marks where the moss never grows. These marks are said to be impressions of a giants hands and feet. According to old stories it is said this stone once formed part of an old castle nearby. The giant is said to have thrown this stone from the castle which is some distance in the fields to where the stone now rests.

5009070/4983642/5117035.title: Giants and Warriors
5009070/4983642/5117035.text:
There were two giants living in this locality in olden times, Cushmore lived in Coola.  The imprints of his fingers may be still seen in the wall near Coola Park.  He was a warrior.  He fought with another giant from Castletown named Hantarrib.  Cushmore in this battle took up two skraws from Commagh to fling at his adversary.  The two skraws formed the split hills and the hollow near Commagh hole made from the lifting of the two skraws.  Dromfauda lived in Clongowley he used a sling to throw stones.  The rocks of Ballard were slung from Dromfauda’s
(continues on next page)

5009076/4984198/5118393.title: My Home District
5009076/4984198/5118393.text: I live in the townland of Conranstown. There are eleven families in it. There are fifty five people living in it. The names most common is Manny. All the houses are slated except one. There was a Giant living in Rath Drishóg castle and he saw enemies coming to kill him. He ran away and had to cross a drain. He fell into the drain and disappeared Con was the Giant's name, and thats how Conranstown got its name. There are two old people in my townland. They don't know any story. There is one ruin in my townland. The townland is not mentioned in story or song. The land is good.

5009125/4988997/5119826.title: Giants and Warriors
5009125/4988997/5119826.text:
Giants and Warriors.9.12.'38.The men that were out long ago were far stronger than the men of nowdays. It is said that there was one man who in lived Brittas his name was James Glennan and it is said he could wheel thirty six stone of oats on a barrow to Ballykeeran mill. The story is told that once there was a stray ass on the road. One morning this man caught the ass eating the oats and he got into a temper and took the ass by the tail and flung him out on the road.A giant flying from Connaught formed the two Waterstown lakes. Where he stepped and the mud fell off his feet and formed Ballyheeran hill.A small haggard beside John Conlons house Lissahillon Glasson, Athlone, the Barony of Kilhenntied in his great grandfathers time. The haggard was sown with barley. The old man was looking at it on Sunday and said ti was fit to eat. The next morning the people got up early to cut it. But it had disappeared. Roots and stems, and it was
(continues on next page)

5009125/4989017/5120111.title: Historical Tradition
5009125/4989017/5120111.text:
There are many stories told in the district. There was once a giant who lived in Whiterock. It was said that he lifted a rock there and trew it to Carrickfin. The rock fell there and killed all the people it fell on. After this, the giant was surrounded and killed. It is said that where he was buried there is a big hill.



Long ago there was a lake surrounded by a wood, in the wood there lived a clan who were opposing the Fianna. After an hour or more the clan returned to this wood. When the Fianna's got them settled down, they lit the wood and they surrounded them and killed each of them. In the
(continues on next page)

5009125/4989017/5120112.text:

The rock fell there and killed all the people it fell on. After this, the giant was surrounded and killed. It is said that where he was buried there is a big hill.

5009083/4985010/5120378.title: Old Irish Tales
5009083/4985010/5120378.text:
Down near Ballinacargy there is a little hill with a stone on the side of it.  It is said that long ago when St Patrick was teaching the true faith one evening he was very tired and he sat down on the stone to rest.  Ever after that it was called St Patrick's chair.People pay visits to it and it is said that whatever you wish for while sitting on it you will get it.



Once a giant who lived in my district some hundred years ago threw a rock of stone from Frewin hill to a field in Mr
(continues on next page)

5009083/4985025/5120400.title: Giants and Warriors
5009083/4985025/5120400.text:
Long ago two giants met and they started an argument.  They were disputing which of them were the strongest.  They started to throw big rocks to see which of them could throw it the farthest.  On of the giants got in a great fury and he lifted up a mighty rock of about three tons weight.With all his might he threw it a distance of about (threw) three miles.  They were having the contest at a place known as the "Captain's hill" beside Lough Owl lake and the rock landed in Mr Owen's field in Walshestown.  There the
(continues on next page)

5009083/4985026/5120402.title: Giants and Warriors
5009083/4985026/5120402.text:
(continued from previous page)
rock is to be seen to the present day.Teresa Mulready



There are no old stoties told locally of giants to have ever existed in my district.On the side of the hill of Frewin in John Beirne's land there is a very large stone with the greater part of it buried in the earth.  It is said to be thrown there by a giant from the hill of Knock-Ine.About a hundred and forty years ago two men Patrick and Nicholas Gaynor who lived near Frewin were the strongest men ever in Midlands.  They were well over seven feet high.There was a large stone in Sonna with a hole in it so any man could put
(continues on next page)

5009089/4985590/5121962.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5009089/4985590/5121962.text:
There was a great warrior by the name of King Martin, who lived in a Castle named Carrick Castle, in the townland  Carrick, Ballinalack. There was a great battle fought at this Castle long ago, and this King Martin was killed there. He was about 7 feet in height, and he was very strong. When he was killed he was buried in the grounds of Carrick and there was a big rock put over his grave.



There is a small river situated about one mile from Float Station. This river is commonly known as the Fanowen. There is a bridge over this river and there was supposed to be a giant living at the bridge.



There was a man living in Clonave, Coole, Co. Westmeath, about twenty years ago. He was about feet in height, and he was never called anything but the wild man of Clonave.



Long ago there lived two Giants in this district, and they used to steal hens and go around selling them for cakes of bread.



Long ago, there was a number of Giants
(continues on next page)

5009089/4985591/5121978.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5009089/4985591/5121978.text:
(continued from previous page)
living in a wood about one mile from Wilsons Hospital, Bunbrusna Co Westmeath. The wood was called Giants and Warriors wood. There was a lot of them in the wood and one day they had a terrible battle between them. It started because a few giants thought they were better than the rest. They (stuck) slashed one another with knives and hatchets. They fought all day long until at last all were killed but one giant.



One time there were fifteen men trying to put a big stone over a door, but after many hours they failed to do so. There was a great Saint watching the men and he told them to go in to their dinner. The men did so and  when they came out the stone was over the door where the giants and warriors wanted it.



Long ago there was a giant living in this district, and he was very strong. One morning before his breakfast, he said to his wife he would go out into the wood and see if there was anyone in it. He saw a little boy gathering sticks and he called him over and told him to go to the big house which was the giants. He also told him to knock at the door and a woman would come to him, and he told the boy to tell her the giant sent him. The boy went to the house and told the giants
(continues on next page)

5009089/4985591/5121981.text:

5009089/4985592/5121984.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5009089/4985592/5121984.text:
(continued from previous page)
wife all but she told him to go home by another was because the giant wanted to kill him.



There was a man in Clonave and he was called the wild man of Clonave.  Every night about ten o'clock he used to go out and walk through the bog with a light. One day the wild man was put into the asylum but after a while he broke out and went back to Clonave. He went into a certain house and asked for a scissors. When he got it he cut of[f] his whiskers so that the people out of the asylum would not know him. Told by Christopher Fagan (deceased) aged 77 Clonave, Coole Co. Westmeath.

5009340/5008697/5129987.title: An Old Story
5009340/5008697/5129987.text:
There was once a man named Michael MacEvoy who was a labourer.  He was ploughing one day in a field by the side of the road.  The priest was coming down the road.  The priest was a very funny man and liked a joke and said something to Michael.  Michael took the joke as an insult and started to curse and swear and said he would never go to Mass again.  The priest said that he only said it for a joke but Michael insisted upon cursing and swearing.  The priest said Michael would never have a days luck and he went away.A few days after Michael MacEvoy went to Wexford town and stayed in it until late at night.  When Michael was coming home it was about twelve o'clock.  When he had come out a piece from town he met something like three dogs.  The dogs fought with him and threw him in the ditch and they nearly killed him.  It was morning now and there was someone going along the road who found Michael under an ash tree.  He asked MacEvoy what was wrong and he said the "The dogs" and then he died.When this man was buried the priest told the people they could pray that he was in heaven but he said he doubted it.



A long time ago there lived on the mountain of Forth a big giant.  He lived in a little hut by himself.  Every morning he used to
(continues on next page)

5009334/5007918/5134265.title: Stories
5009334/5007918/5134265.text: There's two giants buried in one of Laffin's fields in Barmoney.It is said that they stood on Mount Leinster and fired a stone, and they said wherever the stone would fall that they would be buried in that spot.The stone fell in one of Laffin's fields, and they were buried there.

5009321/5007003/5134664.title: Giants
5009321/5007003/5134664.text: 241GiantsThere is a hill behind Ballymore School, it is called Carrig Rue hill.  There is a big rock on top of the hill and it is cut out like a bed and it is believed that a giant slept there long ago : there is a passage through the rock to the bed.It is said that there was another giant on Slieve Wee and he was fighting with the giant on Carrig Rue and they were throwing big stones and rocks at each other, and the giant on Carrig Rue threw stones and some of them fell at Milshogue near Camolin and another fell near Clough.Long ago there were some people chasing a man on horseback on Carrig Rua hill and when he came to the giants bed the horse jumped down from the bed : the horse was killed but the man escaped.Saidee Green.Mt. Seaton, Camolin.Co. Wexford.

5044727/5034901/5137382.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044727/5034901/5137382.text:
In the district of Glendalough joining Derrybawn there is a cut in a cut in a rock and is known as the Giants Cut, a giant some years ago and supposed to cut it with his sword.There is another place in Ballinderry near Knockrath it is called the Giants Glen, and there is another place near Roundwood it is called the Giants Grave because a giant was supposed to be killed there and he was supposed to be only eight years of age when he died.There was a giant in Glendalough and another giant in Wicklow the giant in Glendalough had a beautiful black bull, the giant in Wicklow he heard about the bull
(continues on next page)

5044727/5034911/5137406.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044727/5034911/5137406.text:
There once lived a Giant in Glendalough and there also lived a Giant in the low land of Wicklow, and the one in Glendalough had a bull, the other Giant came up to take the bull from him.  He came up and took it of Glendalough mountain and he got it as far as Parkmore and the two Giants pulled the bull in two parts.  They then started to fight and the Giant from Glendalough killed the other.  He is buried near Parkmore Catholic Church.  There once lived a Giant in Glendalough and another Giant came to attack him and when the Giant from Glendalough was trying to hit the other with his sword he missed his aim and cut a rock
(continues on next page)

5044727/5034921/5137445.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044727/5034921/5137445.text:
Finn McCuhail was supposed to be a giant in some stories told by the old people, one evening he was walking along a path over Moneystown Hill, when he saw some men trying to lift a very big stone but they had failed many times, but Finn took it in his hand and threw it to Moneystown Bridge where it is still to be seen.There is a cave on the Derrybawn mountain  called the Witching Cave or the Wishing Cave, it is said that an old witch lived in it, and it is said that she enchanted it, and if people go there they get
(continues on next page)

5044747/5036084/5137978.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044747/5036084/5137978.text:
There was a giant that lived on Croghan hill.  His name is not known.  He used to come to this district sometimes.  He used to go through all the districts.  Nobody liked to see him coming because they were afraid of him.  He used to throw rocks at the people if they did not give him what he wanted.  He used to throw big stones and socks from place to place but they are not there now.There were two old hags in the district of Ballyrahan long ago.  They lived in two small houses.  One of them was called "Old Mag" and they other "Old Jane"  Nobody ever went near "Old Jane" because she was supposed to have witchcraft



There was a giant who lived in Coolboy.  His name is not known it is forgotten.  There are not many stories told about him.  The house in which he lived is not standing now.  It is levelled there are no ruins there now either.  There is a rive
(continues on next page)

5044588/5024050/5138536.title: The Giant
5044588/5024050/5138536.text:
When the giants were living in Ireland, a giant was standing on Croghan hill.  He saw a witch on the Curragh of Kildare.  He threw a stone at her.  The witche's, dog saw the stone coming, he ran to meet it.  He met it, in a field near Clonbullogue.  He stopped it with his paw.  It is said that the mark of the dog's paw is on one side, of the stone, and the man's hand on the other side.



Long ago, when people were going to the fair, they said if they met a red haired woman on the road, that they might turn back, that they would not be lucky.

5044588/5024050/5138574.title: The Giant
5044588/5024050/5138574.text:
When the giants were living in Ireland, a giant was standing on Croghan hill.  He saw a witch on the Curragh of Kildare.  He threw a stone at her.  The witche's, dog saw the stone coming, he ran to meet it.  He met it, in a field near Clonbullogue.  He stopped it with his paw.  It is said that the mark of the dog's paw is on one side, of the stone, and the man's hand on the other side.



Long ago, when people were going to the fair, they said if they met a red haired woman on the road, that they might turn back, that they would not be lucky.

4921591/4882477/5138768.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921591/4882477/5138768.text: Stories of Giants and WarriorsThe following is a local legend regarding a giant. Long ago two Giants were fighting. One of the giants lived in Cape Clear. The other dwelt in this parish. The latter picked up a big piece of rock from mount Gabriel near Schult and threw it at the giant in Cape Clear. It did not reach the island. It fell into the sea to the west of the island and remained on the top of the water. It is now known as Fastnet Rock.There is also a legend regarding this rock. The old people believed that it left its position around the ocean but returned back again to its former position.

5044599/5024901/5139669.title: The Giant's Grave
5044599/5024901/5139669.text: There is a Giants bed in Willie Smollens field next to our field. It is on the top of the hill and you can see it from the road. There is a shape of a bed in the middle of the stones. There are two stones each side and one at the top for a pillow. The stones each side are about a ton in weight. Long ago the people used to say that giants lived in it, but it is only children that believe it in now. There are trees all around the giant's bed. The field that the giants bed is in was never ploughed.

4921602/4883820/5139966.title: Giants
4921602/4883820/5139966.text:
The old people of this locality say that two giants once lived at the top of Mount Gabriel near the place where the lake now lies. One of them was much taller than the other but the smaller had two heads and was cleverer and stronger than the other. It is said that they killed any person who cut a tree on the mountain side and then they cast their bodies into, the lake.One day a dispute arose between the two as to which was the stronger and it was agreed upon that they should both lift a stone and throw it as afar as they could. The two giants lifted stones of equal weight and threw them
(continues on next page)

5044614/5025978/5140993.title: (no title)
5044614/5025978/5140993.text:
Once upon a time a giant lived in Cooldorougha. One day he got a message that another giant was coming to fight him.He told his wife to bake a cake with iron in the middle and to tell the other giant that she was making the cake for him. When the giant game he saw the cake and he asked for whom it was made. The woman told him it was for her husband.The giant said "If he can eat that cake the can eat me too" and he went away. The giant is buried in the grave yard in Killaghantubber.



Once upon a time a giant lived in Bellair, He was supposed to take a huge rock on his little finger and hurl it from the Hill of Bellair to Claffey's field. That rock can be seen in the middle of the
(continues on next page)

5044620/5026701/5142015.title: Local Monuments
5044620/5026701/5142015.text:
There are few standing stones in our Parish, one in Clonascra was thrown from Clonlyon by a giant.  His fingers are to be seen on it.  There are 3 standing stones in one field belonging to Mr. Kennedy Bloomhill.  These have been described already.  One is the Criss Cross so called because their is a cross on it the other has the track of St. Keiran's Horses foot and the third of St. Keirans cows tail.There are no ornamented stones in this Parish and there is a very famous one in Clonfanlough not very far away.



There are not many stories about giants in this locality but there was a giant living in Clonlyon long ago and he threw a stone and it fell in Clonesera.  It is still to be seen in the spot in which it fell and the
(continues on next page)

5044667/5030569/5143995.title: Giants and Warriors
5044667/5030569/5143995.text:
Long ago two giants from Kilcrut started fighting in Doran's bog. They kept on till both sank into the soft soil and were buried in the bog. Passers by the bog assert that, on a moonlight night, the shadows of the giants can be seen in the bog lunging at each other, and on a dark night weird noises are heard from the bog.In Drummond lived a giant 6ft 8 ins. in height and he weighed 24 stones. It was no bother to him to carry a weight of 5 cut. He used to attend fairs and earn money by performing feats of strength. One day as he was driving a lady to New Ross he was held up by Highwaymen. The giant sprang from the car, seized the leader of the robbers by the neck & kept a grip on him till he collapsed. The other robbers flew away in terror & never again was the Drummond giant interfered with on the public road. Colonel Egan who fought with Sarsfield at the Boyne, Limerick, Athlone & Aughrim returned broken - hearted to his native district after the Treaty of Limerick.
(continues on next page)

5044674/5031008/5144540.title: Hidden Treasure near Leighlinbridge
5044674/5031008/5144540.text:
(continued from previous page)
the moonlight and the house hearing a scurrying in the moat jumped over a small wicket gate into the moat and immediately dropped dead. Doyle was ill for a week with fright.About 10 years ago two boys were ferreting on this mound and sent in a ferret which never came out. The boys got iron bars to dig out the ferret & proceeded to dig deep under the mound. After going in a few feet the bar struck something & reaching in his arm one of the boys drew out two candlesticks, supposed to be of silver & ornamented. The local P.P. met them & having inquired about the candlesticks bought them from the boys.



About a mile from Ballinkillen School in a district called Kilcruit (N.W. of School) & S.E. is the district of Killedon. Mr John Redmond says that these districts were named after giants named Crut & Eden and the prefix "Kil" has no connection with the Irish "Cill" but is the English word "kill" because both giants strove to kill the other so that the survivor would become supreme lord
(continues on next page)

5044674/5031010/5144542.title: The Giant of Lacken
5044674/5031010/5144542.text:
The Giant of LackenLacken is a townsland between Borris and Rathanna.  Here lived a famous giant called Seán Balc.  When Seán was small he was puny and was reared like a pet cat beside the fire.  His body was sometimes so cold that his mother is said to have heaped the warm cinders from under the grate round him.  Anyhow the heat did him good and he grew strong, tall and brawny but the fire was his god.  He grew and grew, so that to sit upright he had to sit on the hob with his head up the chimney as the ceiling was too low for him.When Seán was about 28 a great weight throwing contest between giants of Scotland and  of Wexford was arranged to be held in Dublin by a Wexford man named Coakley.  Coakley rode to Dublin and seeing the Wexford men failing galloped to Lacken and implored Seán to have one throw for ould Ireland.  Seán was ill and feared to risk the journey "Come Seán" says Caokley "and if you die you'll have a marvellous funeral and if you live I'll make a gentleman of you."  Seán went and when they reached
(continues on next page)

4921587/4882222/5146830.title: Story
4921587/4882222/5146830.text: In a strand named Tráth na Thuile[?] there is a stone at the edge of one of the pools in the rocks. It is a very big one, about five feet high and twelve feet in circumference. One time there lived on the top of the hill a giant and his mother. The son wanted to go away, but his mother would not let him. They began fighting and the son managed to get away. As he was getting into the sea, his mother took up a big stone and flung it after him, but she missed and the stone landed on the rocks and is there every since.

4921588/4882268/5146874.title: Local Giants and Warriors
4921588/4882268/5146874.text:
In olden times there were three giants living in this district, namely, Hugh, Jack and Pat Crowley. They were supposed to be the strongest and biggest men in the country. They had no special abode but seemingly they prefered to be travelling from place to place.    There is a story told of those giants. On one occassion Jack had gone to America and one night while he was away his brother Hugh was in the village of Kilcrohane. The night was very dark and when Hugh was coming through the village he accidently struck against another man. Neither of them saluted the other, and Hugh not knowing who the man was started to fight with him. Any one of them could not get the better of the other. They remained struggling for about half-an-hour and finally Hugh got the better of the other man, but when the man was knocked Hugh put down his hand and caught him by the head and when he did he realized that it was his brother Jack, was there. He was surprised and he said to him "You are the devil or Jack He was right it was Jack who had returned that evening from America was there. Then
(continues on next page)

5044680/5031547/5147423.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044680/5031547/5147423.text:
People named Quinn lived in Grangeford. They had a few acres of land, with two cows grazing on them. They could never get butter from the milk. They were told about a witch, who lived in Tullow. They went to her, and she advised them them to get the plough irons, and to put one end in the fire, and the other end under the churn. They did so, and they always had butter afterwards.



In olden times a giant seven feet high stood on Killeshin hill, and with one hand he threw a large stone, and it fell in the
(continues on next page)

5044680/5031547/5147426.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5044680/5031547/5147426.text:
People named Quinn lived in Grangeford. They had a few acres of land, with two cows grazing on them. They could never get butter from the milk. They were told about a witch, who lived in Tullow. They went to her, and she advised them them to get the plough irons, and to put one end in the fire, and the other end under the churn. They did so, and they always had butter afterwards.



In olden times a giant seven feet high stood on Killeshin hill, and with one hand he threw a large stone, and it fell in the
(continues on next page)

5044646/5028681/5148208.title: The Story of a Giant
5044646/5028681/5148208.text:
The Story of a GiantThere is a Giant buried in Cloonfad wood in Glasshouse. Every night about ten o'clock there is a light seen crossing over to the grave. The light is of a dark blue colour and can be seen a distance away. It rises in McDonald's lane and travels through Glasshouse bog and comes to rest where the Giant is buried. it is a very long grave with a flat stone on it. It is surrounded by a huge mass of briars.



The Story of a fortIn years gone by there lived in Glasshouse people by the name of Rollestons. Part of their land was Boultry on which there was a fort. There was music heard in this fort several times. One John Murphy, Conlisk and some other men went to see where the music came from and when they went into the fort they saw a big light coming towards them. They got frightened and ran away.



When a new moon comes bury a piece of fat bacon in the manure heap. When the moon goes away the piece of bacon will go away and so will the wart. The above story was told to me by Mr. Alliehael.

5044646/5028681/5148211.title: The Story of a Giant
5044646/5028681/5148211.text:

The light is of a dark blue colour and can be seen a distance away. 5044605/5025345/5148213.title: Folklore
5044605/5025345/5148213.text: The giant's track. The Giant's track is situated about half a mile from my house. - two miles from Kilcormac.It is on the top of the Hill of Carrig. It is a big flat stone and on it are the marks of a Giant's and A devil's feet. The marks of the giant's big stick are also to be seen. On a hill near it a man is supposed to be seen.A palm tree is growing near the rock.  Men and people are supposed to be heard shouting and laughing at certain times.

5138257/4970931/5151633.title: Giant's Graves
5138257/4970931/5151633.text: There are three graves at a place called Callighstown not far from Ballyacargy in the County of Westmeath. The graves are know as the Giants graves. There is a legend in the locality that three brothers lived in a castle at Callighstown. The sige and strength of the brothers was abnormal. Any of the three could seize a full grown tree and pull it from the roots. The three brothers challenged three other giants from Roscommon to combat and after a fight lasting for nine days the Roscommon giants were killed and buried at Callighstown. The graves are a source of interest to many visitors.
5138257/4970931/5151633.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire, An Uaimh

4798785/4798408/5151658.title: Old Song
4798785/4798408/5151658.text:
(continued from previous page)
When he met me in the boreen.Ach" he said " you angishoreen don't be watching Maryanne "



It is said that there is a giant buried on the top of "[?]" hill.  He was twelve feet in height and had a very big horse and a gun.  His name was Giant McGun  He died and was buried on the top of "[?]" along with his horse and gun.His grave is still to be seen there because there is a cairn or mound of earth over it.  In his lifetime it is said that he threw a stone from "[?]" to Ballinvaird.
4798785/4798408/5151658.school_info: School: Ros Mór, Béal Átha Fhinghín

4798783/4798228/5151769.title: Tithe Proctor
4798783/4798228/5151769.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Kenneigh round tower is near the grave yard in the townland of "Sliabh an Oigh." The top is not finished as it is said that one night the angles were building it and a woman living near, looked out the window. The angles stopped as soon as they saw her, and the top was never finished.



Once upon a time Kenniegh round tower was finished. A giant from the north was to fight a person name Edward O Connor a shoemaker in Ballineen. The shoemaker was too weak and could not fight a giant. The people were praising O Connor. The giant was rubbing the two fences he was so fat and big. He saw a stone on top of the hill and he asked
(continues on next page)

4921660/4888408/5152547.title: Giants
4921660/4888408/5152547.text:
The last giants that were in this parish were jealous of each other and one was trying to kill the other. They used have several fights and at one time they had challenged to fight until one would kill the other. One giant's wife feared that her husband would be killed, and she thought of a plan. She told her husband to go into a hiding place, and when the enemy would come herself would manage him.When the other giant came he asked the wife of the hiding giant where was her husband? and she said he was gone out hunting and
(continues on next page)

4921697/4890955/5153815.title: A Giant
4921697/4890955/5153815.text: About the beginning of the eighteenth century there were numbers of men cutting turf in Raheena bog (old name for Moanflugh bog).  One fine day in the month of May they found a giant.  There were eleven sods in depth of turf over him.  They first saw his legs; they then cleaned around him and took him out on the handles of pikes and shovels on the brink of the old road.  He had no neck or head, and he measured eight feet from his heel to the point of his shoulder.  His body was thicker than the circumference of a horse, and his legs were thicker than a man's body.  They stretched him on the green bank of the road.  The weather was very dry and hard and all the people came to see him, and the doctors. On the third day doctors from Cork came, but he was gone into dust.

4921619/4885543/5153985.title: A Giant Story
4921619/4885543/5153985.text: A Giant StoryIn this locality there are three lakes.  Cullinagh Lake, Coolkelure Lake ad Shiplake.  Cullinagh Lake is at the foot of Mount Owen and is separated from Coolkelure Lake by bogs and woods.About a mile and a half from Coolkelure Lake is Shiplake which got its name from a fanciful connection between the lake and an immense rock standing near it and likened to a ship.A story is told that long ago a giant stepped from Mount Owen to the place where Cullinagh Lake is and from that to Coolkelure Lake and his third footprint made Shiplake.Ernie KingstonAge 12 yearsFrom Mr G Kingston, (50 Years) FarmerCullinagh, Dunmanway.

5162158/5160073/5163916.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5162158/5160073/5163916.text:
There is a story told about Lough Neagh. It is said that a Giant in England came over to Ireland and a Giant in Ireland ran to put him out of the country. As the Giant in Ireland ran-after the other Giant, it is said that he lifted a handful of clay and flung it after the Giant who was running to England. The people say that where he lifted the clay a hole was left that formed Lough Neagh. He threw it out into the Irish sea. and it formed the island which is there to this day and it is called the Isle of Man ever since.



There is a story about a boy who one day was watching the flies lighting and he tried to see how many flies he could kill with one blow. He found that he killed seven with one blow and he wrote on a placard "Jack the seven killer with one blow." One day he was passing where two giants
(continues on next page)

5162158/5160073/5163941.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5162158/5160073/5163941.text:
