As the Giant in Ireland ran-after the other Giant, it is said that he lifted a handful of clay and flung it after the Giant who was running to England. The people say that where he lifted the clay a hole was left that formed Lough Neagh. He threw it out into the Irish sea. and it formed the island which is there to this day and it is called the Isle of Man ever since.



There is a story about a boy who one day was watching the flies lighting and he tried to see how many flies he could kill with one blow. He found that he killed seven with one blow and he wrote on a placard "Jack the seven killer with one blow." One day he was passing where two giants
(continues on next page)

4811661/4809807/5163944.title: Folklore - Giants and Warriors
4811661/4809807/5163944.text:
The giants of long ago never longer than twenty eight years. They were eight feet three inches in height. Brian McPiercan could twist a new horse shoe like a gad around in his hand. his real name was Patrick cotter born in the year seventeen sixty one at Kinsale. He could hold a hundred weight at his arms length.A man named Mahony threw a half ton weight of rock stone or finger stone twenty feet the stone can be seen to this very day. Mark Scott had no ribs only one bone round his chest he could throw a stone from Allens gate and strike the rock in Shorten's lake about five hundred yards of a throw. These giants had factions fights between each other at Quarries cross they fought freely with sticks stones bottles and other missiles. There was a lot of old hags lived
(continues on next page)

4811654/4809306/5164553.title: A Giant
4811654/4809306/5164553.text:
In the townland of Derryleigh is a cromlech which is supposed to contain the body of a giant. The old people tell us that his name is unknown because five hundred years have elapsed since he was buried. He was a very strong man for we are told that he carried a flag which weighed five tons about half a mile.He also had a golden sword, which was buried with him in the cromlech.Three flags each ten feet long by eleven feet broad were put standing on the ground. A big flag fifteen feet long by ten feet broad by one foot in thickness was put resting on
(continues on next page)

5162170/5160591/5164627.title: Hallow Eve Practices
5162170/5160591/5164627.text:
(continued from previous page)
Hallow Een night in case some dead relations might be hovering around and it might be thrown on them. The hearth was specially swept and the kitchen was specially tidied for the "good people."No haws or wild berries were to be eaten after Hallow 'Een night because on that night the fairies were supposed to go round and spit on them.The old people, like old Pat Maquinn of Annies alt. used to say that the fairies changed their place of residence on that night going from one fort to another. People were unwilling to stay late on their ceilidhe on that night in case they would cross the fairies path on their way home.9. A girl who wanted to find out who her future husband was to be would wash a shirt and put it on the back of a chair before the fire today. At midnight her future husband was supposed to come along and turn the shirt to get the other side of it dried.



A big giant long ago threw a large stone from Carn Roe outside Scotshouse to Shontamon Mountain in the County Cavan. The giant
(continues on next page)

5162170/5160593/5164630.title: A Giant and His Cast
5162170/5160593/5164630.text:
(continued from previous page)
was about nine feet high and had two heads. He was afterwards buried under a big stone on Carnroe because Carn was the highest hill in the district. There is some mark on the stone which can still be seen.From Jack Donohoe, Scotshouse.There are many versions of this story in the neighbourhood. Some say the giant threw a stone from Sliabh Glah in Cavan to Carnroe, whilst others say it was from Cuilcagh Mountain he threw the stone. All are agreed that the giant was buried in the old "Giant's Grave" on Carnroe.



My father says that there is a water bull in Drum Loch in the townland of Cortober. This bull was about the size of a yearling calf. It lived in the part of the lake below Dr Moor's house. It used to destroy and scatter his hay at night. Every morning he used to get up to find out what was destroying his hay. One morning he got up very early and went out to see. When he went out he saw a bull running away into the lake. Next morning he got up earlier and brought a gun with him. He fired a shot at it but missed it. The bull was never seen out of the lake again.

4921741/4902294/5167774.title: Piseoga
4921741/4902294/5167774.text:
(continued from previous page)
wife.  But she could not work the piseogs when the "clearing" was drawn through the cowdung.



Near Glenlara there is a very large field and in it are seven very large stones it is said that they were put there by giants.  One of the stones is much larger than the other and it is said the Father put the big stone there and the six sons put one each near the fathers, the father's stone is going right through the centre of the ditch into the ground, and it is said that it would take a great number of men to lift one of them.

4921744/4902674/5171003.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921744/4902674/5171003.text:
Many stories are told in this country of giants and brave warriors who are supposed to have lived there in olden times. In this district a story is frequently told of a brave giant who is supposed to have lived here in former times. People always feared this giant because of his great strength. He is supposed to have thrown a huge rock from a place now known as Ballyhoulihan. The rock is still to be seen in the place where it landed and the print of the giants fingers can also be seen on the rock. Some people say the giant threw the rock at a certain enemy who was attacking him. An old hag is supposed to have lived in a certain cave at a place known as Kiskeam. This hag is supposed to have stopped from
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: An tSr. Seosamh; An tSr. Berchmans

4921744/4902676/5171005.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921744/4902676/5171005.text: The only story known in this locality about a giant is in connection with the battle of "Knoc na Nos" which took place in the seventeenth century. In this battle there was a warrior named Mac Alister who was man of extraordinary strength. It is related that the sword he carried had a 56lb weight attached to it. This weight would slide out to the point of the sword and give greater force to the power of the blow. He used this with great effect on men and horses. It is thought he was killed in the battle because some time afterwards when the bones were being removed from the battlefield the bones of a giant was discovered. The bones and skull, were twice the size of normal human remains.

metadata.Teacher:: An tSr. Seosamh; An tSr. Berchmans

4921744/4902677/5171006.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921744/4902677/5171006.text:
There was once a man named William Murohy, known locally as Big Bill Murphy. He was a man of extraordinary strenght. He lived in the village of Liscarroll about eight miles to the north-east of this town. The feats of strength performed by this giant are still related in this district. he was a blacksmith by trade and on several occasions used to take his anvil around the country in his hand when he went to do jobs for farmers and others. There is an old castle in the village which is about 80 ft high. On one occasion for a small wage he took a sledge weighing 30 lbs and standing close beneath the Castle walls he flung the weight clean over the top.The people still show strangers the place where he stood and the portion of the Castle on which he cast the Sledge. This district always possessed men of great strength. In modern times the
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: An tSr. Seosamh; An tSr. Berchmans

4921744/4902679/5171007.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921744/4902679/5171007.text:
There is a story told about a brave warrior of long ago named Donal na Casgal who lived in the caves of Gortmore a few miles from Mallow.He was of the O'Keeffe Clan. There lived with him as he thought a faithful servant named Mairgéad Ná Ceallaigh and the two were very much attached. Every day she would row into Mallow for their provisions and as there was a price on Donal's head by the English soldiers she had to be very careful and even carried a gun with her. Then one day she got friendly with the English soldiers and by and by they forced her to tell them
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: An tSr. Seosamh; An tSr. Berchmans

4921779/4906495/5177686.title: Hidden Treasure
4921779/4906495/5177686.text: In one of the fields in the farm of Yellow Hill, a crock of gold was placed by a woman, Mary O'Connell, who still guards it with three dogs. One attempt was made by a near neighbour to capture the treasure but on his approach he saw a foxy woman combing her hair which was long and foxy and three dogs guarding her. He dropped his spade and shovel which he brought with him. No gold was found in my district. Joan O'HanlonYellow HillMallowCo. CorkTold byMr O'HanlonYellow HillMallowCo. Cork

4921780/4906588/5178089.title: A Local Industry in the Past
4921780/4906588/5178089.text: About fifty years ago a gentleman farmer named Mr George Bolster lived at Currabower, near Lombardstown.  He was the owner of three farms at that time, and was also the owner of a mill, for the manufacturing of artificial manure called bone manure.  He used to collect all the bones that could be had for that purpose.Once a week he sent his men and horses to Cork for the raw material which was imported from a foreign country for the manufacturing of this manure.  The farmers found it very profitable more especially for the growing of the turnip crop, but they also used it for other purposes and in most cases it gave a great return.  It was far more advantageous to the farmer and gave a better result than the artificial manure that is manufactured at the present day.

4921784/4906867/5178538.title: Giants
4921784/4906867/5178538.text: 83 Giants. When Blarney Castle was being built the giants who were building it were drawing stones from all parts of the country. There was a bugle at the castle to call them. Whenever they would hear it they would drop their stones and run. One day as a giant was passing through the townland of Gurranes he heard the bugle. He dropped two stones which fixed into the ground and has been standing there to-day. Collected 10 - 7 - 1938 Told by: Mr. Eugene O'ConnellGlantane, Mallow.

4921784/4906868/5178541.title: Giants
4921784/4906868/5178541.text: Many years ago a giant lived near Lyre.  He was a huge man being well over eight feet in height.  He lifted many huge stones - chief among them being a large rock, which he put up on a six foot wall.  It is said that the stone weighed about eight cwts.  He could do as much work in one day as any of the local men could do in a week.

4811628/4803973/5178699.title: Giant's Dream
4811628/4803973/5178699.text:
(continued from previous page)
heard him said that if himself were then alive (when that would happen) that he would throw aslate over atown land of them."



These Giants who lived (according to tradition) in this district always fought when they met. Conán Maol fought also on top of Owen Hill. Diarmuid always chose the top of Owen Hill for a fight.



"These lived in Beara (70 miles west) and had Dens there". "They never came here - afraid of the Giants"

5162154/5159362/5180702.title: A Giant
5162154/5159362/5180702.text:
Forty years ago there lived over the Old Bridge a giant named Tom Mcgrath. He was six feet six inches in height, and was nick-named "The Balk". A balk was locally known as the bark of a tree. Although a very strong man he was not a good work-man, and men of half his size could work
(continues on next page)
5162154/5159362/5180702.school_info: School: Clochar na Toirbhirte, Cluain Meala

5162155/5159429/5181080.title: Giants or Hags
5162155/5159429/5181080.text: There is a story told about two giant huge stones. Each would weigh about a hundred tons. Those stones were in the Nire district. They are supposed to be brought there by a Giant when given a hop, step and a jump from the Knockmealdown mountains across to the Comeragh mountains. It is supposed that he had a stone on each of his hands, when he landed in the comeragh mountains he threw the stone backwards. He cut a channel through the Comeragh mountains with his heels. His name was Fionn. There is a place up in Tipperary called the Devil's bit. It is supposed that a Devil was passing there and he took a bite out of the hill.

4921683/4889753/5184098.title: Giants and Warriors
4921683/4889753/5184098.text: 1.A long time ago it was said, that a giant lived in this district. There is an old story told about this giant. Long ago it was said, that a giant lived in the townland of Tuireen, and one day there was a man working in a field, and the giant came to him as he was ploughing the field, and he demanded the plough and from him, but the man refused and they had a fight, the man being victorious. The man reported it to headquarter officials and they came to get the giant, but he ran off when he saw them coming and they chased hm through the fields, and he took up a of a rock and threw it at them killing two of them.

4921685/4889824/5184344.title: Giants
4921685/4889824/5184344.text: Once upon a time there lived a giant near Bandon, by the name of Jim Dempsey. One day he called to a gentleman farmer who lived in Currenure Innishannon looking for work. At that time the farmer was ploughing a bawn field and in this field was a large stone which either a man or a horse could shift it from where it was. Take this stone out of the way and I will give you a sovereign said the farmer The giant took the huge stone in his big hands and threw it about five yards away in the ploughed ground The farmer was so pleased with the giant that he gave him the pound immediately. The stone is still to be seen where the giant threw it.

4921838/4895713/5184389.title: Games I Play
4921838/4895713/5184389.text:
(continued from previous page)
When all the colours are known, the angel's party and the devil's party have tug-of-war



Long ago there lived in Araglin a giant of a woman called "Beit Ní Bhrin." The dwelling place of this giantess was a dark cave. In this cave there were born to her two sons who were giants also.   In those years there was at the other side of the Black-Water a mansion house. In this house there was a lot of gold and silver and jewels kept. "Bet Ní Bhrin" knew this, and her sons now were big, string able giants. One night they planned to go and plunder the mansion. The two sons started off on their journey about midnight. When they reached the gate leading to the mansion they were charged by a monstrous bull-dog.    Their
(continues on next page)

4921847/4896403/5184736.title: Stories of Giants
4921847/4896403/5184736.text:
The old inhabitants of this village relate many stories about giants.  One old told me an interesting tale about a giant called Oscar.             He dwelt in an underground cave in the hill of Cnoc-an-Ceoig about  two miles from Ballynoe.  He became a source of great alarm to the inhabitants of the parish, as he devoured several cattle every day.               Many attempts were made to prevent his daily ravages, but each one was unsuccessful.  Many brave young men attacked the giant in single combat, but each one failed.               At that time, there dwelt in this parish, a wealthy chieftain, who had a beautiful daughter.            The chieftain offered her hand in marriage to anyone who would kill the giant. A very poor man determined to win the hand of the girl.  Despite the efforts of his friends to dissuade him, he set out one lonely night with
(continues on next page)

5177632/5174576/5188119.title: Historical Tradition
5177632/5174576/5188119.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



16th May, 1939. Stories of Giants.At Rathclooney Lake, which is about six miles north east of Ennis two giants were supposed to have fought in olden times. They fight began at dawn and lasted until dark and then they stopped for that night. Early next morning the fight began and in the middle of the second day one of the giants killed the other. The way it was fought was by pelting rocks at one another across the lake. To the present day huge rocks are at the place where these giants fought. The late Mr. John McInerney of Cloona Lough, about six miles north east of Ennis, put up a ten hundred weight rolling stone on a car before his breakfast and also a huge stump of an oak tree single-handed.
(continues on next page)

5177632/5174580/5188124.title: A Collection of Prayers
5177632/5174580/5188124.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



30th May, 1938. Stories of Giants.Many huge rocks are to be seen to the present day at each side of Rathclooney Lake, which is six miles north-east of Ennis. It was supposed that the two giants fought there by throwing rocks at one another. The fight lasted a day and a half and then one was killed with a terrific blow on the stomach. Near Cappafean, a remote district, which is seven miles north-east of Ennis, is a huge rock, which is split down the centre. This was supposed to have been split by a giant,
(continues on next page)

4921870/4897444/5190494.title: Stories of Giants
4921870/4897444/5190494.text:
A giant wanted to meet another giant. The other giant was afraid and his wife put him into a cradle. She thought of a plan. She baked a cake and she put nails and irons into it.When the giant came she gave the cake to him to eat. When he was eating the cake the nails and irons got caught in his gums and all his teeth were pulled.The woman told him that she had a baby giant in the cradle. So he went over to the baby giant. He put his hand into the baby giants mouth and the baby bit it. He got afraid when he saw that the baby giant was very strong and he did not want to meet the father because he thought that he would kill him at once.A giant named Jim Cooney nicknamed "Carraigean Ciarraige" lived near Carrigane Cross, Carrigtwohill, Co. Cork. He lived at the time of Cromwell and he fought several battles against him. He met another giant named Seaman Ellane in the East Ferry, Midleton, Co. Cork. They wanted to challenge each other
(continues on next page)

5177653/5177247/5190799.title: (no title)
5177653/5177247/5190799.text:
243Biddy Early was a famous Clare witch that lived during the early half of the last century.She resided near Feakle and the ruins of her house can still be seen It was a mud cabin.A man from Newmarket-on-Fergus went to Biddy about a horse that was in him.Biddy gave him a bottle and told him to shake some of the contents on the horse ,and it would be cured but to be careful not to let anyone take the bottle from him.When he was coming home he was met at Fenloe Cross by three men who did their best to wrestle the bottle and did as he was told and the horse got better.



Long ago three giants were living together in Co.Clare.  Another
(continues on next page)

5162182/5161897/5190899.title: Giants and Fairies
5162182/5161897/5190899.text:
Line of players.  One in front.  The player in front says to each in the line from left to right:- Take a giant or Take a fairy or Take two giants or 1/2 a fairy or 1/4 a giant.A giant is a big long step.A fairy is a very short step.The player ordered takes the step or steps ordered and the first to reach the one in front is winner.  The winner then give the orders.



One player stands on floor or ground and sings:- Who'll come into my wee ring my wee ring my wee ring.Who'll come into my wee ring and make it a little bigger.Someone comes in, then they sing as above and so on till a big ring is formed.  That ring may be used for playing another game.

4921731/4894478/5191778.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921731/4894478/5191778.text:
There are no stories of Giants or Warriors told locally.



The Leipreachan or Mermaid is not known locally.



There is no strange animal known locally.
4921731/4894478/5191778.school_info: School: An Cnocán Bán, Áth Treasa

4921774/4905762/5191989.title: Giants and Warriors
4921774/4905762/5191989.text: Kanturk got its name through a Giant and a boar. Through jealousy Fionn Mach Cumhall sent his boar to fight Dicrmudh Doinn. And they faught from Carriganima to Kanturk and Diarmuidh be-headed the boar near Kanturk. It is called Ceann-na-Tuirch. How Caishleán Adhbhara in Mhushera got its name it is as follows:- a wild tribe of Giants lived there and some Holy man came to convert them. He forgot a book in the place. He ordered his servant to go back and bring his book. His servant said that the giants would kill him if he went back but the holy man said No! go and bring it. When he went back he found the book untouched and no sight of the Giants ever since. The ford is named Cas-is Tabhar Mo Labhar Dom - Cashleán Oura Mhushera. Giants lived by the bow-an-arow killing all sorts of animal and birds and lived in caves. There is a Giant's cave near Carriganima called Leabh Dhiarmhudhe with forms of beds cut into the rock.

4921803/4908683/5192385.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
4921803/4908683/5192385.text: The story is told of "Kitty the Blue" who put a ball of blue in a cup & whirled the cup around. She then read fortunes of people. She was called a "Cup Tosser".
4921803/4908683/5192385.school_info: School: Cill Bheoláin (B.), Áth an Mhuilinn, Ráth Luirc

5162120/5155842/5196664.title: Giants
5162120/5155842/5196664.text: About four miles north side of Clonmel town there is a place known as Giant's Grave. It is said that a giant lived there and he is supposed to be buried there. There is a grave with a large flat stone and people say if that stone were removed the remains of this giant's bones could be seen. Giant Donovan lived at the foot of Slieve-na-mBan. He was very proud of his strength and use to go to everybody's house in the neighbourhood and tell them all the fights he had during the year and whom he had killed. He used to visit them once a year. One day he had a fight with another giant in a field near Killusty. He knocked the other giant to the ground and kicked him until he thought he was dead. Then he ran home to tell the news. On his way home he had to pass through a wood near Slieve-na-mBan.

5162122/5155956/5198724.title: Old Houses
5162122/5155956/5198724.text: All the houses in olden times were thatched with straw either wheaten or oaten and rushes got from the bogs.  the walls were made of yellow clay mixed with chopped straw.  This was kept continually walled whilst building and the cut to the required thickness.  All the old houses had a "Settlebed" in the kitchen.  Used as a seat during the day and then pulled out and made into a bed for the night.  They are still used and are to be seen in some of the local houses.  The fire place was generally at the gable end wall or in the centre wall.  About 35 years ago, there was a house built against the ditch at Burkes of the Hill, Clerihan, which had no chimney.  The fire used to be in the centre of the floor and the smoke escaped through a hole in the roof.  Inhabited by a family named Slattery.  Their descendants are still alive named Donnells of Darcy's Cross.  The chimneys were made of wattles or sallies covered over with clay called "switch chimneys".After the night of the "Big Wind" most of the houses were knocked down, so people had to build their houses of mud as quickly as possible.Many of these houses had no glass windows.  These were made of sheep skin.The old floors were made of yellow clay.  After a new floor being put down, a dance was held for the purpose of binding the clay.

5177621/5173804/5199110.title: Folklore - Giants
5177621/5173804/5199110.text: Not very long ago there lived a huge man out near Middle Line near Scariff. He was as strong as six men put together. One day he went to the bog of Baha for a creel of turf. On his way home the wheel of the car broke and he could not fix it. So he put the wheel up on top of the load and he caught the axle by one hand and he carried the load home.Not so long after that he began contrasting the neighbours, he was then put to jail by the peelers. When he arrived at the door of the jail, he had to creep in because he was so big. He got on very good there because he did very hard work and the keepers fed him well, soon after that he died after leaving jail.

5177621/5173805/5199112.title: Folklore - Giants
5177621/5173805/5199112.text: Once upon a time there lived a man in the parish of "The Island", who was endowed with superhuman strength. His appetite was something ferocious. It is said that he could eat as much as four ordinary men. An old saying of his was "A goose is nice picking after four pounds of Long Bottom".He had a very big sow to sell that weighted about five hundredweights. He had five men assisting him lifting the sow into the creel. Just as they were about to put the sow into the creel she escaped from their grasp and fell into a sink hole. He became furious with the way they let the sow go. Then he caught the sow by himself and threw her into the creel.

5177621/5173806/5199114.title: Folklore - Giants
5177621/5173806/5199114.text: Once upon a time a giant and his wife lived in Clonosquer. They were very strong. One day both of them went up to a mountain near by.Then the giant took up a very large flat rock and threw it a very long distance. Then his wife took up a round rock and threw it but did not throw it as far as her husband. In later times priests used to kneel on the flat rock and the prints of their knees are their still. The two rocks are to be seen in John Nuggent's field in Clonosquer.

5177621/5173807/5199118.title: Folklore - Giants
5177621/5173807/5199118.text: Long ago there lived in Six-Mile-Bridge a Giant named Andy he used to live in a tent made of bags. His food was sheep and goats.One day he met a man and told him if he was able to trow a stone  farther than he was he would kill him. The giant first threw a stone about twenty pounds, then the man threw it but did not go as far as the giant. The giant was going to kill him but the had a gun and shot the giant.

5177647/5176346/5200665.title: Giants
5177647/5176346/5200665.text:
There are no giants in this locality now but there were long ago because there is a field called the giant's field. It is said that there was a rock there called the giant's rock. One day there were two giants asleep. The people were very much afraid of these giants. They were after walking a long distance and were tired so they fell asleep. There was a little boy coming along the road and he was afraid to pass for fear the giants might hear him and he went up to the top of a high tree. While the giants were snoring the boy thought of a trick. He let down a stone and put out one of the giant's eyes. The giant woke up all of a sudden and the two giants started fighting and one killed the other. Before one killed the other the two giants did terrible fighting. They tore up trees from the roots and all of a sudden the tree that Jack was on was pulled up. Jack hid himself under one of the branches of the tree. Then the giant went home and when he was going he pulled some
(continues on next page)

4798667/4788636/5203234.title: A Giant Story
4798667/4788636/5203234.text: A giant story 19-12-38.Two giants lived long ago named Tom and John. One was as tall as a spear and the other was as broad as a cock of hay They used to make the women bake big oven caked and the men had to bring them turf. They used to steal cows, sheep, and pigs. At last the people made up their minds to kill the giants. So two men set out one day. They brought a mouse and a bee. When they went in, the two giants were in bed and the mouse and the bee went into the bed. The bee began stinging. The two giants got mad and one thought it was Tom. The other thought it was John. The bee kept on stinging and the mouse kept on biting. At last the two giants jumped out of bed. Tom hit John and John hit Tom At last their two heads rolled off. The boys were glad that the giants were killed So they went home laughing

4798667/4788658/5203242.title: A Giant Story
4798667/4788658/5203242.text:
A giant StoryThere once lived a big giant. He was very wicked. He used to kill people, and make them do his work by force. There lived a family man near his castle. There were three sons in this family. One day the giant brought off one of the men. He told him that if he was not able to eat as much as him in the evening he would kill him. The man worked all day hoping he would be able to eat as much as the giant in the evening. When evening came the man went to the castle. The giant had a pig pot of stirabout ready. They both began eating but the giant ate a lot more than the man. So the giant killed him. The next day the giant brought the second son and told him the same thing. In the evening the man came. The giant had the stirabout ready, the two began eating but the giant ate alot more than the man so he killed him. The next day he brought the third son. This fellow was clever than the rest. He had a leather bag inside his clothes. He knew that the giant would not be able to eat as much as him. He worked all day. In the evening he went to the castle. The giant had the stirabout ready. The both began eating. The man eat enough first
(continues on next page)

5215796/5211621/5219286.title: Stories of Giants and Warriors
5215796/5211621/5219286.text:
Once upon a time, there was a giant living in Ireland, and there was another one living in England also. The Irish giant challenged the English giant to fight. One day, the Irish man heard that the other man was coming over. He changed himself into a small boy and went into a cradle.
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208004/5219353.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208004/5219353.text:
Long ago there lived big men in Ireland called giants.  They used to take a big heavy stone containing two tons weight and put it on their shoulders and throw it a long distance off.  We are also told that one of them would eat one cwt of potatoes for their dinner and they would eat a big cake containing about two stone of flour.  Long ago two giant lived in a little
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208031/5219405.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208031/5219405.text:
There was three giants living in Ayle. They were very strong men. There was  a poor old man living in a house beside the giant castle. They told him if he told anyone about their doings they would put him to death. The poor man was very much afraid of the giants. One day the man went to the guards and told them the story. The guards
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208110/5219485.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208110/5219485.text:
Long ago there lived a giant in the village of Mace. His name was Pat Mc Hugh but the people called him Páidin. He was about nine feet in hight. For one meal he could eat about seven stone of potatoes & six pounds of meat. He lived in a small house on the side of a hill. The giant was always stealing fowl & turf from the people round the place. So the all decided to kill him or drive him out of the country. They
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208193/5220793.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208193/5220793.text:
There was once a giant in this village long ago. There was another giant in Killawalla. The giant in Killawalla used to come down to this giant. Every day they used go out through the country killing all that would come before them. One day they were after a little boy and they could not get up to him. The house was not far from him. So he got to the house and they were after him all the time. As soon as he got inside the door he told the father to get the gun quickly because there is two
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208316/5221376.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208316/5221376.text:
Long ago there lived a great big giant with two heads. He lived in Dun Cashel. He was the ugliest looking creature you could leave eyes on. All the people in that district were afraid of him. He used come to the houses at night when the people were sleeping and steal the hens and geese, cattle and everything he could get his hands on. At last the people could stand it no longer and the
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208401/5221592.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208401/5221592.text:
Once upon a time long ago there lived a mighty giant on the borders of Gorthbawn. He lived on the flesh of human beings. He had such a mighty voice that he could talk to all the other giants of Ireland without leaving his own door. One day he sent a challenger to all the giants of Ireland saying he was not afraid of anyone of them. One day a giant came to give
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208553/5235736.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208553/5235736.text:
Long ago there lived a big gaint in the village of Cooloughra. The people called him big tady. He lived in a small house at the foot of a hill. This gaint had a huge appitite. He could eat six stone of potatoes at a time & eight pounds of meat. One day an old man was passing by and the gaint came out and told him that if he was not able to run six miles he would kill him. The old man said he would.
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208622/5235904.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208622/5235904.text:
Long ago there lived two great giants together in the one house. They were very generous to each other all the time. They walked together and they talked and ate their meals to-gether. One night they tried their strength. One of them said that he would hold Tom Thumb in his ear but he failed. Then the other great giant said that he would hold little Tom in his ear and so he did. That night the two giants went to bed and they slept soundly. During the night they heard a great noise in the
(continues on next page)

5215779/5208661/5235940.title: Fathaigh
5215779/5208661/5235940.text:
Long ago there was three giants living near our village. They were three brothers and their names were Mc Donnaghs. They were very cruel men and the people did not like them and they decided to kill them. One day all the people gathered and they made up there minds to kill them. These giants lived high up on a hill and they had a very small house. So one night a man and a mouse & a bee went to the giant's house. When they came to the house the bee went in the window and the giants were sleeping and the mouse bit the
(continues on next page)

5236078/5218230/5240712.title: Giants
5236078/5218230/5240712.text:
There were two giants in Murrish and they lived in a small house. They used to go out fighting every day. They used to take a big rock in their hands and break it. They used to kill the people and eat them. When they died they put a big rock over them



There was a man once and he used to kill priests. One day he told his wife that he was dying. His wife told the priest to come to anoint him. There was a parish priest and a curate in the parish. The curate said he would but the parish priest would not let him. When the parish priest was gone the curate followed him. When the parish priest went into the house
(continues on next page)

5236078/5218231/5240714.title: Seán na Sagart
5236078/5218231/5240714.text:
(continued from previous page)
Seán killed him. He came out then and followed the curate and when he was crossing a river the priest flung the spear back at him and killed him. He was buried in Ballintubber and a tree grew over his grave and turned down over the grave in order that no one would kneel on his grave.



There was a giant in a house near Aughagower. He used to kill all the people he got up to. One time a boy went into a giant's house with an axe and got the giant sleeping. He cut the head of the giant and buried him in the mountains of Curvey.

5236078/5218261/5240769.title: Giants
5236078/5218261/5240769.text:
There lived a giant in Ireland and he was a great hunter. He took a great big rock and he flung it at his mighty best into the sea and it is said by very old people that that is the Isle of Man.A giant from Ireland and a giant from Scotland started to make a road in which they could walk from Ireland to Scotland. They started to make it and when they had a bit of it made they started to fight and they made no more of it. The part that is made is called the giants causeway.



There is a river in Curvey and a water dog lives in it. A man named John Lavelle was crossing in a place where the water dog was to pass. He had just
(continues on next page)

5236078/5218301/5240830.title: Sean na Sagart
5236078/5218301/5240830.text:
(continued from previous page)

There were two giants at a place called Murrisk and they were always fighting. It was in a field they used to fight, and there was a rock on the fence. One day as they were fighting one of giants killed the other. The victorious giant took the rock and broke it and it is called the giants rock and it is still to be seen there.

5236078/5218338/5240917.title: Giants
5236078/5218338/5240917.text: There was a giant in Aughagower one time his name was Cloughannra. There is a stone in Aughagower and there was no one able to lift this stone but him. He went up the country then to a place called Sruagh and there used to be young lads throwing a half hundred weight. Cloughannra put his foot in the wring of the half-hundred and he fired it past all the lads. They wanted him then to fire it with his hand as he did and he fired it five times past them all.

5236078/5218395/5240992.title: Giants
5236078/5218395/5240992.text:
There were two giants one time in a small house. They used to go fighting every day for a month. They were fighting one day and one of them said to the other I will kill you. At last one of them got killed. One of them split a rock and it is there yetThere was a giant in a house near Aughagower. He used to kill all the people he got up to. One time a boy went into the giants house with an axe and got the giant sleeping. He cut the head off the giant and buried him in the mountains of Curvey.A prince had two children and a giant was living in a wood. Every day he used to come to the prince's house. One day he

5274069/5270878/5274073.title: Folklore - Giant
5274069/5270878/5274073.text:
One night last week a few neighbours were at my house in cuart and one of them told the followingA giant came over from Scotland to fight an Irish giant named which was Fionn Mac Cumhail. When the Irish giant saw the Scoth giant coming he went into a crodle and his wife said that Fionn was gone hunting. She made a gridle cake and the Scotch giant was hardly able to eat it and he saw

There is a giant stone on the Hill of Knockaulin which was trown by Fionn Mac Cumhaill from the Hill of Allen about twelve miles away. The marks of his five fingers are on itAbout half  mile from the Curragh is a hollow
(continues on next page)

5260471/5256449/5275494.title: Giants
5260471/5256449/5275494.text: There was a man named Fionn Mac Cumhaill who lived in Kildare. One day he threw a stone from the Hill of Allen to the Hill of Knockaulin. The stone is to be seen there still and the marks of his five fingers are seen on it. There was another very strong man named Donnelly. One day he and Cooper were fighting. Donnelly killed Cooper and the footprints of their feet are seen leading down to the hollow where they fought.
